choices.text: Non hemorrhagic stroke at any time

questions.text: Clear contraindications to the use of fibrinolytic agents are all except?
questions.solution:
Clear contraindications to the use of fibrinolytic agents include

  1. a history of cerebrovascular hemorrhage at any time,
  2. a non-haemorrhagic stroke or other cerebrovascular event within the past year,
  3. marked hypertension (a reliably determined systolic arterial pressure >180 mmHg and/or a diastolic pressure >110 mmHg) at any time during the acute presentation,
  4. suspicion of aortic dissection, and
  5. active internal bleeding (excluding menses

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Relative contraindications to fibrinolytic therapy, which require assessment of the risk-to-benefit ratio, include current use of anticoagulants (international normalized ratio ≥2), a recent (<2 weeks) invasive or surgical procedure or prolonged (>10 min) cardiopulmonary resuscitation, known bleeding diathesis, pregnancy, a hemorrhagic ophthalmic condition (e.g., hemorrhagic diabetic retinopathy), active peptic ulcer disease, and a history of severe hypertension that is currently adequately controlled.

questions.text: Which of the following is a distinguishing feature of classic heatstroke (CHS) compared to exertional heatstroke (EHS)?
questions.solution:
OPTION A - Profuse diaphoresis is characteristic of EHS, not CHS

OPTION B - CHS is associated with hypernatremia secondary to dehydration, a feature resulting from limited access to fluids and a sedentary state.

OPTION C - Rhabdomyolysis is common in EHS due to intense muscular exertion.

OPTION D - Hyponatremia and hypoglycemia are more typical in EHS.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Differences between classic and exertional heat stroke.

questions.text: Health communication is very important aspect from public health point of view because of the various functions it has. All of the following are functions of health communication except?
questions.solution:
Health communication has to cater to the following needs:

  • Information: The primary function of Health Communication is to provide scientific knowledge or information to provide about health problems and how to maintain and promote health.
  • Education: Education of the general public as an integral part of the prevention-oriented approach to health and disease problems and the basis of all education is communication.
  • Motivation: It is a power that drives a person from within to act. One of the goals of Health Communication is to motivate individuals to translate health information into personal behaviour and lifestyle for their own health.
  • Persuasion: The sole purpose of communication is to influence. Persuasion is a conscious attempt by one individual to change on influence the general beliefs, understanding, values and behaviour of another individual or group of individuals in some desired way.
  • Counselling: Counselling is a process that can help people understand better and deal with their problems and communicate better with those with whom they are emotionally involved.
  • Raising morale: Morale is the capacity of a group of people to pull together persistently or consistently. Communication vertical and horizontal internal and external is the first step in any attempt to raise morale of the health team or a group of people.
  • Health development: Communication can play a powerful role in health development by helping to defuse knowledge in respect of the goals of development and preparing the people for the roles expected of them.
  • Health organisation: Communication is the life and blood of an organisation. There are two major directions in which communications within an organisation flow, these are vertical and horizontal communications.

questions.text: 55-year-old male present with severe abdominal pain, history of blood in vomiting - Haematemesis 2 episodes in a week. There is significant history of weight loss with reduced appetite. Patient is having complain of postprandial heaviness. Which of the following is investigation of choice in this patient to evaluate underlying condition?
questions.solution:
• In given clinical scenario - Patient is having warning signs of underlying malignant condition in form of severe abdominal pain haematemesis and weight loss - Provisional clinical diagnosis should be oesophageal or stomach malignant lesion.
  • CT scan is investigation of choice in detection of intraluminal and extraluminal malignant mass lesion of oesophagus and thorax.
  • Ultrasound have limitation in visualisation of oesophagus - so not recommended for intraluminal lesion of stomach and oesophagus.
  • Barium study have limitation in visualisation of extraluminal mass lesions. Barium study can be used as a screening method. Staging cannot be done on barium study.
  • X-ray limited role in visualisation of soft tissue lesions in oesophagus and stomach.

choices.text: Disruption of DNA synthesis by inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase
Direct action on tubal smooth muscle to expel the pregnancy

questions.text: What is the primary mechanism by which methotrexate treats ectopic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
A. Inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis

Methotrexate does not inhibit prostaglandin synthesis. Drugs like NSAIDs work via this mechanism, which is unrelated to methotrexate's action.

B. Disruption of DNA synthesis by inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase

Methotrexate is a folate antagonist. It inhibits the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase, which is essential for the synthesis of purines and pyrimidines, thereby preventing DNA synthesis and cellular replication. This mechanism is crucial for stopping the growth of trophoblastic tissue in ectopic pregnancies.

C. Direct action on tubal smooth muscle to expel the pregnancy

Methotrexate does not act directly on smooth muscle. This mechanism is associated with medications like prostaglandins or oxytocin.

D. Stimulation of uterine contractions

Methotrexate does not stimulate uterine contractions; instead, it halts the growth of ectopic trophoblastic tissue, leading to resorption

choices.text: Plasma cell infiltration with increased IgG4-positive plasma cells

questions.text: What is the characteristic histopathological feature of IgG4-related disease?
questions.solution:
1. Lymphocytic infiltration: Lymphocytic infiltration is a common feature of many inflammatory conditions, but it is not the characteristic histopathological feature of IgG4-related disease.
  2. Plasma cell infiltration with increased IgG4-positive plasma cells: The characteristic histopathological feature of IgG4-related disease is a dense infiltration of plasma cells, with a high proportion of IgG4-positive plasma cells.
  3. Neutrophilic infiltration: Neutrophilic infiltration is a feature of acute inflammatory conditions, but it is not the characteristic histopathological feature of IgG4-related disease.
  4. Eosinophilic infiltration: Eosinophilic infiltration is a feature of some allergic and parasitic conditions, but it is not the characteristic histopathological feature of IgG4-related disease.

Key Takeaway:

Definition

  • A component of a systemic immune mediated fibroinflammatory condition which generally manifests in the kidney as an acute or chronic interstitial nephritis with lymphoplasmacytic inflammation containing increased IgG4+ plasma cells, tubulointerstitial immune complex deposits and frequently storiform fibrosis, which may be mass forming/tumor-like.
  • Varying degrees of glomerular involvement, predominantly membranous nephropathy, can also be seen.

Essential features

  • Usually chronic interstitial nephritis with dense lymphoplasmacytic inflammation with a predominance of IgG4+ plasma cells (hallmark).
  • Some degree of fibrosis, usually storiform in character
  • Generally associated with other systemic manifestations of IgG4 disease
  • Good response to glucocorticoids
  • Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA) related disease has been excluded

Microscopic (histologic) description

  • Most cases show chronic interstitial nephritis with dense lymphoplasmacytic interstitial inflammation with prominent plasma cells
  • Increased IgG4+ plasma cells
  • Storiform fibrosis

questions.text: The fifth vital sign is:
questions.solution:
• Temperature is the fifth vital sign and constitutes part of the intraoperative monitoring.
  • Normal body temperature is tightly regulated to within 0.2° of 37°C Shivering is a reflex controlled by the hypothalamus which has a temperature regulating centre (the thalamus is not involved).
  • Brown fat may release fatty acids after oxidation, an action mediated by the adrenergic system. Certain endogenous factors are known to be pyrogenic.
  • These include interleukins, interferons and tumour necrosis factor. Normal body temperature shows diurnal variation with a peak in the afternoon and a trough at night.

choices.text: Freshly collected watery stool is the specimen of choice for diagnosing acute cholera cases, ideally before starting antibiotic treatment.
Rectal swabs are preferred for diagnosing acute cholera cases in adults, especially when stool specimens cannot be collected.
If there is a delay in specimen transport, fecal samples should be inoculated into transport media such as Alkaline salt transport medium or Cary-Blair medium.
For convalescent patients or carriers, a rectal swab is the preferred specimen as it provides a better chance of detecting Vibrio cholerae.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about specimen collection and transport for the diagnosis of cholera is incorrect?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Correct. Freshly collected watery stool is the preferred specimen for diagnosing acute cholera, as it is the best source for detecting the Vibrio cholerae bacteria.
  • Option B: Incorrect. Rectal swabs are not the preferred specimen for acute cholera cases; they are instead preferred for convalescent patients or carriers who may no longer have watery stool but still harbor the pathogen.
  • Option C: Correct. If there is a delay in specimen transport, fecal specimens should be inoculated into transport media like Cary-Blair or Alkaline salt transport medium to preserve the sample and ensure the survival of the pathogen during transport.
  • Option D: Correct. For convalescent patients or carriers, rectal swabs are preferred since they can still harbor Vibrio cholerae, even after symptoms have resolved.

Key Takeaways:

  • Watery stool is crucial for acute cholera diagnosis, while rectal swabs are used for carriers and convalescent patients.
  • Proper transport and inoculation into appropriate media are essential to preserve specimen integrity and allow successful pathogen detection.

questions.text: Which of the following nerve roots are primarily affected in Erb's palsy, a type of brachial plexus injury?
questions.solution:
Erb's palsy typically results from an injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus, which involves the C5 and C6 nerve roots. This leads to weakness or paralysis of the muscles innervated by these roots, such as the deltoid, biceps, and brachialis, causing a characteristic "waiter's tip" deformity/policeman's tip hand deformity (arm adducted, internally rotated, and pronated).

Erb's Palsy

  • Definition: Erb's Palsy is a neurological deficit involving injury to the C5 and C6 nerve roots of the brachial plexus, affecting the upper limb.
  • Causes:
    • Most commonly caused by excessive lateral traction or stretching (Option D) of a baby's head and neck during childbirth.
    • In adults, it can result from trauma involving forceful separation of the neck from the shoulder.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Affects nerves that control the deltoid, biceps, brachialis, and brachioradialis muscles, leading to paralysis or weakness in shoulder abduction, external rotation, elbow flexion, and forearm supination.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • (Option A)"Policeman's Tip Deformity": Arm is adducted and internally rotated, elbow extended, forearm pronated, and wrist flexed.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Based on clinical presentation, history of trauma or birth complications, and possibly imaging (X-rays, MRI).
  • Management:
    • Conservative: Physical therapy and exercises for mild cases.
    • Surgical: Nerve repair or transfer for severe cases not improving within 3-6 months.
  • Prognosis:
    • Depends on the severity; mild cases often recover fully, while severe cases may need surgical intervention.

Erb's Palsy requires timely diagnosis and management to optimize outcomes, especially in cases involving childbirth.

Nerve injuries and neuropathies

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is considered a "club drug" associated with dance clubs and raves?
questions.solution:
Option A: Cocaine: While cocaine is a stimulant, it is not typically categorized as a "club drug" specifically tied to dance clubs and raves.

Option B: Methamphetamine: Methamphetamine is a key "club drug", often used in settings like dance clubs and raves.

Option C: Heroin: Heroin is an opioid and is not associated with the club scene.

Option D: Alcohol: Although common in social settings, alcohol is not categorized as a "club drug".

  • Cocaine History:
    • Cocaine has been used for over 15 centuries.
    • Cocaine is derived from the Erythroxylum coca
    • First isolated in 1855 and used as a local anesthetic by 1880.
  • Methods of Use:
    • Common methods: snorting, injection, smoking (freebasing, crack).
    • Inhalation (snorting) is the least dangerous; smoking and injecting are more dangerous.
  • Crack Cocaine:
    • Crack is a potent freebase form of cocaine, highly addictive, and associated with intense cravings and violence.
  • Club Drugs:
    • Includes drugs like LSD, MDMA, GHB, ketamine, and Rohypnol.
    • Often used at clubs and raves; GHB and Rohypnol are sometimes used in date rape.
  • Stimulant Intoxication:
    • Symptoms: euphoria, agitation, tachycardia, hypertension, and potentially dangerous behavior.
    • Severe intoxication may lead to confusion, seizures, or coma.
  • Stimulant Withdrawal:
    • Symptoms: depression, anxiety, fatigue, hunger, and cravings.
    • Depression is the most serious withdrawal symptom and can lead to suicidal behavior.
  • Stimulant-Induced Disorders:
    • Psychotic disorder: Paranoid delusions, auditory hallucinations, formication.
    • Mood disorder: Bipolar or depressive symptoms, depending on intoxication or withdrawal.
    • Anxiety disorder: Panic-like symptoms.
    • OCD-like behaviors: Stereotyped rituals after high doses.
  • Sexual Dysfunction: High doses of stimulants can lead to erectile dysfunction.
  • Sleep Disorders: Stimulant use can cause insomnia during intoxication and hypersomnolence during withdrawal.

questions.text: All the following constitute primary active transport except
questions.solution:
Active transport is vectorial movement of a solute across a membrane against a concentration gradient, and thus requires energy (frequently derived from the hydrolysis of ATP); a specific transporter (pump) is involved.

Primary Active Transport: Involves the direct use of energy (usually from ATP hydrolysis) to move ions or molecules against their concentration gradient.

Examples include:

  • Sodium-potassium pump (Na+/K+-ATPase): Actively pumps Na+ out and K+ into the cell using ATP.
  • Calcium pump (Ca2+-ATPase): Actively pumps Ca2+ out of the cell or into organelles like the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
  • Potassium-hydrogen pump (H+/K+-ATPase): Pumps H+ out and K+ into cells (e.g., gastric parietal cells), using ATP.

Secondary Active Transport:

  • Relies on the electrochemical gradient established by primary active transport.
  • Na-Glucose Transporter (SGLT) is an example of secondary active transport.
  • The Na+-glucose transporter does not use ATP directly. Instead, it depends on the sodium gradient created by the ATP-consuming Na+/K+ pump. This makes it a secondary active transporter.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, pneumonia, and severe headache. He works on a sheep farm and is involved in shearing wool. What zoonosis should be suspected?
questions.solution:
Q fever, caused by Coxiella burnetii, is transmitted through inhalation of aerosols from infected sheep, goats, or cattle, especially during birthing or shearing. Symptoms include fever, pneumonia, and headache. Prevention includes proper disposal of animal waste and vaccination in high-risk populations.

Drug of choice: Doxycycline

questions.text: Which of the following muscle is not a part of the 2nd layer of the sole of the foot?
questions.solution:
Layers of the sole

  • There are 18 intrinsic muscles and 4 extrinsic tendons in the sole of the foot. The muscles of the sole are described in four layers from superficial to deep.
  • Neurovascular palne:
    • Superficial neurovascular plane between the first and second layers. Derived from the trunks of medial and lateral plantar nerves and the arteries.
    • Deep neurovascular plane between the third and fourth layers. Derived from the deep branches of the lateral plantar nerve and the artery
  • The muscles supplied by medial plantar nerve:
    • Abductor hallucis
    • Flexor digitorum brevis
    • First lumbrical
    • Flexor hallucis brevis
  • Rest all muscles supplied by lateral plantar nerve.

Key Points:

questions.text: A 58-year-old male was suffering from end stage renal disease. He underwent the transplant surgery, but the transplanted organ was rejected by immune system. Which among the following is primarily responsible rejection?
questions.solution:
• Option b: T cells are the primary drivers of acute cellular rejection, the most common type of organ rejection following transplantation.
    It directly attack donor cells expressing foreign MHC molecules, activates other immune cells and macrophages leading to inflammation, tissue destruction, and loss of graft function .
  • Option a: B cells are responsible for humoral immunity by producing antibodies. However, B cells are not the primary mediators of acute cellular rejection, which is more commonly observed after transplantation.
  • Option c: The innate immune system includes macrophages, natural killer cells, dendritic cells. It does not initiate the specific immune response targeting donor antigens, making it a secondary contributor.
  • Option d: T cell immune system is the most critical and direct effector in the rejection of transplanted organs. Therefore, this option is not accurate.

questions.text: What skin condition is characterized by the presence of coral red fluorescence under a Wood's lamp?
questions.solution:
• Etiological agent: Corynebacterium minutissimum
  • Lesions of erythrasma are asymptomatic, erythematous to hyperpigmented. Occurs in axilla, groin or inframammary area.

Colors on woods lamp:

  • Erythrasma - Coral red
  • Versicolor - Yellow
  • Tinea capitis(Microsporum sp.) - Blue-Green
  • Tinea capitis( T. scoenleinii) - Dull blue
  • Vitiligo - Chalky white

Option B, C and D do not show fluorescence on wood's lamp examination.

Key takeaway:

Erythrasma:

  • Etiological agent: Corynebacterium minutissimum
  • Lesions are asymptomatic, erythematous to hyperpigmented. Occurs in axilla, groin or inframammary area.
  • Colors on wood's lamp: Coral red

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl has fully developed breasts with the papilla projecting only slightly, and pubic hair is adult in quantity and type, spreading to the thighs. What Tanner stage does she belong to?
questions.solution: Tanner Stage 5 indicates full breast development with adult-type pubic hair extending to the thighs.

questions.text: The epithelium shown in the diagram below is seen in which of the following organ?
questions.solution:
• The epithelium shown in the diagram is transitional epithelium.
  • From the given option, it is seen in the ureter.

Transitional epithelium:

  • This is a multilayered epithelium and is 4 to 6 cells thick.
  • It differs from stratifi ed squamous epithelium in that the cells at the surface are not squamous.
  • The deepest cells are columnar or cuboidal.
  • The middle layers are made up of polyhedral or pear-shaped cells.
  • The cells of the surface layer are large and often shaped like an umbrella
  • In the urinary bladder, it is seen that cells of transitional epithelium can be stretched considerably without losing their integrity. When stretched it appears to be thinner and the cells become flattened.
  • Because of this distribution it is also called urothelium.
  • Location
    • Renal pelvis and calyces
    • Ureter and urinary bladder
    • Prostatic part of the urethra.
  • Function
    • At the surface of the epithelium the plasma membranes are unusual.
    • Embedded in the lipid layer of the membranes there are special glycoproteins.
    • It is believed that these glycoproteins make the membrane impervious and resistant to the toxic effects of substances present in urine, and thus afford protection to adjacent tissues.

Key Points:

  • Examples of the transitional epithelium:
    • Minor and major calyces of kidney
    • Renal pelvis
    • Ureter
    • Urinary bladder
    • Prostatic part of the urethra

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents with a history of chronic cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss. He has a past history of alcohol abuse and has been experiencing fatigue and weakness. On physical examination, he has clubbing of the fingers and a lung auscultation revealing crackles in the right lower lobe. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Tuberculosis may present similarly, but alcohol history and symptoms of weight loss and hemoptysis point more towards lung cancer.
  • Option B: The most likely diagnosis is lung cancer, especially in a patient with a smoking history, the patient's age, weight loss, hemoptysis, and clubbing.
  • Option C: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease would not typically present with hemoptysis and weight loss in this manner.
  • Option D: Pneumonia typically presents acutely and with more localized symptoms.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Clubbing, weight loss, and hemoptysis in an adult with alcohol use history are suggestive of lung cancer.

questions.text: Gold standard investigation for diagnosis of pancreatic divisum?
questions.solution:
Pancreas divisum is the commonest congenital pancreatic anomaly characterized by the failure of normal fusion of the dorsal and ventral ducts in the fetal period.

MRI and MRCP is gold standard investigation for evaluation of pancreato biliary duct anatomy to established diagnosis of pancreatic divisum

choices.text: It is primarily associated with increased gastric acid secretion due to gastrinomas in the pancreas only.
Diagnosis can be confirmed by a fasting serum gastrin level and a secretin stimulation test.
Proton pump inhibitors are contraindicated in the management of ZES.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome (ZES)?
questions.solution:
Option A: Incorrect. While gastrinomas primarily increase gastric acid secretion, they are not confined to the pancreas. They also occur in the duodenum and, less commonly, other parts of the gastrointestinal tract.

Option B: Incorrect. Gastrinomas are most commonly malignant, with a significant proportion metastasizing to the liver or regional lymph nodes.

Option C: Correct. Diagnosis of ZES relies on a fasting serum gastrin level (>1000 pg/mL) and confirmation through a secretin stimulation test, which distinguishes ZES from other causes of hypergastrinemia.

Option D: Incorrect. Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) are the cornerstone of ZES management as they effectively control gastric acid hypersecretion.

Key Takeaways:

  • ZES is characterized by gastrin-secreting tumors (gastrinomas) that cause hypergastrinemia and acid hypersecretion.
  • Most gastrinomas are malignant.
  • PPIs are critical for symptom control.

questions.text: Identify the electrolyte abnormality shows prolonged ventricular repolarisation & following ECG changes?
questions.solution:
OPTION A - Hyperkalemia produces a sequence of changes, usually beginning with narrowing and peaking (tenting) of the T waves.

Further elevation of extracellular K+ leads to AV conduction disturbances, diminution in P-wave amplitude, and widening of the QRS interval. Severe hyperkalemia eventually causes cardiac arrest with a slow sinusoidal type of mechanism ("sine-wave" pattern) followed by asystole.

OPTION B - Hypokalemia prolongs ventricular repolarization, often with prominent U waves.

OPTION C & D - Hypocalcemia typically prolongs the QT interval (ST portion), whereas hypercalcemia shortens it.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

choices.text: Precision level is set at higher level.
Power of study is set at higher level.

questions.text: Sample size will be increased in all situations except?
questions.solution:
Sample size increases if:

  • Prevalence of diseases under study is low in population.
  • Precision level is set at higher level.
  • Sampling method other than stratified random sampling is used.
  • Power of the study is set at high level.

Sample size decreases if:

  • Prevalence of diseases under study is high in population.
  • Precision level is set at lower level.
  • Stratified random sampling is used.
  • Power of the study is set at low level.

choices.text: Steroid administration and biweekly Doppler studies
Fetal reduction of the smaller twin

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman at 28 weeks of gestation with a monochorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy is found to have discordant fetal growth (one fetus is 10th percentile, and the other is 50th percentile). What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Discordant growth in monochorionic twins raises suspicion for TTTS or selective intrauterine growth restriction (sIUGR). Doppler studies help assess for placental insufficiency or TTTS progression.

Discordant fetal growth in monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA) twins requires careful monitoring to differentiate between twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) and selective intrauterine growth restriction (sIUGR). The management depends on the gestational age, the severity of growth discordance, and the presence or absence of Doppler abnormalities.

  1. Weekly Doppler studies are critical in:
    • Assessing umbilical artery flow, middle cerebral artery Doppler (for brain-sparing effect), and ductus venosus waveforms.
    • Identifying whether growth restriction is due to placental insufficiency or inter-twin vascular anomalies associated with TTTS.
  2. Other options:
    • A) Immediate delivery: Not indicated unless there is fetal compromise or severe Doppler abnormalities at a viable gestational age.
    • C) Steroid administration and biweekly Doppler studies: Steroids are given if delivery is imminent (e.g., severe Doppler abnormalities or non-reassuring status). Biweekly studies are insufficient for high-risk MCDA pregnancies.
    • D) Fetal reduction of the smaller twin: Contraindicated in monochorionic twins due to shared vascular connections, which can lead to complications for the surviving twin.

Key Points:

  • TTTS is typically evaluated using the Quintero staging system, while sIUGR classification is based on Doppler abnormalities and growth discordance.
  • Early intervention with Doppler studies allows timely identification of worsening conditions requiring advanced management (e.g., laser ablation or preterm delivery).

questions.text: 50-year-old man has had headache, dizziness, and fatigue for the past 3 months. His friends have been commenting about his increasingly ruddy complexion. He also has experienced generalized and severe pruritus, particularly when showering. He notes that his stools are dark. On physical examination, he is afebrile, and his blood pressure is 165/95 mm Hg. There is no hepatosplenomegaly or lymphadenopathy. A stool sample is positive for occult blood. CBC shows hemoglobin, 22.3 g/dL; hematocrit, 67.1%; MCV, 94 μm3; platelet count, 453,000/mm3; and WBC count, 7800/mm3. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) typically presents with leukocytosis (high WBC count) and often with hepatosplenomegaly.

B) Erythroleukemia typically is not accompanied by such a high hematocrit concentration because leukemic erythroid progenitors do not differentiate into mature RBCs.

C) Essential thrombocytosis is a myeloproliferative neoplasm that primarily affects platelets, but it does not typically cause polycythemia.

D) This patient has polycythemia vera (PCV), a myeloproliferative disorder characterized by an increased RBC mass, with hematocrit concentrations typically exceeding 60%.

  • Although the increased RBC mass is responsible for most of the symptoms and signs, these patients also have thrombocytosis and granulocytosis. This occurs because, similar to other myeloproliferative disorders, PCV results from transformation of a multipotent stem cell.
  • The high hematocrit concentration causes an increase in blood volume and distention of blood vessels.
  • The neoplastic erythroid progenitor cells require extremely small amounts of erythropoietin for survival and proliferation; the levels of erythropoietin are virtually undetectable in PCV.
  • When combined with abnormal platelet function, this condition predisposes the patient to bleeding. Abnormal platelet function also can predispose to thrombosis.
  • The pruritus and peptic ulceration most likely are the result of the histamine release from basophils.
  • Positive stool sample for occult blood, which suggests gastrointestinal bleeding, possibly due to increased blood viscosity.
  • Elevated platelet count (453,000/mm3), which is also consistent with PV.

Key Takeaway:

Definition/general

  • BCR::ABL1 negative myeloproliferative neoplasm (MPN) characterized by peripheral erythrocytosis frequently accompanied by leukocytosis or thrombocytosis

Essential features

  • Relatively common MPN characterized by increased red blood cell (RBC) production with elevated red blood cell count and hemoglobin level, which is not proportional to erythropoietin (EPO) production (usually has markedly decreased EPO level)
  • JAK2V617F (exon 14, valine to phenylalanine) and JAK2 exon 12 mutations are identified in > 95% and ~5% of patients, respectively.
  • Occurs in 3 phases
    • Prodromal/prepolycythemic
    • Overt polycythemic
    • Postpolycythemic myelofibrosis/spent
  • < 20% undergo blastic transformation within 15 years

questions.text: Which atypical antipsychotic has the best evidence for efficacy in treating bipolar depression?
questions.solution:
Option A: Aripiprazole: Less effective for bipolar depression compared to other atypical antipsychotics, primarily used for mania.

Option B: Olanzapine: Effective for mania but less consistently proven for bipolar depression compared to quetiapine.

Option C: Quetiapine: Best evidence for efficacy in treating bipolar depression, with studies showing consistent improvement in depressive symptoms.

Option D: Ziprasidone: More commonly used for acute mania, with less evidence for treating bipolar depression.

  • Treatment Phases: Bipolar disorder treatment is divided into acute and maintenance phases, with strategies for mania, hypomania, and depression.
  • First-Line Medications for Acute Mania: Lithium, divalproex, atypical antipsychotics like olanzapine, risperidone, quetiapine.
  • Anticonvulsants: Valproate is commonly used for acute mania; carbamazepine and lamotrigine are alternatives.
  • Antipsychotics: Atypical antipsychotics are preferred for acute mania, with haloperidol as a second-line option.
  • Acute Bipolar Depression: Quetiapine has the best evidence; other options include lamotrigine and certain atypical antipsychotics.
  • Antidepressants: Controversial due to risks of inducing mania, not recommended as monotherapy.
  • Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT): Used for treatment-resistant bipolar depression or in emergency situations.
  • Maintenance Treatment: Focuses on preventing mood episode recurrences with lithium, carbamazepine, or valproate.
  • Side Effects: Weight gain, cognitive impairment, and sedation are common and may lead to discontinuation.
  • Treatment Failures: If first-line treatments fail, second-line options include haloperidol and carbamazepine.

questions.text: A 67 year old woman recently diagnosed with atrial fibrillation started treatment with atenolol, 100 mg/dl. With this dose, the percentage of atenolol bound to plasma proteins is about 5%. Which of the following would have been the bound percentage of atenolol if a dose of 50 mg/dl had been administered to the same patient?
questions.solution:
• Plasma protein binding is a concentration-independent (linear) process for most drugs at therapeutic levels.
  • This means that the percentage of drug bound to plasma proteins remains constant, regardless of the dose or plasma concentration - unless the binding sites become saturated, which doesn't happen here (especially with atenolol, which binds only about 5%).
  • So, whether the dose is 100 mg/dL or 50 mg/dL, 5% of atenolol will remain bound to plasma proteins.
  • Drugs bind primarily to albumin (if acidic) or to α1 acid glycoprotein (if basic).
  • The extent to which drugs are bound to protein is highly variable (e.g., 0% for lithium, 99% for warfarin).
  • Drugs ordinarily bind to protein in a reversible fashion and in dynamic equilibrium, according to the law of mass action, as shown by the equation
  • [Free drug] + [Protein] =[Drug−protein complex]
  • Mass action kinetics predicts that a constant percentage of the drug is bound; therefore, binding is independent of the dose

The clinically significant implications of plasmaprotein binding are:

  1. Plasma protein binding causes restriction of drugs in the vascular compartment and thus lower volume of distribution.
  2. Longer duration of action- as the protein-bound fraction is not available for metabolism orexcretion.
  3. Plasma protein bound drugs tend to have more drug interactions due to displacement of a drug with lower affinity by a drug with higher affinity for plasma proteins.
  4. Hypoalbuminemia can lead to high concentration of free drug and thus drug toxicity.

Clinical Importance of Plasma Protein Binding

  1. Duration of action: Drugs with high PPB are usually long acting
  2. Distribution:High PPB drugs stay in plasma, thus have low Vd.
  3. Displacement:Highly PPB drug can be displaced by another highly bound drug
  4. Dialysis:It is not effective for drugs having high PPB
  5. As proteins cannot be filtered by glomerulus, so if a drug has high binding to plasma proteins, it tends to have less glomerular filtration.

Key takeaway

  • Mass action kinetics predicts that a constant percentage of the drug is bound; therefore, binding is independent of the dose

questions.text: According to Sunderland's classification, which grade of nerve injury involves axonal damage with preserved endoneurium, allowing potential regeneration?
questions.solution:
Introduction

  • Peripheral nerve function can be compromised by various mechanisms, including:
    • Compression
    • Stretch
    • Blast
    • Crush
    • Avulsion
    • Transection
    • Tumor invasion
  • Evaluation and Treatment: The evaluation and management of traumatic peripheral nerve dysfunction are determined by the mechanism of injury and the presence of other associated injuries.
  • Prognosis:
    • The most important prognostic factorfor nerve recovery is the patient's age.
    • Good prognosis:
      • Typically seen in stretch injuriesor clean wounds, and after direct surgical repair.
    • Poor prognosis:
      • Seen in crushor blast injuries, infected or scarred wounds, and after delayed surgical repair.

In Sunderland's classification of nerve injuries:

  • Grade I: Neuropraxia, involves temporary conduction block with no structural damage.
  • Grade II: Axonotmesis, where the axons are damaged, but the endoneurium, perineurium, and epineuriumremain intact, enabling good potential for regeneration.
  • Grade III: Damage to the axons and endoneurium, with preservation of the perineurium, resulting in variable recovery.
  • Grade IV: Severe injury with damage to axons, endoneurium, and perineurium, while the epineurium is intact; recovery often requires surgical intervention.
  • Grade V: Neurotmesis, complete nerve transection with no spontaneous recovery without surgery.

Nerve injuries and neuropathies

questions.text: Amotivational syndrome is seen in which substance use disorder?
questions.solution:
Option A: Alcohol:

Alcohol use disorder is associated with a range of effects like liver damage, memory loss, and mental health issues (e.g., depression and anxiety), but amotivational syndrome, characterized by a lack of motivation and apathy, is not a primary symptom of alcohol misuse. While alcohol can cause cognitive and emotional problems, amotivational syndrome is more commonly linked to cannabis use.

Option B: Tobacco:

Tobacco use can lead to dependence, respiratory issues, and various cancers, but it does not typically cause amotivational syndrome. Tobacco is a stimulant, and its withdrawal is more related to irritability, cravings, and anxiety rather than a persistent lack of motivation or apathy.

Option C: Cannabis:

Amotivational syndrome is most commonly associated with chronic cannabis use, especially in heavy users. This syndrome is characterized by a lack of motivation, reduced interest in daily activities, and a general sense of apathy. It is debated whether cannabis directly causes this syndrome or if it is a result of long-term use and its cognitive effects, but it is most strongly linked with cannabis.

Option D: Caffeine:

Caffeine is a stimulant that can lead to dependence, and withdrawal can cause symptoms like fatigue, irritability, and headaches. However, it does not lead to amotivational syndrome. Caffeine generally enhances alertness and energy, so it is unlikely to cause the lack of motivation seen in amotivational syndrome.

questions.text: A slow-activity isozyme of which enzyme is most likely responsible for an individual to exhibit a very low tolerance to alcohol, leading to the individual rarely drinking?
questions.solution:
Alcohol consumption results in increased adverse reactions to acetaldehyde owing to a genetic defect of mitochondrial aldehyde dehydrogenase in some asian population.

An isozyme of ALDH has a dramatically increased Km (>200-fold) and a 1 0-fold reduced Vmax·

In such individuals, acetaldehyde, the toxic component of alcohol ingestion, accumulates to a large extent, leading to the individual having a very low tolerance for alcohol.

A slow-acting ADH would not lead to a low tolerance to alcohol because acetaldehyde accumulation (the toxic intermediate of alcohol metabolism) would be slowed such that the acetaldehyde produced can be safely metabolized without any side effects.

Acetate, once produced, is not toxic, so a slow-acting acetyl-CoA synthetase (which uses acetate as a substrate) would not lead to the accumulation of a toxic intermediate. MEOS is used as an alternative ethanol-oxidizing system when ethanol levels are high.

A slow-acting MEOS would reduce the production of acetaldehyde, which is the toxic intermediate of alcohol metabolism. This would not lead to a low level of tolerance to alcohol.

Acetyl-CoA carboxylase is not involved in ethanol metabolism (the acetyl-CoA formed would be used for energy). Acetyl-CoA carboxylase is needed for fatty acid synthesis, and if its activity were low, fatty acid production would be reduced, but it would have no effect on the tolerance to alcohol

questions.text: What is the appropriate age to initiate routine cervical cancer screening for women living with HIV?
questions.solution:
• The prolonged early phase of cancer in situ can be detected by the pap smear. Current policy suggests that all women should have a pap test at the age of 30 years, and then every 3 years thereafter.
  • Visual inspection-based screening tests such as visual inspection with 5% acetic acid (VIA), VIA with magnification (VIAM), and visual inspection post application of Lugol's iodine (VILI) are some of the alternative screening tests.
  • After application of freshly prepared 5% acetic acid solution. Detection of well-defined opaque acetowhite lesions close to the squamocolumnar junction, well defined circum-orificial acetowhite lesion or dense aceto-whitening of ulcero-proliferative growth on the cervix constitute a positive VIA or VIAM.
  • WHO now encourages countries to use HPV tests for cervical screening.
  • Screening should start from 30 years of age in the general population of women, with regular screening with a validated HPV test every 5-10 years, and from 25 years of age for women living with HIV. Women living with HIV also need to be screened more frequently, every 3 to 5 years.

questions.text:
A newborn male is brought to the neonatal intensive care unit with ambiguous genitalia, severe dehydration, and vomiting. Laboratory investigations reveal:
Hyponatremia (low sodium)
Hyperkalemia (high potassium)
Low cortisol and aldosterone levels
Further genetic testing identifies a loss-of-function mutation in the steroidogenic acute regulatory (StAR) protein gene
What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Option b: Lipoid CAH is caused by mutations in the StAR protein gene, which is critical for the transport of cholesterol into the mitochondria for steroidogenesis. The result is a severe deficiency of all adrenal and gonadal steroids.

This condition presents with salt-wasting (low aldosterone), glucocorticoid deficiency, and ambiguous genitalia in genetic males due to a lack of androgen.

  • Option a: While 21-hydroxylase deficiency is the most common cause of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), it is due to mutations in the CYP21A2 gene, not the StAR protein gene.

It leads to cortisol and aldosterone deficiencies with androgen excess causing virilization.

  • Option c: Addison's disease refers to acquired adrenal insufficiency, often due to autoimmune destruction of the adrenal glands. It is not a congenital disorder and does not involve mutations in the StAR protein gene.
  • Option d: This form of CAH is caused by mutations in the CYP11B1 gene, leading to reduced cortisol and aldosterone synthesis.

questions.text: A 8 year old child presents with a generalized vesicular eruption all over the body involving the trunk. His brother also had similar rash. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Varicella:

Causative agent: Varicella Zoster Virus

Morphology: Crops of papules with erythematous halo; rapidly become vesicular (dew drops on rose petal appearance), then pustular.

Eruption at different stages present. Adults usually have a more severe eruption.

Site: Centripetal distribution.

Prophylaxis: Live attenuated vaccine.

Treatment: Specific antiviral therapy (acyclovir 800mg, five times daily × 7-10 days) in adults and in immunocompromised individuals. None needed in children.

Option B- Rubella is a viral disease characterized by rash, swollen glands and fever.

  • Mucosal involvement results in the Forchheimer sign, in which pinpoint or larger petechiae are noted on the soft palate and uvula during the prodromal period of rubella.
  • Rash begins on the face that spreads to the neck, trunk and extremities. Appear as erythematous pauples about 2-3 mm in size.

Option C- Measles

Presents as fever, malaise, and loss of appetite, followed by conjunctivitis, cough, and coryza. In Prodromal phase, Koplik spots appear.

These are blue-white spots on the inside of the mouth opposite the molars. Erythematous macules ranging from 0.1-1.0cm in diameter appear on the 4th or 5th day following the start of symptoms.

This non-itchy rash begins on the face and behind the ears. Within 24-36 hours it spreads over the entire trunk and extremities (palms and soles rarely involved).

Option D- Mumps

Infection typically presents with a prodrome of headache, fever, fatigue, anorexia, malaise followed by the classic hallmark of the disease, parotitis.

Key takeaway:

Varicella:

Causative agent: Varicella Zoster Virus

Morphology: Crops of papules with erythematous halo; rapidly become vesicular (dew drops on rose petal appearance), then pustular.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl with a history of precocious puberty presents with early onset of pubic hair and rapid growth. Serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels are elevated. What is the next best step in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
In a child with precocious puberty and elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone, the most likely diagnosis is non-classical CAH. Treatment with glucocorticoids is the first-line therapy to reduce androgen excess and prevent premature puberty (OPTION B).

  • OPTION A: Brain MRI is not the first step unless a central cause of precocious puberty (such as a pituitary tumor) is suspected, which is less likely given the elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone.
  • OPTION C: Karyotyping would be necessary if there were suspicion of a disorder of sexual development (e.g., Turner syndrome or androgen insensitivity syndrome), but the clinical presentation here suggests CAH rather than a chromosomal issue.
  • OPTION D: GnRH agonist therapy is used to treat central precocious puberty caused by hypothalamic or pituitary issues (gonadotropin-dependent), but in this case, the cause is likely adrenal (gonadotropin-independent), so glucocorticoid therapy is preferred.

Thus, initiate glucocorticoid therapy to manage the underlying CAH and control androgen excess in this patient.

questions.text: In case of the blockage of the maxillary artery which of the following artery is not affected?
questions.solution:
Maxillary artery:

Superficial temporal artery is NOT a branch of the maxillary artery. It is the other terminal branch of the external carotid artery. Hence, a blockage of the maxillary artery will not affect the superficial temporal artery.

  • Maxillary artery is a largest terminal branch of the external carotid artery.
  • The maxillary artery has a wide territory of distribution.
  • It supplies:
    • Upper and lower jaws
    • Muscles of temporal and infratemporal fossae
    • Nose and paranasal sinuses
    • Palate and roof of pharynx
    • External and middle ear
    • Pharyngotympanic tube
    • Dura mater
  • Branches of the 1st part:
    • Deep auricular artery
    • Anterior tympanic artery
    • Middle meningeal artery
    • Accessory meningeal artery
    • Inferior alveolar artery
  • Branches of the 2nd part:
    • Deep temporal artery
    • Pterygoid branches
    • Masseteric artery
    • Buccal artery
  • Branches of the 3rd part:
    • Posterior superior alveolar artery
    • Infraorbital artery
    • Greater palatine artery
    • Pharyngeal artery
    • Artery of pterygoid canal
    • Sphenopalatine artery

Key takeaways:

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with polyuria, polydipsia, and a history of weight loss despite an increased appetite. On examination, she is found to be dehydrated, with dry mucous membranes and rapid breathing. Laboratory tests show a random blood glucose level of 450 mg/dL, and urine analysis shows glucose but no ketones. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Type 1 diabetes would typically present with ketosis or a more rapid onset of symptoms.
  • Option B: Type 2 diabetes mellitus can present with hyperglycemia, polyuria, and polydipsia without ketosis, especially in the absence of an acute metabolic crisis.
  • Option C: Diabetic ketoacidosis presents with ketosis and an elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis, which is absent in this case.
  • Option D: Hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state is less common in young women and more common in older individuals with type 2 diabetes, but it is a possibility.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with hyperglycemia and dehydration without ketosis.

questions.text: 30-year-old male region with chronic abdominal pain, ultrasound examination reveals presence of moderate hepatosplenomegaly on colour doppler study portal vein shows hepatofugal flow with evidence of thrombus in inferior vena cava, which of the following is likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Budd-Chiari syndrome / hepatic venous outflow obstruction (HVOO) on ultrasound shows following features:

  • Discontinuity between the main hepatic vein and the inferior vena cava
  • Reversed flow in hepatic veins
  • Intra- and extrahepatic collaterals
  • Portal vein changes e.g. hepatofugal flow
  • Low or absent flow in the inferior vena cava or balanced bidirectional flow
  • Thrombus within the inferior vena cava.

questions.text: Which of the following is most commonly associated with a basal ganglia stroke?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Hemiparesis typically occurs in corticospinal tract lesions, not specifically basal ganglia strokes.
  • Option B: Homonymous hemianopia is more typical of occipital lobe strokes.
  • Option C: Dysphagia is associated with brainstem strokes.
  • Option D: Hemiballismus, a type of involuntary movement, is commonly seen in basal ganglia strokes, particularly in the contralateral side of the body.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Basal ganglia strokes are commonly associated with movement disorders like hemiballismus.

questions.text: Which drug is preferred in AF to maintain sinus rhythm in patients without evidence of structural heart disease?
questions.solution:
OPTION A&D: The class III agents sotalol and dofetilide can be administered to patients with coronary artery disease or structural heart disease but have ~3% risk of inducing excessive QT prolongation and torsades des pointes. Dofetilide should be initiated only in a hospital with ECG monitoring, and many physicians take this approach with sotalol as well.

OPTION B: In AF patients without evidence of structural heart disease, use of flecainide, disopyramide or propafenone (class I sodium channel-blocking agents) is well tolerated but negative inotropic and proarrhythmic effects warrant avoidance in patients with coronary artery disease or heart failure.

OPTION C: Amiodarone is more effective, maintaining sinus rhythm in approximately two-thirds of patients. It can be administered to patients with heart failure and coronary artery disease.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The class III agents sotalol and dofetilide can be administered to patients with coronary artery disease or structural heart disease.

questions.text: Ideally drinking water should not contain any microorganisms known to be pathogenic. Which of the following guideline for biological value of water is correct?
A 25-year-old pregnant woman at 30 weeks gestation has a normal ultrasound scan but develops severe polyhydramnios after two weeks. What is the most likely cause of this rapid change?
questions.solution:
Polyhydramnios is the presence of excessive amniotic fluid, and it can develop rapidly in certain situations. Hydrops fetalis is one of the conditions most commonly associated with sudden onset of severe polyhydramnios, particularly when the fluid accumulation is marked. Hydrops fetalis refers to a condition in which there is abnormal fluid accumulation in fetal compartments, and it can lead to severe polyhydramnios.

  • OPTION B: Hydrops fetalis may be caused by a variety of underlying issues such as fetal anemia, heart failure, infections, or chromosomal abnormalities. The rapid onset of polyhydramnios in this case is most consistent with a condition like hydrops, which can develop quickly.
  • OPTION A: Fetal aneuploidy is more often associated with mild to moderate polyhydramnios, but it does not usually lead to the rapid change in fluid accumulation described here.
  • OPTION C: Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) is a complication in monochorionic twin pregnancies and typically causes polyhydramnios in one twin (the recipient) and oligohydramnios in the other (the donor). Since this patient is not described as having a twin pregnancy, TTTS is unlikely.
  • OPTION D: Gestational diabetes can cause mild to moderate polyhydramnios, but it is unlikely to result in a rapid and severe increase in amniotic fluid levels over a short period of time, as seen in this case.

Reference: www.uptodate.com

choices.text: Donor antibodies were directed against his granulocytes
Donor blood was contaminated with hepatitis C virus
Fluid overload led to congestive heart failure
Mislabeled specimens were processed in the Laboratory

questions.text: 25-year-old man involved in a motorcycle accident incurs a laceration to his thigh. The bleeding is stabilized enroute to the hospital, but on arrival he is noted to have orthostatic hypotension and his hematocrit is 21%. He received 2 units of PRBCs. As the first unit is nearly finished transfusing, he becomes febrile and hypotensive. Urine output ceases. The serum above the clot in a red top phlebotomy tube is pink. Which of the following complications of transfusion has most likely occurred in this man?
questions.solution:
A) Donor antibodies directed against the patient's granulocytes would cause a febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction, not a hemolytic reaction.

B) Donor blood contaminated with hepatitis C virus would not cause an immediate hemolytic reaction.

C) Fluid overload leading to congestive heart failure would not cause hemolysis or the other symptoms described.

D) The patient's symptoms, including fever, hypotension, and cessation of urine output, along with the presence of pink serum above the clot in a red top phlebotomy tube (indicating hemolysis), are consistent with a hemolytic transfusion reaction.

  • This type of reaction occurs when there is an incompatibility between the blood type of the donor and the recipient.
  • In this case, it is likely that the patient received blood that was not compatible with his own blood type, leading to a severe hemolytic reaction.
  • The most likely cause of this reaction is a laboratory error, such as mislabeling of specimens, which resulted in the patient receiving incompatible blood.

Key takeaways:

Hemolytic transfusion reactions can occur due to laboratory errors, such as mislabeling of specimens, resulting in the transfusion of incompatible blood.

questions.text: Which type of depression may respond better to antidepressants with dual action on both serotonergic and noradrenergic receptors?
questions.solution:
Option A: Atypical depression: Atypical depression is characterized by symptoms like hypersomnia, increased appetite, and mood reactivity. It often responds well to antidepressants like SSRIs or MAOIs, but not typically to those with dual serotonergic and noradrenergic action.

Option B: Melancholic depression: Melancholic depression involves severe symptoms such as anhedonia (loss of interest or pleasure) and significant functional impairment. Antidepressants that target both serotonin and norepinephrine (e.g., SNRIs) are often more effective for this type of depression.

Option C: Seasonal depression: Seasonal affective disorder (SAD) typically responds to light therapy, and while antidepressants may be used, they are not always the first-line treatment. SSRIs are more commonly used, rather than dual-action antidepressants.

Option D: Depression with psychotic features: Depression with psychotic features is usually treated with a combination of an antidepressant and an antipsychotic, rather than a dual-action antidepressant alone.

  • Antidepressant Dosage:
    • Common mistake: Low dosage, short trial time.
    • Max dose should be used for 4-5 weeks unless adverse events occur.
    • Drug plasma levels can help identify issues with noncompliance or unusual drug metabolism.
  • Initial Medication Selection:
    • Antidepressants are similar in efficacy but differ in side effects, drug interactions, and ease of dose adjustment.
    • SSRIs are most commonly prescribed.
    • Selection depends on illness chronicity, family history, and patient preferences.
  • Duration & Prophylaxis:
    • Maintain antidepressant for at least 6 months or the length of the previous depressive episode.
    • Gradually taper off medication to avoid withdrawal.
    • Prophylactic treatment is effective for preventing recurrences, especially in recurrent or severe episodes.
  • Treatment of Specific Depressive Disorders:
    • Melancholic depression may respond better to drugs with both serotonergic and noradrenergic action.
    • Light therapy is used for seasonal depression.
    • Psychotic depression requires a combination of antidepressants and antipsychotics, and ECT may be more effective than medication.
  • Comorbid Disorders:
    • Treat comorbid conditions (e.g., OCD, panic disorder) with medications that work for both conditions (e.g., SSRIs, TCAs).
    • Substance abuse must be evaluated for potential substance-induced mood disorders.
    • Medical conditions (e.g., cardiovascular disease) increase depression risk.
  • Therapeutic Use of Side Effects:
    • Sedating antidepressants like mirtazapine may help anxiety initially but may lead to long-term sedation.
    • Adjuncts like hypnotics/anxiolytics can help immediate symptoms but may cause dependence.
  • Acute Treatment Failures:
    • Treatment failure may be due to side effects, poor clinical response, or misdiagnosis.
    • Acute phase trials should last 4-6 weeks, with partial response by 4 weeks being expected.
  • Second Treatment Options:
    • Switching medications is preferred after initial treatment failure.
    • Augmentation is an option when partial benefit is achieved.
    • Evidence supports quetiapine and aripiprazole as effective augmenting agents.
  • Novel Pharmacologic Agents:
    • Ketamine: Effective for treatment-resistant depression; rapid effects, but short-lived and potential for abuse.
    • Esketamine: Nasal form of ketamine, approved for treatment-resistant depression with a restricted distribution system.
    • Brexanolone: IV treatment for postpartum depression; rapid effects with side effects like sleepiness and dry mouth. Phase 3 trials for oral form are promising.

questions.text: A 45 year old scientist working in private laboratory has developed a drug that is described as: "A drug that binds to a receptor at a site distinct from the active site and alters the affinity of the receptor for the endogenous ligand". Which of the following option is most suitable for the same?
questions.solution:
• Allosteric modulators shows high selectivity for distinct receptor subtypes These agents exert their pharmacological actions by altering the affinity or efficacy of orthosteric muscarinic ligands.
  • Positive allosteric modulators (PAMs) enhance orthosteric activity, while negative allosteric modulators (NAMs) inhibit it.
  • Allosteric agents that can directly activate muscarinic receptors are termed allosteric agonists.

A noncompetitive antagonist binds to the receptor at a site other than the agonist-binding site and renders it less effective by preventing agonist binding or preventing activation.

Noncompetitive antagonism

  • The antagonist is chemically unrelated to the agonist, binds to a different allosteric site altering the receptor in such a way that it is unable to combine with the agonist or is unable to transduce the response.
  • This is also called allosteric antagonism. Because the agonist and the antagonist are combining with different sites, there is no competitionbetween them-even high agonist concentration is unable to reverse the block completely.

Increasing concentrations of the antagonist progressively flatten the agonist DRC

Option A: Competitive antagonism

The antagonist is chemically similar to the agonist, competes with it and binds to the same site of the agonist molecules. Because the antagonist has affinity but no intrinsic activity, no response is produced and the log DRC of the agonist is shifted to the right.

Option B: Inverse agonist

These type of drugs bind to the receptor and produce opposite effect (IA is negative) e.g. b carboline is an inverse agonist at BZD receptors

Option C: Partial agonist

It activates the receptor submaximally (IA between 0 and +1). It will produce the similar effect in the absence of agonist but it will decrease the effect of a pure agonist.

Key Takeaway

Allosteric modulators shows high selectivity for distinct receptor subtypes. These agents exert their pharmacological actions by altering the affinity or efficacy of orthosteric muscarinic ligands.

questions.text: WHO safety check list consists of all the following components except?
questions.solution:
World Health Organization Surgical Safety Checklist. Tool introduced by the World Health Organization (WHO) in 2008 to improve patient safety during surgery, and implemented within the NHS in 2010. Consists of a series of questions confirming the main issues that may hinder safe operating or result in adverse outcomes, arranged in three phases:

  • Before anaesthesia ("sign in"): patient's identity, site and type of procedure and consent; presence of allergies; expected blood loss; anaesthetic equipment/drugs checked; risk of aspiration or difficult airway.
  • Before the surgical procedure ("time out"): introduction of all team members; patient's identity, site and type of procedure; ASA physical status, expected blood loss; any anticipated critical events; need for antibiotics or imaging/specialised equipment (including monitoring); sterility of instruments.
  • Before the patient leaves the operating theatre ("sign out"): correct record of procedure and labelling of specimens; correct instrument, sponge and needle counts; any equipment issues addressed; any key concerns for recovery. Supported by evidence in many hospital settings, with the biggest reductions in morbidity and mortality seen in (but not restricted to) developing countries. Has been modified according to local needs, e.g. in obstetric and other specialised units.

questions.text: Which of the following condition is not a result of deterministic effect of radiation?
questions.solution:
Deterministic effect → acute and subacute effects of radiation exposure which directly proportional to dose of radiation which have non-linear relationship with threshold dose. Examples - Acute radiation syndrome, cataract, skin changes like erythema and ulceration, sterility, radiation myelitis, fibrosis, teratogenesis.

Stochastic effect → chronic effects of radiation exposure which is unrelated to dose and have linear relationship with threshold dose. Examples - Carcinogenesis, genetic mutations, chromosome aberrations.

questions.text: Properties of Vector for DNA Cloning include all except
questions.solution:
A vector is a molecule of DNA to which the fragment of DNA to be cloned is joined.

Properties of Vector includes

  1. Capacity for autonomous replication within a host cell
  2. Presence of at least one specific nucleotide sequence recognised by restriction endonuclease
  3. Presence of at least one gene (such as an antibiotic Resistance gene) that confers the ability to select for the vector

Commonly used vectors are plasmid and viruses.

questions.text: All of the following are the sites where pleura extends beyound the thoracic cage, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Recesses of the pleura:

  • Normally the space between the parietal and visceral pleura is only a potential space and is filled with thin film of serous fluid.
  • However in areas of pleural reflection on to the diaphragm and mediastinum, the space between the parietal and visceral pleura is greatly expanded.
  • These expanded regions of pleural cavity are called pleural recesses.
  • They are essential for lung expansion during deep inspiration. Thus pleural recesses serve as reserve spaces of pleural cavity for the lungs to expand during deep inspiration.

Costodiaphragmatic recess:

  • It is located inferiorly between the costal and diaphragmatic pleurae.
  • Vertically it measures about 5 cm and lies opposite the 8thto 10th ribs along the midaxillary line.
  • The costodiaphragmatic recesses are the most dependent parts of the pleural cavities, hence the fluid of pleural effusion first collect at these sites.

Costomediastinal recess:

  • It is located anteriorly between the costal and mediastinal pleurae and lies between sternum and costal cartilages.
  • The right costomediastinal recess is possibly occupied by the anterior margin of the right lung even during quiet breathing.
  • The left costomediastinal recess is large due to the presence of cardiac notch in left lung.
  • Its location can be confirmed clinically by percussion (tapping) of the chest wall.
  • As one moves during tapping from the area of underlying lung tissue to the area of left costomediastinal recess unoccupied by lung tissue, a change in tone, from resonant to dull, is noticed.
  • This is called the area of superficial cardiac dullness.

Key points:

Sites of extension of pleura beyond the thoracic cage:

  • There are five sites, where pleura extends beyond the thoracic cage.
  • These sites are as follows:
    • On either side in the root of the neck (as domes of pleura).
    • In the right xiphisternal angle.
    • On left side in the costovertebral angle.
    • On right side in the costovertebral angle.

The pleura can be punctured inadvertently at these sites during surgical procedures.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl has eye ache, headache, difficulty in watching movie on television. She visited the ophthalmologist for the same complain. Doctor examined the patient and checked acuity of vision. Patient has difficulty in distant vision. What could be the probable cause?
questions.solution:
• The 7-year-old girl presents with eye ache, headache, difficulty in watching movies on television, and difficulty in distant vision. These symptoms are commonly associated with refractive errors, particularly myopia (nearsightedness).
  • Option c: If the lens is placed anteriorly, the focal length is reduced, causing light to focus in front of the retina.
  • This is a feature of myopia (nearsightedness), where distant vision is impaired but near vision remains intact.
  • Option a: Axial shortening of the eyeball reduces the distance between the cornea and the retina, which shifts the focal point behind the retina.
  • This is a feature of hyperopia (farsightedness), not myopia. Hyperopia leads to difficulty focusing on near objects rather than distant ones.
  • Option b: A decreased curvature of the cornea leads to reduced refractive power, causing light to focus behind the retina.
  • This is another cause of hyperopia (farsightedness).
  • Option d: A reduction in the refractive index of the lens due to changes in its composition is a feature of age-related changes, such as presbyopia or early cataracts.
  • This is unlikely in a 7-year-old child and does not typically cause difficulty in distant vision at this age.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Becker's nevus?
questions.solution:
Option A. It is a congenital melanocytic nevus.

  • Incorrect. Becker's nevus is usually acquired rather than congenital.

Option B. It typically presents as a small, flat, hyperpigmented lesion.

  • Incorrect. Becker's nevus usually appears as a larger, irregularly shaped, hyperpigmented patch, often with coarse hair.

Option C. It is often associated with underlying muscle or skeletal abnormalities.

  • Correct. Becker's nevus can be associated with abnormalities such as hypoplasia of the underlying muscle.

Option D. It commonly appears in females during adolescence.

  • Incorrect. Becker's nevus is more commonly seen in males and typically develops during puberty.

Key takeaway:

Becker's nevus is characterized by hyperpigmented skin, often with increased hair growth (hypertrichosis), and can appear anywhere on the body but is most commonly found on the upper body and arms. It is thought to be related to an increase in melanocyte activity and may also have associations with certain muscle or connective tissue abnormalities.

Becker's nevus

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with SUI undergoes a Q-tip test. A urethral hypermobility angle of more than what degree is indicative of SUI?
questions.solution:
The Q-tip test evaluates urethral hypermobility, a common feature of stress urinary incontinence (SUI). During the test, a lubricated Q-tip is inserted into the urethra and the angle of movement is measured when the patient performs activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, such as coughing or straining.

An angle greater than 45 degrees is considered diagnostic of urethral hypermobility, which indicates weakened pelvic support structures.

questions.text: Which of the following functional component is not a part of the facial nerve?
questions.solution:
• GSE fibers are typical motor fibers to somite-derived muscles (e.g., extraocular or tongue muscles).
  • These are present in oculomotor, trochlear, abducens, and hypoglossal nerves, not the facial nerve.

Facial nerve:

  • Facial nerve is the nerve of the second branchial arch.
  • It is the 7th cranial nerve.
  • Functional Components:
    • Special visceral or branchial efferent (SVE): It is responsible for muscles of facial expression and for elevation of the hyoid bone
    • General visceral efferent (GVE) or parasympathetic fibres: These fibres are secretomotor to the submandibular and sublingual salivary glands, the lacrimal gland, glands of the nose, palate and pharynx.
    • General visceral afferent (GVA): It carries afferent impulses from the above mentioned glands.
    • Special visceral afferent (SVA): It carries tastes sensations from the palate and from anterior two thirds of the tongue except from vallate papillae.
    • General somatic afferent (GSA): It innervates a part of the skin of the ear. The nerve does not give any direct branches to the ear, but some fibres may reach it through communications with the vagus nerve. Proprioceptive impulses from muscles of the face travel through branches of the trigeminal nerve to reach the mesencephalic nucleus of the nerve.
  • Nuclei: The fibres of the nerve are connected to four nuclei situated in the lower pons.
    • Motor nucleus or branchiomotor (
    • Superior salivatory nucleus or parasympathetic
    • Lacrimatory nucleus is also parasympathetic.
    • Nucleus of the tractus solitarius which is gustatory. It also receives afferent fibres from the glands.

Key Points:

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with progressive fatigue, dry mouth, and joint pain. On examination, she has parotid gland enlargement and dry oral mucosa. Laboratory tests reveal positive antinuclear antibodies (ANA) and anti-SSA (Ro) antibodies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Systemic lupus erythematosus can present with fatigue and joint pain, but parotid enlargement and dry mouth are not typical features.
  • Option B: Rheumatoid arthritis causes joint pain but does not lead to parotid enlargement or positive anti-SSA antibodies.
  • Option C: Sjögren's syndrome is characterized by dry mouth, dry eyes, parotid gland enlargement, and positive anti-SSA (Ro) antibodies.
  • Option D: Scleroderma primarily presents with skin changes, not parotid enlargement or dry mouth.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Sjogren's syndrome is characterized by dry mouth, dry eyes, and parotid gland enlargement with positive anti-SSA (Ro) antibodies.

questions.text: What is the recommended first-line therapy for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbations?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Antibiotics and systemic corticosteroids are recommended for COPD exacerbations, especially when bacterial infections are suspected.
  • Option B: Bronchodilators help with symptom relief but are not enough as first-line therapy alone in exacerbations.
  • Option C: Oxygen therapy is often used but not as the sole treatment for exacerbations.
  • Option D: Antitussives are not typically used in acute COPD exacerbations.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The management of COPD exacerbations typically involves antibiotics, corticosteroids, and bronchodilators.

questions.text: Which of the following components is NOT a part of a rate?
questions.solution:
Rate:

  • It measures the occurrence of a particular event in a population in a given time.
  • It consists of a numerator, denominator, time specification and multiplier.
  • Numerator is often part of the denominator.
  • Examples: Crude death rate, incidence rate.

Ratio:

  • It expresses a relation in size between two random quantities.
  • It consists of only numerator and denominator and no time specification.
  • The numerator is not part of the denominator.
  • Examples: sex ratio, doctor-population ratio.

Proportion:

  • It is a ratio that indicates the relation in magnitude of a part of a whole.
  • The numerator is always part of the denominator.
  • Proportions are usually expressed as percentage and it is often measured at a point in time.

choices.text: Serial ultrasounds for fetal growth and structural abnormalities
Routine follow-up with no further monitoring required

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, G3P2, presents at 24 weeks of gestation for routine follow-up. An ultrasound reveals the presence of a single umbilical artery (SUA). The rest of the ultrasound is normal with no signs of fetal abnormalities. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The presence of a single umbilical artery (SUA) is associated with an increased risk of fetal anomalies, particularly cardiovascular, renal, and chromosomal defects.

However, if the ultrasound reveals no other structural abnormalities and there is no indication of other complications, the appropriate management involves serial ultrasounds to monitor fetal growth and check for any potential structural issues or signs of fetal distress.

This is important because SUA can sometimes be associated with intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), so monitoring the growth of the fetus is key.

Other Options:

  • a) Amniocentesis for karyotyping:
    • Amniocentesis is not routinely recommended solely based on the presence of SUA unless there are additional risk factors or signs of fetal abnormalities (such as abnormal screening results, structural anomalies, or family history of genetic disorders). Since this pregnancy has no signs of abnormal findings, amniocentesis is not immediately indicated.
  • c) Routine follow-up with no further monitoring required:
    • Although SUA can sometimes be an isolated finding with no adverse outcomes, this condition warrants some level of monitoring because it can be associated with fetal growth issues or anomalies that may not be initially apparent. Therefore, no further monitoring is not recommended.
  • d) Elective cesarean section at 38 weeks:
    • There is no indication for an elective cesarean section based on the presence of SUA alone, particularly when the rest of the pregnancy appears normal. Most women with SUA can have a vaginal delivery unless there are other complicating factors such as growth restriction or fetal distress.

choices.text: The same in both specimen groups
Higher in the hypertrophy group than the recurrent infection group
