questions.text: When comparing tonsillectomy specimens for recurrent tonsillitis versus tonsillar hypertrophy, the incidence of EBV detection in pediatric patients is?
questions.solution:
While the exact cause of recurrent tonsillitis and tonsillar hypertrophy is not fully understood, there is evidence suggesting a potential link with the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).

EBV's Role:

  • Prevalence in tonsillar tissue: Studies have found EBV DNA present in the tonsillar tissues of children with tonsillar hypertrophy.
  • Potential link to chronic tonsillar disease: Some researchers suggest a possible causal relationship between the presence of viruses like EBV in tonsils and chronic tonsillar issues like hypertrophy and recurrent tonsillitis. Tge incidence of finding EBV in both cases is the same.
  • EBV's mechanism: EBV is a B-lymphotropic virus that can transform memory B-cells into blast cells, leading to permanent proliferation and potentially contributing to tonsillar enlargement.

Incorrect choice explanation:

Choice B. Higher in the hypertrophy group than the recurrent infection group

There is no consistent evidence showing a higher incidence of EBV detection in hypertrophy cases compared to recurrent infection cases. Studies suggest that EBV presence is fairly balanced between both conditions.

Choice C. Higher in the recurrent infection group than the hypertrophy group

EBV detection rates are not reported to be higher in recurrent tonsillitis than in hypertrophy. Instead, both conditions show a similar rate of EBV presence, indicating no significant difference between them.

Choice D. Absent in both groups

EBV is not absent; it is detected in both hypertrophy and recurrent tonsillitis specimens. The virus's presence is part of the ongoing research into its role in chronic tonsillar diseases.

Key Takeaways:

  • EBV DNA is commonly detected in tonsillar tissues in both recurrent tonsillitis and hypertrophy cases.
  • The incidence of EBV detection is roughly the same in both conditions.
  • EBV may contribute to the chronic pathology of the tonsils by affecting B-lymphocytes.
  • Understanding the role of EBV helps in comprehending the pathology behind tonsillar diseases

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman has noticed an enlarging mass in her left breast for the past 2 years. The physician palpates a 4-cm firm mass. Following biopsy, a simple mastectomy is performed with axillary lymph node sampling. On gross sectioning, the mass has a soft, tan, fleshy surface. Histologically, the mass is composed of large cells with vesicular nuclei and prominent nucleoli. There is a marked lymphocytic infiltrate within the tumor, and the tumor has a discrete, non infiltrative border. No axillary node metastases are present. The tumor cells are triple negative, for HER2, estrogen receptor (ER), and progesterone receptor (PR). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) Colloid carcinoma (also known as mucinous carcinoma) is characterized by the presence of abundant extracellular mucin, which is not mentioned in the description.

B) Infiltrating ductal carcinoma is the most common type of breast cancer, but it typically has a more infiltrative growth pattern and may have a more variable receptor status.

C) Infiltrating lobular carcinoma is characterized by a more diffuse, infiltrative growth pattern, and often has a positive receptor status.

D) Medullary carcinoma is a rare subtype of breast cancer that typically presents as a well-circumscribed, firm mass. The tumor cells are large and have vesicular nuclei and prominent nucleoli. A distinctive feature of medullary carcinoma is the presence of a marked lymphocytic infiltrate within the tumor.

Other characteristic features of medullary carcinoma include:

  • A discrete, non-infiltrative border
  • Triple-negative receptor status (i.e., negative for HER2, estrogen receptor, and progesterone receptor)
  • Absence of axillary node metastases

Key takeaways:

  • Medullary carcinomas account for about 1% to 5% of all breast carcinomas. They tend to occur in women at younger ages than do most other breast cancers.
  • Despite poor prognostic indicators (such as absence of HER2, ER, and PR), medullary carcinomas have a better prognosis than most other breast cancers.
  • Perhaps the infiltrating lymphocytes are a helpful immune response.

choices.text: ASD symptoms last for more than 6 months, whereas PTSD symptoms last for less than a month
ASD is diagnosed only if the traumatic event occurred less than 24 hours ago
PTSD requires symptoms to last for more than 1 month, whereas ASD lasts from 3 days to 1 month
PTSD involves dissociative symptoms, but ASD does not

questions.text: Which of the following best distinguishes Acute Stress Disorder (ASD) from Post-traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD)?
questions.solution:
Option A is incorrect: ASD lasts between 3 days to 1 month, whereas PTSD symptoms last for more than 1 month.

Option B is incorrect: There is no specific 24-hour requirement for diagnosing ASD; symptoms should last from 3 days to 1 month after trauma.

Option C is correct: PTSD is diagnosed if symptoms last for more than 1 month, whereas ASD lasts from 3 days to 1 month after the trauma.

Option D is incorrect: Both ASD and PTSD can involve dissociative symptoms (e.g., flashbacks, depersonalization).

PTSD

  • Trauma Exposure: Directly experiencing or witnessing traumatic events (e.g., death, injury, or sexual violence).
  • Intrusion Symptoms: Distressing memories, dreams, flashbacks, or psychological distress triggered by reminders of trauma.
  • Avoidance: Avoiding thoughts, feelings, or external reminders related to the trauma.
  • Negative Mood/Cognitions: Feelings of guilt, shame, detachment, and inability to experience positive emotions.
  • Altered Arousal: Symptoms like irritability, hypervigilance, sleep disturbances, and exaggerated startle response.
  • Duration: Symptoms last more than 1 month, causing significant impairment in functioning.
  • Dissociative Symptoms: Depersonalization or derealization can be present in severe cases.
  • Delayed Expression: Full criteria may not be met until 6 months after the trauma.

Acute Stress Disorder

  • Trauma Exposure: Similar to PTSD, but symptoms last from 3 days to 1 month after the traumatic event.
  • Symptoms: At least 9 symptoms from categories like intrusion, negative mood, dissociation, avoidance, and arousal.
  • Impact: Distress and impairment in daily functioning.
  • Adjustment Disorder
  • Stress Response: Emotional or behavioral symptoms triggered by an identifiable stressor within 3 months.
  • Symptoms: Distress out of proportion to the stressor or significant impairment in functioning.
  • Duration: Symptoms do not persist for more than 6 months after the stressor ends.

questions.text: A 15 year old homeless patient is found on a railway track and brought to emergency department with hot dry skin, raised temperature, dilated pupils, slurred speech and a staggering gait. Which of the following is the most likely cause for the above signs and symptoms?
questions.solution:
Belladonna poisoning

  • It occurs due to drug overdose or consumption of seeds and berries of belladonna/dhatura plant. Children are highly susceptible.

Manifestations are due to exaggerated pharmacological actions.

  • Dry mouth, difficulty in swallowing and talking.
  • Dry, flushed and hot skin (especially over face and neck), fever, difficulty in micturition, decreased bowel sounds.
  • A scarlet rash
  • Dilated pupil, photophobia, blurring of near vision, palpitation.
  • Excitement, psychotic behaviour, ataxia, delirium, dreadful visual hallucinations.
  • Hypotension, weak and rapid pulse, cardiovascular collapse with respiratory depression.
  • Convulsions and coma occur only in severe poisoning.

Diagnosis

  • Methacholine 5 mg or neostigmine 1 mg s.c. fails to induce typical muscarinic effects.

Treatment

  • If the poison has been ingested, gastric lavage should be done with tannic acid (KMnO4 is ineffective in oxidizing atropine).
  • The patient should be kept in a dark quiet room.
  • Cold sponging or ice bags are applied to reduce body temperature.

Physostigmine 1-3 mg s.c. or i.v. antagonises both central and peripheral effects, but has been found to produce hypotension and arrhythmias in some cases

Mydriasis, tachycardia, dry mouth, warm (hot) skin and delirium are classical symptoms of anticholinergic overdose.

Mnemonic

D - Dry mouth, Delirium

H - Hyperthermia

A - Agitation

T - Tachycardia

U - Urinary

R - Retention

A - Accommodation lost (Blurred vision, Photophobia)

Physostigmine is the drug of choice for treatment of atropine and belladona poisoning.

Key takeaway

  • Belladonna poisoning occurs due to drug overdose or consumption of seeds and berries of belladonna/dhatura plant. Children are highly susceptible.

choices.text: It synthesizes RNA from a DNA template.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the function of a spliceosome?
questions.solution:
Maturation of eukaryotic m RNA usually involves removal from the primary transcript of RNA sequence (Intron or Intervening sequence) that do not code for protein.

The process of removing introns and joining exons is called splicing. The molecular complex that accomplishes these tasks known as the spliceosome.

Spliceosome consists of primary transcript plus sn RNA and approximately 60 other protein.

Option A) A) It synthesizes RNA from a DNA template. This describes the process of transcription, where RNA polymerase synthesizes RNA by using DNA as a template.

Option C) It facilitates the folding of polypeptide chains into functional proteins. This refers to the role of molecular chaperones, such as heat-shock proteins (HSPs), which assist in the proper folding of proteins to ensure their functional conformation.

Option D) It synthesizes ribosomal RNA (rRNA) in the nucleolus.This describes the activity of RNA polymerase I, which transcribes rRNA genes in the nucleolus. Ribosomal RNA is a key structural and functional component of ribosomes.

choices.text: The couple is not eligible because Priya is below 25 years of age.
The couple is eligible as they meet the age and child criteria
The couple would only be eligible if they had three or more children.
The couple must obtain written consent from both spouses for sterilization

questions.text:
Rajesh and Priya, a married couple, visit a government hospital to inquire about sterilization. They are curious about their eligibility. Rajesh is 26 years old, and Priya is 21 years old. They have two children. The counsellor explains the government guidelines for sterilization, mentioning age limits and other criteria.
As the couple discusses further, Priya asks, "What if we had three children instead of two? Would the age criteria still apply?"
The counsellor smiles and says, "In that case, the lower age limit might be relaxed."
Based on the situation, what is the correct interpretation of the guidelines for sterilization?
questions.solution:
Following are the guidelines issued by government for sterilization:-

  • The age of the husband should not be less than 25 years nor more than 50 years.
  • The age of the wife should not be less than 20 years not more than 45 years.
  • The motivated couple must have 2 living children at the time of operation.
  • If the couple has 3 or more living children the lower limit of age of the husband and wife may be relaxed.
  • It is sufficient if the acceptor declares having obtained consent of his/her spouse to undergo sterilization procedure without any outside pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following part of the duodenum is commonest site for peptic ulcer?
questions.solution:
Duodenal ulcer:

  • The first part of the duodenum is one of the commonest sites for peptic ulcer, possibly because of direct exposure of this part to the acidic contents reaching it from the stomach.
  • The duodenal ulcers commonly occur in the first part of the duodenum because it is supplied by a series of end arteries.
  • The patient is usually an over busy young person with a tense temperament.
  • The ulcer pain located at the right half of epigastrium is relieved by meals and reappears on an empty stomach.
  • The first part of duodenum is overlapped by the liver and gallbladder, either of which may become adherent to or even ulcerated by a duodenal ulcer.
  • Other clinically important relations of duodenum are the right kidney and transverse colon
  • In barium meal X-ray of abdomen, the first part of the duodenum presents a triangular shadow having a well-demarcated base and less distinct apex called duodenal cap or bulb.
  • When duodenal ulcer is present in the first part, a small fleck of barium is found filling the ulcer crater and the duodenal cap is said to be deformed.

Key Points:

Duodenal ulcer:

  • The first part of the duodenum is one of the commonest sites for peptic ulcer, possibly because of direct exposure of this part to the acidic contents reaching it from the stomach.
  • The duodenal ulcers commonly occur in the first part of the duodenum because it is supplied by a series of end arteries.
  • The patient is usually an over busy young person with a tense temperament.

choices.text: Insulin secretion from pancreatic beta cells
Estrogen secretion to act on endometrium

questions.text: Endocrine gland is of various type depending on secreting gland and target organ. Among the following list which is an example of neurocrine activity?
questions.solution:
• Option b: This is an example of neurocrine activity, where a neuron synthesizes and secretes a hormone (oxytocin) into the bloodstream.
  • Oxytocin is produced in the hypothalamus, stored in the posterior pituitary, and released into the circulation to exert its effects on distant targets, such as the uterus and mammary glands.
  • Option a: Insulin is secreted into the bloodstream by pancreatic beta cells to regulate blood glucose levels in distant tissues such as muscles and the liver.
  • This is an example of endocrine activity as the hormone is transported to target organs via the bloodstream.
  • Option c: Estrogen is secreted by the ovaries and travels through the bloodstream to act on the endometrium, stimulating proliferation and preparation for potential implantation. This represents endocrine activity, as the hormone acts on distant cells.
  • Option d: Thyroid hormones are produced by the thyroid gland and travel through the bloodstream to regulate metabolic and developmental processes in distant organs, including the brain. This is another example of endocrine activity. It is not neurocrine hormone.

choices.text: Primary syphilis; intramuscular benzathine penicillin G
Secondary syphilis; intramuscular benzathine penicillin G

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man presents with a rash covering his trunk and extremities, along with several large, wart-like lesions in his groin. He also has a history of a painless ulcer on his penis that resolved spontaneously a few months ago. His laboratory tests reveal a positive Rapid Plasma Reagin (RPR) and a positive Treponema pallidum particle agglutination (TPPA) test.
What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the recommended treatment?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of a rash, wart-like lesions, and a history of a primary ulcer, combined with positive serologic tests (RPR and TPPA), is consistent with secondary syphilis.

Secondary Syphilis presents 2 to 8 weeks post-chancre disappearance.

  • Characterized by systemic manifestations and varied cutaneous lesions, including:
    • Condyloma lata: highly infectious warty lesions.(MOST INFECTIOUS LESIONS OF SECONDARY SYPHILIS)
    • Moth-eaten alopecia: patchy hair loss.
    • Mucous patches: lesions in the oral cavity.
    • Palmoplantar lesions: hyperpigmented macules or scaly papules.
    • Truncal rash: macular or papular rash commonly found on the torso.
  • Requires treatment with Benzathine penicillin G (2.4 million units, single dose).

Option A: Tertiary syphilis would be associated with late complications and requires more extensive treatment.

Option B: Primary syphilis involves a single ulcer (chancre), and the patient's presentation fits secondary syphilis.

Option D : Latent syphilis refers to the infection without symptoms, and azithromycin is not the first-line treatment; benzathine penicillin G is preferred.

Key Takeaways:

  • Secondary syphilis can present with systemic symptoms, skin rashes, and mucosal lesions.
  • Treatment: Inj Benzathine penicillin G4 million units, single dose

choices.text: It is effective only in women over 30 years of age
It prevents all types of HPV infections
It is most effective when given before the onset of sexual activity
It replaces the need for cervical cancer screening

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the role of HPV vaccination in cervical cancer prevention?
questions.solution:
HPV vaccination is most effective when administered prior to any sexual activity because it provides immunity before potential exposure to HPV. The vaccine targets the most common high-risk types of HPV that cause cervical cancer (e.g., HPV 16 and 18).

Why the other options are incorrect:

  • A) HPV vaccination is effective in both younger and older women, but its efficacy is highest when given before any exposure to the virus (i.e., before sexual activity begins). It is not limited to those over 30 years of age.
  • B) While the vaccine prevents the majority of high-risk HPV types (specifically types 16, 18, 6, and 11), it does not prevent all types of HPV infections.
  • D) HPV vaccination does not replace cervical cancer screening. Even vaccinated women should continue regular screening, as the vaccine does not protect against all HPV types and does not eliminate the need for Pap smears or HPV testing.

Reference: National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) Guidelines for cervical cancer

questions.text: Which of the following nerve is suppling to marked area in the diagram?
questions.solution:
• Marked area is lateral part of the forearm.
  • It is supplied by the lateral cutaneous nerve of forearm.
  • It is a continuation of the musculocutaneous nerve.

Cutaneous branches

  • Musculocutaneous nerve:

  • Median nerve:

    • Digital branches:

    • Dorsal branches:

    • Dorsal branches:

Cutaneous innervation of the upperlimb:

Key Points:

Musculocutaneous nerve:

  • The musculocutaneous nerve is the main nerve of the front of the arm.
  • It is a branch of the lateral cord of the brachial plexus.
  • Root value: Ventral rami of C5, C6, C7 segments of spinal cord.
  • Branches of musculocutaneous nerve:
    • Muscular branches:
      • Coracobrachialis

choices.text: Hyperthyroidism due to toxic multinodular goiter

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a history of weight loss, fatigue, and palpitations. On examination, her thyroid is diffusely enlarged, and she has a fine tremor in her hands. Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is undetectable, and free thyroxine (T4) is elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Graves' disease is the most likely diagnosis, as it presents with hyperthyroidism, diffuse thyroid enlargement, and elevated free T4 with suppressed TSH.
  • Option B: Toxic multinodular goiter typically presents with variable thyroid function tests and multiple palpable thyroid nodules, which are not described here.
  • Option C: Thyroid carcinoma would present with a hard, non-tender thyroid nodule and typically no hyperthyroidism.
  • Option D: Subclinical hyperthyroidism typically has normal symptoms and mildly suppressed TSH.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Graves' disease presents with diffuse thyroid enlargement, hyperthyroidism, and elevated T4 with suppressed TSH.

questions.text: Which of the following is a common complication of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Pulmonary embolism is a common and life-threatening complication of DVT when a clot dislodges and travels to the lungs.
  • Option B: Stroke is not a common complication of DVT, although it can occur in certain conditions like atrial fibrillation.
  • Option C: Myocardial infarction is unrelated to DVT but rather related to coronary artery disease.
  • Option D: Acute kidney injury is not typically associated with DVT but may occur with certain complications like sepsis or contrast-induced nephropathy.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Pulmonary embolism is a major complication of deep vein thrombosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman at 37 weeks of gestation is referred for ECV due to a breech fetus. She has a history of myomectomy for fibroids, and the ultrasound shows an anterior myometrial scar. What is the best course of action?
questions.solution:
Contraindications for ECV:

  • A history of myomectomy with a myometrial scar, particularly on the anterior uterine wall, significantly increases the risk of uterine rupture during procedures that increase uterine pressure, such as ECV or labor.
  • In such cases, scheduled cesarean delivery is the safest approach for both the mother and the fetus.

Why Not ECV?

  • Even under close monitoring, ECV poses risks in women with uterine scars, including rupture or placental abruption, and is contraindicated.

Why Scheduled Cesarean Delivery?

  • Elective cesarean at 39 weeks minimizes the risks of spontaneous labor, which can be dangerous in a scarred uterus.
  • It ensures optimal fetal maturity while reducing complications.

Why Not Other Options?

  • A) Proceed with ECV after obtaining informed consent:
    ECV is contraindicated due to the uterine scar and associated risk of rupture.
  • B) Offer a trial of vaginal breech delivery:
    Vaginal breech delivery is contraindicated in women with a uterine scar, given the potential for rupture during labor.
  • D) Schedule ECV with inpatient monitoring:
    Close monitoring does not mitigate the inherent risks of ECV in this context.

choices.text: Atrophy of pancreatic acini with normal islet morphology
Increase in the number of islets of Langerhans
Fibrosis and atrophy of islets of Langerhans with amyloid deposition

questions.text: Which of the following morphological alterations is commonly observed in the pancreas of individuals with long-standing diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
A) Atrophy of pancreatic acini with normal islet morphology is incorrect because while acinar atrophy can occur in diabetes, there are also significant changes in the islets, including amyloid deposition and fibrosis, rather than just normal morphology.

B) Increase in the number of islets of Langerhans.

  • Diabetes, especially type 2, is typically associated with islet dysfunction rather than an increase in the number of islets.
  • There may be hyperplasia early in the disease as a compensatory response to insulin resistance, but this is not typically observed in long-standing diabetes.

C) Long-standing diabetes mellitus, especially in type 2 diabetes, is associated with degeneration of the islets of Langerhans.

  • This can lead to atrophy of the islets, with an accumulation of amyloid deposits within the islets. These amyloid deposits disrupt normal islet function and are a hallmark of diabetic pancreas pathology, especially in type 2 diabetes.
  • Fibrosis in the pancreatic tissue is also common, as the chronic high glucose levels and metabolic changes can lead to collagen deposition in the stroma.

D) Hyperplasia of ductal epithelium is not a characteristic finding in diabetes mellitus. Ductal epithelium may show some changes due to chronic inflammation or other factors, but ductal hyperplasia is not a hallmark of diabetic pancreatic pathology.

Key takeaways:

Here are some pancreatic alterations that can occur in diabetes patients:

Type 1 Diabetes

  1. Insulitis: Inflammation of the islets of Langerhans, leading to the destruction of beta cells.
  2. Beta-cell destruction: Autoimmune destruction of beta cells, leading to a decrease in insulin production.
  3. Islet cell atrophy: Atrophy of the islets of Langerhans, leading to a decrease in insulin production.

Type 2 Diabetes

  1. Amyloid deposition: Deposition of amyloid fibrils in the islets of Langerhans, leading to the destruction of beta cells.
  2. Beta-cell dysfunction: Dysfunction of beta cells, leading to a decrease in insulin production and secretion.
  3. Islet cell hypertrophy: Hypertrophy of the islets of Langerhans, leading to an increase in insulin production.
  4. Pancreatic fibrosis: Fibrosis of the pancreas, leading to a decrease in pancreatic function.

Common Alterations

  1. Pancreatic atrophy: Atrophy of the pancreas, leading to a decrease in pancreatic function.
  2. Islet cell exhaustion: Exhaustion of the islets of Langerhans, leading to a decrease in insulin production.
  3. Ductal proliferation: Proliferation of the pancreatic ducts, leading to an increase in pancreatic juice production.

choices.text: A sense of lack of control over eating during binge episodes
Recurrent inappropriate compensatory behaviors (e.g., vomiting, misuse of laxatives)
Disturbance in body shape and weight perception

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is unique to Bulimia Nervosa compared to Anorexia Nervosa?
questions.solution:
Option A: Both disorders involve a fear of weight gain, but it’s a defining characteristic of Anorexia Nervosa.

Option B: Both disorders have a sense of loss of control during eating episodes, but this behavior is tied more to Bulimia Nervosa, where the eating episodes are followed by compensatory actions.

Option C: In Bulimia Nervosa, compensatory behaviors like vomiting or using laxatives are key diagnostic criteria.

Option D: This is common to both Anorexia Nervosa and Bulimia Nervosa.

Anorexia Nervosa (AN):

  • Criterion A: Significant weight loss due to restriction of energy intake, resulting in body weight significantly below normal for age, sex, and health.
  • Criterion B: Intense fear of weight gain or persistent behavior to prevent weight gain, even at low body weight.
  • Criterion C: Distorted body image or lack of recognition of the seriousness of low weight.
  • Subtypes:
    • Restricting type: Weight loss through dieting, fasting, or exercise.
    • Binge-eating/purging type: Involves binge eating or purging behaviors (vomiting, misuse of laxatives).

Bulimia Nervosa (BN):

  • Criterion A: Recurrent binge eating (large amounts of food with lack of control).
  • Criterion B: Inappropriate compensatory behaviors (vomiting, laxatives, excessive exercise).
  • Criterion C: Occurs at least once a week for 3 months.
  • Criterion D: Self-evaluation unduly influenced by body shape and weight.

Binge-Eating Disorder (BED):

  • Criterion A: Recurrent binge eating (large quantities of food with lack of control).
  • Criterion B: Three or more of the following:
    1. Eating rapidly.
    2. Eating until uncomfortably full.
    3. Eating large amounts when not hungry.
    4. Eating alone due to embarrassment.
    5. Feeling disgusted, depressed, or guilty afterward.
  • Criterion C: Distress about binge eating.

Night Eating Syndrome (NES):

  • Criterion: Recurrent episodes of eating after waking from sleep or after the evening meal, with awareness and recall.
  • Distress/impairment: Eating at night causes distress or functional impairment.
  • Not explained by: Other mental disorders, binge-eating disorder, or medical conditions.

questions.solution: All of the above causes can cause an increased CO2 in the Capnogram. It is important to identify life threatening complication like malignant hyperthermia and treat.

choices.text: To promote cell growth and division
To remove damaged or unnecessary cells
To increase the number of cells in tissues
To enhance inflammation in response to injury

questions.text: What is the primary function of apoptosis in multicellular organisms?
questions.solution:
A) To promote cell growth and division

While cell growth and division are essential processes in development and tissue maintenance, they are not functions of apoptosis.

  • Apoptosis is a programmed cell death mechanism that ensures cells that are damaged, aged, or no longer needed are eliminated.

B) To remove damaged or unnecessary cells

Apoptosis is a controlled process that eliminates cells that are no longer needed or are potentially harmful to the organism (such as cells with DNA damage). This process is crucial for maintaining tissue homeostasis and preventing diseases such as cancer.

C) To increase the number of cells in tissues

Apoptosis does not increase the number of cells; in fact, it leads to a decrease in cell number. The balance between cell proliferation (growth) and apoptosis is critical for maintaining healthy tissues.

D) To enhance inflammation in response to injury

While inflammation is an important response to injury, apoptosis itself is not a mechanism that enhances inflammation.

  • Instead, apoptosis can help resolve inflammation by removing immune cells after their job is done, thus preventing excessive inflammation and tissue damage.

Key Takeaways:

  • Apoptosis is a vital process for maintaining cellular health by removing damaged or unnecessary cells.
  • It plays a crucial role in development, tissue homeostasis, and preventing diseases such as cancer.
  • Understanding apoptosis helps in comprehending various biological processes, including how the body responds to injury and maintains balance in cell populations.

questions.text: 32-year-old women came with the history of amenorrhea from last 2 months. On investigating she was found pregnant. On taking history, you got to know that she is an elderly primigravida, you explained her that her pregnancy is high risk pregnancy. Which of the following are criteria of high-risk pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• The central purpose of antenatal care is to identify 'high risk' cases. These cases comprise the following: -
    • Elderly primi (30 years and over)
    • Short statured primi (140cm and below).
    • Malpresentations, viz breech, transverse lie, etc.
    • Antepartum haemorrhage, threatened abortion.
    • Pre-eclampsia, and eclampsia.
    • Anaemia
    • Twins, hydramnios.
    • Previous still-birth, intrauterine death, manual removal of placenta.
    • Elderly grandmultiparas.
    • Prolonged pregnancy.
    • History of previous caesarean or instrumental delivery.
    • Pregnancy associated with general diseases, viz cardiovascular disease, kidney disease, diabetes, tuberculosis, liver disease, malaria, convulsions, asthma, HIV, RTI, STI etc.
    • Treatment for infertility.
    • Three or more spontaneous consecutive abortions.

choices.text: Perineal branch of fourth sacral nerve

questions.text: 60 years old male patient was undergone I&D of the abscess in the ischiorectal fossa. All of the following nerves can be injured during surgery, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Dorsal nerve of the penis

  • Course: Travels anteriorly, deep to the perineal membrane, to reach the penis dorsum
  • Runs away from the ischiorectal fossa
  • NOT involved in that area during surgery

Ischiorectal fossa (Ischioanal fossa):

  • The ischiorectal fossa is a wedge shaped fat-filled space
  • It is situated on each side of the anal canal below the pelvic diaphragm.
  • The two fossae communicate with each other behind the anal canal.
  • They help in dilatation of the anal canal during defecation.
  • The base of the fossa lies on the skin over the anal region of the perineum.
  • The apex is directed upward and laterally.
  • Each fossa measures about 5 cm in length, 5 cm in width, and 5 cm or slightly more in depth.
  • Boundaries
    • Lateral: Fascia covering the obturator internus muscle and ischial tuberosity.
    • Medial: Fascia covering the levator ani muscle and external anal sphincter.
    • Posterior: Sacrotuberous ligament, on the posterior surface of which is gluteus maximus.
    • Anterior: Posterior border of the perineal membrane.
    • Floor: Perineal skin.
    • Roof: Meeting point of the fascia covering obturator internus and inferior fascia of the pelvic diaphragm.
  • Contents:
    • Ischiorectal pad of fat.
    • Inferior rectal nerves and vessels (running from lateral to medial side).
    • Perineal branch of fourth sacral nerve.
    • Posterior scrotal (or labial) nerves and vessels.

Key Points:

Ischiorectal abscess:

  • The ischiorectal fossa is prone for infection due to its location.
  • The infection may occur from boils and abrasions of the perianal skin, from lesions within the anal canal, from pelvic infection or rarely via blood.
  • It often forms the ischiorectal abscess.
  • The infection may readily pass from one fossa to the other through horseshoe shaped recess behind the anal canal forming horseshoe shaped abscess.
  • Since ischiorectal fossa does not contain any important structure, it can be incised fearlessly to drain the abscess.
  • Sometimes following nerves can be injured during I&D.
    • Inferior rectal nerves
    • Perineal branch of fourth sacral nerve
    • Posterior scrotal (or labial) nerves

Acyl Carrier Protein contains Vitamin B5

questions.text: All are true for Fatty Acid Synthase multienzyme complex except
questions.solution:
The Fatty acid Synthase complex is a homodimer of Two Polypeptide Chains containing Six Enzyme activities and the Acyl Carrier Protein. X Ray Crystallography had identified the complex as homodimer, with two identical subunits each containing six enzymes and ACP arranged in an X Shape.

The use of one Multienzyme functional unit has the advantage of achieving compartmentalization of the process within the cell without the necessity for permeability barriers and synthesis of all enzyme in the complex is coordinated since it is encoded by a single gene.


The individual enzymes required for fatty acid synthesis are linked in this multienzyme polypeptide complex that incorporates the acyl carrier protein (ACP), which has a similar function to that of CoA in the β-oxidation pathway . It contains the vitamin pantothenic acid in the form of 4′-phosphopantetheine

choices.text: Saddle joint - Carpometacarpal joint of the thumb

questions.text: Which of the following is not a correct match between the type of joint and its example?
questions.solution:
Atlanto-Occipital Joint

  • The atlanto-occipital joint is a condyloid (ellipsoid) joint, enabling nodding and limited side-to-side motion.
  • Key anatomical features:
    • The atlas (C1) lacks a vertebral body and spinous process.
    • It has two concave superior facets that articulate with the occipital condyles.
    • Approximately 50% of total neck flexion and extension occurs at the occiput-C1 articulation.

Atlanto-Axial Joint

  • The atlanto-axial joint is a pivot (diarthrodial) joint, allowing rotational movement (e.g., shaking the head "no").
  • Key anatomical features:
    • The base of the dens narrows due to the transverse ligament.
    • Approximately 50% of total neck rotation occurs at the C1-C2 articulation.
  • Clinical relevance:
    • Pannus formation in rheumatoid arthritis can affect this articulation, leading to instability.

Other Types of Joints

  • Ball-and-socket joint (e.g., shoulder, hip): Allows multi-axial movement.
  • Hinge joint (e.g., elbow, knee): Allows movement in one plane.
  • Saddle joint (e.g., thumb): Allows biaxial movement.

General orthopaedics and basic sciences

choices.text: Aggressive hydration and monitoring renal function

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with cervical cancer is undergoing chemotherapy with cisplatin. After several cycles, her renal function worsens, with elevated serum creatinine and oliguria. Which of the following strategies should be employed to manage cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity?
questions.solution:
Cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity is a common and well-documented side effect, and management primarily involves aggressive hydration to prevent or minimize kidney damage. Hydration helps to increase renal perfusion, promoting the excretion of cisplatin and reducing its nephrotoxic effects. Monitoring renal function (serum creatinine, urine output) is essential to assess the severity of nephrotoxicity.

  • Mannitol infusion (A) is sometimes used as an osmotic diuretic to promote urine output in cases of renal injury, but it is not the first line in managing cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity. Hydration remains the cornerstone of prevention and treatment.
  • Corticosteroids (B) are not commonly used for managing cisplatin nephrotoxicity and may have limited benefits.
  • Discontinuing cisplatin (C) is generally considered in severe cases, but initial management typically includes supportive measures such as hydration and renal function monitoring.

choices.text: Left umbilical vein and two umbilical arteries
Right umbilical vein and two umbilical arteries
Left umbilical artery and two umbilical veins
Right umbilical artery and two umbilical veins

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the contents of the umbilical cord?
questions.solution:
Umbilical Cord:

  • The umbilical cord is a long cord-like structure by which fetus is attached to the uterine wall via placenta.
  • It connects umbilicus of a fetus to the center of fetal surface of the placenta.
  • It is covered by glistening amniotic membrane.
  • At full-term, one end of this cord is attached to the center of anterior abdominal wall of fetus (umbilical region) and the other end is attached to the center of fetal surface of the placenta.
  • The cord is twisted and presents false knots.
  • The umbilical cord has natural twists because the umbilical vein is longer than the umbilical arteries.
  • Measurements (at full term):
    • Length: 50-55 cm (about 2 ft)
    • Breadth: 1-2 cm
  • Development:
    • The umbilical cord develops from connecting stalk (the part of extraembryonic mesoderm in which the extraembryonic celom does not develop).
    • The umbilical vessels develop in the connecting stalk and the primary mesoderm of connecting stalk undergoes mucoid generation to form a gelatinous substance called Wharton's jelly. The Wharton's jelly protects the umbilical vessels.
    • As the amniotic cavity enlarges it obliterates the extraembryonic celom and forms a tubular sleeve around the umbilical cord.
  • Contents of umbilical cord:
    • Two umbilical arteries
    • One umbilical vein (left umbilical vein)
    • Wharton's jelly
    • Remains of allantoic diverticulum
    • Remains of vitellointestinal duct (remnant of yolk sac).
  • Functions:
    • The umbilical arteries arising from ventral divisions of internal iliac arteries carry deoxygenated blood from fetus to the placenta.
    • After oxygenation in the placenta, the umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus.
  • Cord prolapse:
    • The umbilical cord due its long length is likely to prolapse through the uterus during parturition (child birth) leading to a clinical condition called cord prolapse.
    • The cord is likely to be compressed between fetal head and pelvic wall of mother. This may lead to hypoxia to the fetus.
    • In about one-fifth of all deliveries, the cord may encircle the neck of the fetus and may cause strangulation.

questions.text: What is the hallmark feature of primary hyperparathyroidism on biochemical evaluation?
questions.solution:
OPTION A - Serum calcium is elevated in primary hyperparathyroidism.

OPTION B - High serum calcium is the hallmark feature.

OPTION C - Serum phosphate is typically low due to increased renal excretion.

OPTION D - Alkaline phosphatase may be elevated due to increased bone turnover.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

  • Primary hyperparathyroidism is caused by parathyroid adenomas, hyperplasia, or carcinoma.
  • It is the most common cause of hypercalcemia in the outpatient setting.

questions.text: 72-year-old male patient present in neurology OPD with complaint of recurrent backward falls and progressive weakness with imbalance, accompanying relative complain of sluggish movement while doing routine work, MRI brain of patient was done and image is given below: Which of the following sign is depicted in given MRI images?
questions.solution:
Hummingbird sign - Case of progressive supranuclear palsy.

MRI findings in progressive supranuclear palsy - Parkinson plus syndrome:

Midbrain atrophy:

  • Increased MRI parkinsonism index.
  • Reduced midbrain to pons ratio
  • Hummingbird sign - flattening of superior aspect of mid brain which usually shows normal convex profile.
  • Mickey mouse sign - reduction in antero-posterior and midline diameter of midbrain in axial images.
  • Morning glory sign - loss of normal lateral convex margin of the tegmentum of midbrain.

Ice cream cone sign - seen in acoustic neuroma/vestibular schwannoma.

Empty delta sign - seen in cerebral venous sinus thrombosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of hemophilia A?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Hemophilia A is characterized by a prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), not PT.
  • Option B: Platelet count is usually normal in hemophilia A.
  • Option C: The INR is typically normal in hemophilia A unless there is liver disease.
  • Option D: Hemophilia A is due to a deficiency of factor VIII, leading to abnormal clotting and bleeding.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Hemophilia A is characterized by decreased factor VIII activity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male complains of constant and severe muscular cramps, profuse diarrhea, and suppressed urine output. He has no fever, and his surface temperature is subnormal. What is the most likely cause?

choices.text: Monitoring serum sodium and fluid balance
Use of a nasogastric tube for gastric decompression

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman undergoing hysteroscopic surgery with glycine experiences breathlessness after the procedure. The surgical team is concerned about the possible absorption of glycine. What is the best method for monitoring this patient postoperatively?
questions.solution:
• The most effective way to monitor for complications related to glycine absorption is to closely monitor serum sodium levels and fluid balance (OPTION B). This helps detect hyponatremia and fluid overload.
  • OPTION A: Abdominal x-rays are not necessary for monitoring glycine absorption.
  • OPTION C: Diuretics are not typically administered immediately unless fluid overload is severe.
  • OPTION D: A nasogastric tube is unnecessary in this case. A nasogastric tube would be indicated if there were concerns about gastric distention or a bowel obstruction, which is not the primary concern here. The primary issue is fluid absorption, so electrolyte monitoring is more critical.

questions.text: Which of the following medications has shown effectiveness in treating explosive behavior in patients with Intermittent Explosive Disorder?
questions.solution:
Option A: Antipsychotics:

Antipsychotic medications have been used in some cases to manage aggressive behavior, but they are not the first-line treatment for Intermittent Explosive Disorder (IED). Their use is more common in other disorders, like schizophrenia or mood disorders.

Option B: Benzodiazepines:

While benzodiazepines might be used to manage anxiety or agitation, they are generally avoided in IED because they can cause disinhibition, potentially worsening the impulsive and aggressive behaviors associated with the disorder.

Option C: Lithium:

Lithium has been reported as effective in reducing aggressive behavior in patients with IED. It is a mood stabilizer that helps regulate emotions, reducing the intensity of explosive outbursts.

Option D: Tricyclic antidepressants:

Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) are sometimes used for mood-related disorders but have not been consistently proven effective in managing the aggression or impulsivity seen in IED. They are less commonly used compared to other options like lithium or SSRIs.

Intermittent Explosive Disorder

  • Combined Treatment: Pharmacologic and psychotherapeutic approaches work best.
  • Psychotherapy: Challenging due to anger outbursts; group therapy and family therapy may help.
  • Medications:
    • Lithium and anticonvulsants (e.g., carbamazepine, valproate) may reduce aggression.
    • SSRIs, buspirone can reduce impulsivity and aggression.
    • Benzodiazepines avoided due to disinhibition risk.
  • Surgical Treatment: Limited evidence for effectiveness.

Kleptomania

  • Therapy: Insight-oriented psychotherapy, cognitive-behavioral therapy, and behavior therapies (e.g., aversive conditioning) may help.
  • Medications: SSRIs (e.g., fluoxetine), naltrexone, and others like lithium and topiramate have been used with varying success.

Pyromania

  • Treatment: Behavioral therapy, especially CBT, shows promise.
  • Supervision: Ongoing supervision necessary due to recurrence risk.
  • Medications: SSRIs, lithium, and other drugs have been used, but efficacy is uncertain. Family therapy is key for children and adolescents.

choices.text: They are more potent than other antimuscarinic drugs.
They have an oral bioavailability higher than that of other antimuscarinic drugs.
They have negligible effects on bronchial secretions and mucociliary clearance.

questions.text: A 54 year old man, recently diagnosed with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, started a therapy with ipratropium bromide using a metered-dose inhaler. Which of the following statements best explains why drugs from the ipratropium class are the only antimuscarinic drugs used to treat bronchospastic disorders?
questions.solution:
• Bronchial asthma, asthmatic bronchitis, COPD
  • Reflex vagal activity is an important factor in causing bronchoconstriction and increased secretion in chronic bronchitis and COPD, but to a lesser extent in bronchial asthma.
  • Orally administered atropinic drugs are bronchodilators, but less effective than adrenergic drugs; not clinically used.
  • They dry up secretion in the respiratory tract, may lead to its inspissations and plugging of bronchioles resulting in alveolar collapse and predisposition to infection.
  • The mucociliary clearance is also impaired. Inhaled ipratropium bromide has been found specially effective in asthmatic bronchitis and COPD, though less so in bronchial asthma.
  • Given by aerosol, it neither decreases respiratory secretions nor impairs mucociliary clearance, and there are few systemic side effects.
  • In the past, antimuscarinic drugs were used to treat bronchospastic disorder.
  • However, it was realized that most antimuscarinic drugs reduce the volume of bronchial secretions, which then become thick.
  • This viscous material is difficult to remove from the respiratory tree and can dangerously obstruct airflow.
  • Moreover, the reduced bronchial secretions in turn decrease mucociliary clearance, an important function for the cleaning of the bronchial tree.
  • Therefore, these drugs (except ipratropium and tiotropium) have become contraindicated in respiratory disorders.
  • Ipratropium bromide 40-80 μg by inhalation; it acts selectively on bronchial muscle without altering volume or consistency of respiratory secretions.
  • Another desirable feature is that in contrast to atropine, it does not depress Mucociliary clearance by bronchial epithelium.
  • Thus, it is more suitable for regular prophylactic use rather than for rapid symptomatic relief during an attack.
  • The parasympathetic tone is the major reversible factor in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Therefore, ipratropium is more effective in COPD than in bronchial asthma.

Option A: Potency, or the inverse of the dose needed to get a predetermined effect, is almost never the reason for the choice of a specific drug.

Option B: These drugs are given only by the inhalatory route, so oral bioavailability is not an issue. Moreover, the oral bioavailability is very low, as these drugs are quaternary ammonium compounds and therefore cannot cross lipid membranes.

Option C: By definition, bioavailability is the fraction of drug reaching the general circulation. When given by inhalatory route, the fraction of ipratropium reaching the general circulation is negligible.

  • Key takeaway
  • Ipratropium has negligible effects on bronchial secretions and mucociliary clearance. Thus, its anticholinergic properties can be safely exploited in the treatment of bronchospastic disease especially COPD.
