choices.text: They promote healing of lung tissue.

questions.text: What role do neutrophils play in the pathogenesis of acute lung injury?
questions.solution:
A) They promote healing of lung tissue: Neutrophils are primarily involved in the inflammatory response rather than healing.

B) They release pro-inflammatory mediators: This is Neutrophils release cytokines and other mediators that contribute to inflammation and tissue damage in ALI.

C) They decrease vascular permeability: Neutrophils actually increase permeability through their inflammatory actions.

D) They enhance surfactant production: Neutrophils do not play a direct role in surfactant production.

Key Takeaway:

Neutrophils are key players in the inflammatory response during ALI, releasing mediators that exacerbate lung injury.

choices.text: Dietary fat should be limited approximately 10-15% of total daily intake.
Saturated fats should contribute no more than 10% of the total energy intake.
Protein should account for approximately 20-30% of the daily intake.
Salt intake should be reduced to an average of not more than 10g. per day.

questions.text: All countries develop a national nutrition and food policy setting out "dietary goals". The dietary goals recommended by the WHO includes which of the following goal?
questions.solution:
• The dietary goals (prudent diet) recommended by the various expert committees of WHO are as below:
  • Dietary fat should be limited to approximately 15 to 30 percent of total daily intake.
  • Saturated fats should contribute no more than 10% of the total energy intake, unsaturated vegetable oils should be substituted for the remaining fat requirement.
  • Excessive consumption of refined carbohydrates should be avoided, some amount of carbohydrate rich in natural fibre should be taken.
  • Sources rich in energy such as fats and alcohol should be restricted.
  • Salt intake should be reduced to an average of not more than 5g. per day.
  • Protein should account for approximately ten to fifteen percent of the daily intake.
  • Junk foods such as colas, Ketchups and other foods that supply empty calories should be reduced.

choices.text: Conversion of atrial flutter to normal sinus rhythm
Prolongation of the atrial refractory period, leading to flutter termination
Increase in atrial rate due to enhanced automaticity
Decrease in ventricular rate by slowing AV nodal conduction

questions.text: A 59-year-old male with a history of hypertension presents to the emergency department with complaints of palpitations, dizziness, and mild shortness of breath for the past 2 days. On examination, his pulse is 120 bpm and irregular, and his blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. On ECG his atrial rate is 290 beats per minute and ventricular rate is 120/min. Diagnosis is atrial flutter. Which among the following is effect of digoxin on atrial flutter?
questions.solution:
• Option d: Digoxin increases vagal activity, which decreases conduction velocity through the AV node. The number of impulses transmitted through AV node are reduced. This reduces the ventricular rate without affecting the atrial flutter mechanism.
  • Option a: Digoxin is not effective for rhythm conversion in atrial flutter. Rhythm conversion typically requires electrical cardioversion, antiarrhythmic drugs, or ablation.
  • Option b: While digoxin may have some effects on atrial refractory periods. It is not as significant to alleviate the atrial flutter.
  • Option c: Digoxin does not increase atrial rate. Instead, it primarily acts on the AV node to control ventricular rate by enhancing vagal tone.

For information: Digoxin is also used in treatment of systolic heart failure, atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: Phosphofructokinase 1 is inhibited by all except
questions.solution:
Phosphofructokinase 1 (PFK-1) is a crucial enzyme in the regulation of glycolysis. It controls the conversion of fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate, which is a key regulatory step in the glycolytic pathway. PFK-1 activity is tightly regulated by various metabolites and hormones to ensure that energy production is balanced with the cell's needs.

Option A) ATP is a major product of glycolysis and an indicator of the cell's energy status. When ATP levels are high, there is less need for energy production, so ATP inhibits PFK-1 to prevent further breakdown of glucose.

Option B) Glucagon is a hormone released during low blood sugar levels. It signals the liver to produce glucose via gluconeogenesis and inhibits glycolysis.

Glucagon indirectly inhibits PFK-1 by decreasing the levels of fructose-2,6-bisphosphate, which is an activator of PFK-1. Thus, glucagon has an indirect inhibitory effect on PFK-1.

Option C) Citrate is an intermediate of the citric acid cycle (Krebs cycle). When cellular energy levels are high (indicating abundant ATP), citrate accumulates and inhibits PFK-1, signaling to decrease rate of glycolysis.

Option D) Aspartate is an amino acid that does not directly regulate PFK-1 activity. In contrast to ATP, citrate, and glucagon, aspartate does not inhibit PFK-1.

choices.text: Primary bone healing occurs with the formation of a callus, while secondary healing involves direct contact between bone fragments without callus formation.
Secondary healing is characterized by the formation of a bone callus, whereas primary healing occurs with direct contact of the bone ends and no callus formation.
Primary healing involves significant soft tissue involvement, while secondary healing occurs without soft tissue involvement.
Both primary and secondary healing require the formation of a bone callus for the healing process to complete.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about primary and secondary healing of bone fractures?
questions.solution:
Primary and Secondary Healing of Bone Fractures

Primary Healing

  • Occurs when bone ends are in direct contact.
  • Typically achieved with rigid fixation, such as surgical plates or screws.
  • No callus formation is observed.
  • Requires precise alignment of the fracture site.
  • Healing is slower compared to secondary healing.

Secondary Healing

  • Involves the formation of a callus.
  • Happens when there is some movement at the fracture site.
  • The process begins with a soft callus that gradually hardens into bone.
  • Commonly occurs when fractures are not rigidly fixed.
  • Generally takes more time to complete compared to primary healing.

questions.text: A patient with a Bartholin's abscess has undergone incision and drainage, but the abscess reoccurs several months later. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Marsupialization is the next step in management for a recurrent Bartholin's abscess after incision and drainage. This procedure involves creating a permanent opening in the cyst or abscess to prevent reaccumulation of fluid, thus reducing the likelihood of recurrence. It is considered the definitive treatment for recurrent Bartholin's gland abscesses or cysts.

Repeat incision and drainage (B) is not ideal for recurrent abscesses, as it only provides temporary relief without addressing the underlying issue (i.e., the blocked duct or cyst formation). Marsupialization is preferred in these cases to provide a long-term solution.

Systemic antibiotics (C) are typically used if there is evidence of infection, but they will not address the underlying cause of the recurrence. Antibiotics alone will not prevent the cyst or abscess from reforming, so they are not a definitive treatment for recurrent cases.

Topical corticosteroids (D) are not indicated for the treatment of Bartholin's abscess. While corticosteroids can be useful in certain inflammatory conditions, they are not effective in managing cystic or abscess-related problems in the Bartholin's gland.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH)?
questions.solution:
OPTION A - Trauma causes intracranial hemorrhage more frequently than non-traumatic SAH. Idiopathic SAHs are localized to the perimesencephalic cisterns and are benign; they probably have a venous or capillary source, and angiography is unrevealing.
OPTION B - Berry aneurysm rupture is the leading cause of non-traumatic SAH.
OPTION C - Arteriovenous malformations are a less common cause of SAH.
OPTION D - Hypertensive bleeds are more commonly associated with intracerebral hemorrhage.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

  • Risk factors for aneurysm rupture include hypertension, smoking, and family history.
  • The classic presentation of SAH is a "thunderclap headache."

questions.text: Coronal T1 image of head - orbit region given below - Identify structure B?
questions.solution:
A - temporalis muscle,

B- Optic nerve,

C - maxillary sinus,

D - falx - interhemispheric cleft,

E - Medial rectus

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, bubo (enlarged lymph node), and signs of septicemia. He recalls handling a dead rodent a few days earlier. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Plague, caused by Yersinia pestis, is transmitted through fleas on rodents or handling infected animals. Bubonic plague presents with fever and painful lymphadenopathy (bubo). Prevention involves rodent control and flea management.

3 types of plague:

  1. Bubonic plague: It presents as an inflamed lymph node (bubo) which may turn into open ulcer. it is the most common type
  2. Septicemic plague: It happens without formation of Bubo
  3. Pneumonic plague: It is usually extension of bubonic plague. it is a least common type.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding for the last 6 months. She is menopausal for 1 year but has had irregular bleeding since. A transvaginal ultrasound shows an endometrial thickness of 12 mm. What is the next step in the management?
questions.solution:
Postmenopausal bleeding with an endometrial thickness greater than 4-5 mm requires endometrial sampling to rule out malignancy or hyperplasia. An endometrial biopsy is the most appropriate next step in this patient to evaluate the cause of abnormal bleeding.

Option-wise Explanation:

A) Hormonal therapy:

  • Hormonal therapy, such as progestins, may be used for endometrial hyperplasia without atypia.
  • However, in a postmenopausal woman with an ET of 12 mm, histopathological evaluation is mandatory before initiating any treatment.

B) Endometrial biopsy (Correct):

  • This is the first-line diagnostic step for evaluating PMB with increased ET.
  • It allows direct assessment for hyperplasia or malignancy.

C) D&C (Dilation and Curettage):

  • Used if the biopsy is non-diagnostic or if sufficient tissue cannot be obtained.
  • D&C is not the initial step but may be considered later if required.

D) Hysterectomy:

  • Reserved for confirmed cases of endometrial carcinoma or persistent abnormal bleeding refractory to conservative treatments.
  • It is not indicated at the diagnostic stage.

Reference: FOGSI GCPR on AUB

choices.text: Acute pain and swelling with fever
Chronic hip pain with limp and limited range of motion
Sudden onset of severe hip joint dislocation
Pain and stiffness in the knee joint

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common presentation of tuberculosis of the hip?
questions.solution:
Tuberculosis (TB) of the hip typically presents with chronic hip pain, often accompanied by a limp and limited range of motion. This is due to the gradual onset of infection in the joint, leading to joint destruction, soft tissue involvement, and progressive stiffness.

Clinical Features of Tuberculosis of the Hip

Presenting Complaints:

  • The disease has an insidious onset and follows a chronic course.
  • The child may appear apathetic and pale, with a loss of appetite before specific symptoms related to the hip are noticed.
  • One of the first symptoms is stiffness of the hip, leading to a limp.
    • Initially, stiffness may occur only after rest but may later become persistent.
  • Pain may be absent in the early stages. If pain is present, it is often referred to the knee.
  • The child may experience "night cries", also known as "starting pain", which is caused by the rubbing of two diseased surfaces during movement, typically when muscle relaxation occurs during sleep.
  • As the disease progresses, cold abscesses may develop around the hip, which can eventually burst, leading to discharging sinuses.

A) Acute pain and swelling with fever are less typical in TB hip, which usually develops insidiously over time rather than as an acute event.

C) Sudden onset of severe hip joint dislocation is not a common feature of TB hip, as the infection leads to gradual damage, not acute mechanical failure.

D) Pain and stiffness in the knee joint are not typical of TB hip, as the infection specifically affects the hip joint.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man undergoes a lumbar puncture at the L3-L4 interspace. The physician experiences two distinct "pops" during needle advancement. If the needle is inadvertently advanced beyond the second "pop" at an incorrect angle or with excessive force, which of the following structures is most likely to be encountered next?
questions.solution:
The lumbar puncture proceeds through the following posterior-to-anterior sequence:

Skin → Superficial fascia → Supraspinous ligament → Interspinous ligament → Ligamentum flavum (first

pop) → Dura mater (second pop) → Arachnoid mater → Subarachnoid space (lumbar cistern) → Cauda equina (nerve roots) surrounded by CSF and covered by pia mater

  • First pop = Ligamentum flavum punctured
  • Second pop = Dura mater + Arachnoid mater punctured (They’re closely adherent)

After the second pop, the needle tip enters the lumbar cistern, where the cauda equina floats in CSF. These nerve roots are covered by pia mater. If the needle is advanced further—especially if not perfectly midline or angled—it may encounter a nerve root, contacting its pia covering.

  • Spinal cord (option c) is unlikely to be hit in properly performed lumbar punctures done below L1-L2.
  • Ligamentum flavum (a) and Dura mater (b) have already been crossed at this point.
  • Anterior longitudinal ligament (not listed here) would never be encountered unless the needle drills through the entire vertebral body.

Key Concept:

Advancing beyond the second "pop" = entering subarachnoid space, and at lumbar levels, you're in the lumbar cistern housing cauda equina nerve roots, each ensheathed in pia mater.

choices.text: HIV resistance to the current regimen

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a CD4 count of 180 cells/μL and a viral load of 50,000 copies/mL. He has been on antiretroviral therapy (ART) for 2 years. His last CD4 count was 400 cells/μL. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his current immunological decline?
questions.solution:
• (A) Poor adherence to antiretroviral therapy: Non-adherence to ART is a common cause of viral rebound and CD4 decline in HIV patients. It leads to inadequate viral suppression and allows for immune system deterioration.
  • (B) HIV resistance to the current regimen: Resistance could be a possibility but usually takes more time to develop and requires specific resistance testing to confirm. It is unlikely without evidence of ongoing viral replication.
  • (C) Acute retroviral syndrome: Typically presents shortly after infection, not after 2 years of treatment. It is characterized by a brief flu-like illness, not the immunological decline observed in this patient.
  • (D) Secondary opportunistic infection: This would not be expected without a significantly lower CD4 count (usually below 200 cells/µL). Opportunistic infections tend to present with lower CD4 counts.

Key Takeaway:

  • Poor adherence to ART is the most common cause of immunological failure in HIV patients on therapy.
  • Key point: Regular monitoring of CD4 count and viral load is essential for managing ART efficacy.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is NOT used for opioid detoxification?
questions.solution:
Option A: Buprenorphine: Buprenorphine is used for opioid detoxification and maintenance therapy.

Option B: Methadone: Methadone is also used for detoxification and maintenance therapy in opioid use disorder.

Option C: Naloxone: Naloxone is used to reverse opioid overdose, not for detoxification.

Option D: Clonidine: Clonidine is used to manage withdrawal symptoms during detoxification.

Methadone:

  • Gold standard for treating opioid use disorder with physical dependence.
  • Used for detoxification and as a maintenance agent.
  • Dose typically starts at 20-30 mg, adjusted as needed, with a tapering schedule after stabilization.

Buprenorphine:

  • Partial opioid agonist that activates the receptor partially.
  • High affinity for receptors; may cause precipitated withdrawal if used with other opioids.
  • Used for detoxification and maintenance therapy; available as monotherapy or in combination with naloxone to prevent misuse.
  • Typically administered under medical supervision to avoid withdrawal.

Opioid Antagonists (Naloxone, Naltrexone):

  • Block opioid receptors without activation.
  • Naloxone: Used for overdose reversal; short-acting, may require repeated doses.
  • Naltrexone: Long-acting, used post-detoxification to prevent relapse by blocking opioid effects.

Overdose Treatment:

  • Prioritize airway management and mechanical ventilation.
  • Naloxone is given intravenously to reverse overdose; dose may be repeated if no improvement is seen.
  • Naloxone may need repeated doses due to its shorter duration compared to opioids.

Methadone and Buprenorphine in Detoxification:

  • Methadone: Initial dose is 20-30 mg, increased if needed, followed by gradual tapering. Used in inpatient and outpatient settings.
  • Buprenorphine: First dose given when withdrawal symptoms are moderate, then titrated. Used for both detoxification and maintenance.

Nonopioid Medications for Withdrawal:

  • Clonidine for autonomic symptoms (e.g., sweating, restlessness).
  • Benzodiazepines for anxiety/agitation (inpatient).
  • NSAIDs for musculoskeletal pain, loperamide for diarrhea.

Opioid Substitution Therapy:

  • Methadone and buprenorphine reduce heroin use and related risks, allowing stable life.
  • Major drawback: ongoing opioid dependence.

Buprenorphine/Naloxone Combination:

  • Buprenorphine is a partial agonist with a ceiling effect, reducing overdose risk.
  • Naloxone reduces misuse risk by precipitating withdrawal if abused.

Opioid Antagonists:

  • Block opioid effects without causing dependence (e.g., Naloxone, Naltrexone).
  • Naltrexone is used post-detoxification to prevent relapse but has no mechanism to ensure continuous use.

questions.text: A 45 year old person was taking an antihypertensive drug and continued taking it despite developing constipation, dry mouth and dizziness. He was taking it regularly but forgot to take it during a trip abroad and has now developed a hypertensive emergency. Which antihypertensive was he likely taking?
questions.solution:
• This drug is an alpha-2 agonist which decreases norepinephrine release. In the periphery, this causes a fall in adrenergic tone which lowers blood pressure.
  • Excessive sleepiness is a common complaint of patients taking this drug.
  • Abrupt discontinuation of clonidine therapy can lead to rebound hypertension (treated by phentolamine); therefore this drug is not suitable for people having travelling job like business executives who are likely to miss the doses.
  • Alarming rise in BP, in excess of pretreatment level, with tachycardia, restlessness, anxiety, sweating, headache, nausea and vomiting occur in some patients when doses of clonidine are missed for 1-2 days.
  • The syndrome is very similar to that seen in pheochromocytoma: plasma catecholamine (CA) concentration is increased.

This is due to:

(a) Sudden removal of central sympathetic inhibition resulting in release of large quantities of stored CAs.

(b) Supersensitivity of peripheral adrenergic structures to CAs that develops due to chronic reduction of sympathetic tone during clonidine therapy.

Adverse effects of clonidine

  • Sedation, mental depression, disturbed sleep; dryness of mouth, nose and eyes, constipation
  • Impotence, salt and water retention, bradycardia.
  • Postural hypotension
  • On sudden withdrawal -- > Alarming rise in BP, in excess of pretreatment level, with tachycardia, restlessness, anxiety, sweating, headache, nausea and vomiting

Option A, C & D: None of the other given drugs are associated with rebound hypertension on discountinuation

Key takeaway

  • Abrupt discontinuation of clonidine therapy can lead to rebound hypertension, therefore this drug is not suitable for people having travelling job like business executives who are likely to miss the doses.
  • Alarming rise in BP, in excess of pretreatment level, with tachycardia, restlessness, anxiety, sweating, headache, nausea and vomiting occur in some patients when doses of clonidine are missed for 1-2 days.

questions.text: 55-year-old man presents for a routine colonoscopy. A 1.5 cm polyp is found in the sigmoid colon and is described as having a soft, velvety appearance. Histological examination reveals small pedunculated polyps composed of rounded/tubular glands. What is the most likely type of adenoma found in this patient?
questions.solution:
A. Tubular adenoma: This is the most common type of adenoma found in the colon, often described as having a smooth surface. The description of the polyp in this case fits this type.

B. Tubulo-villous adenoma: This type has both tubular and villous components and tends to have a higher risk of malignancy than purely tubular adenomas.

C. Villous adenoma: Typically larger and has a higher risk of cancer. This polyp’s description does not fit this type.

D. Serrated adenoma: Characterized by a serrated architecture. The histological findings do not suggest this type.

Key Takeaway:

Tubular adenomas are common and have low malignant potential compared to other types.

Recognizing the morphology of adenomas is essential for appropriate management.

choices.text: It is a thickened band of tissue in the radial collateral ligament.
It is located between the volar aspect of the distal radius and the ulna.
It results from a failure of ossification in the ulnar head.
It contributes to abnormal tension in the extensor tendons of the wrist.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Vicker's ligament in Madelung deformity?
questions.solution:
Madelung deformity is a condition characterized by:

  • Disruption of the volar ulnar physis of the distal radius.
  • Deformity of the distal radius and dorsal dislocation of the ulna.
  • Excessive radial inclination and volar tilt of the distal radius, with a spectrum of abnormalities as the child grows.

Vicker's ligament is the implicated tethering structure in this condition. It:

  • Connects the volar aspect of the distal radius to the lunate bone (radio-lunate ligament).
  • Restricts normal growth and contributes to the deformity.

Pathogenesis and Genetics:

  • Hypothesized to result from Léri-Weill dyschondrosteosis, an X-linked dominant disorder caused by a mutation in the SHOX (short-stature homeobox-containing)

Clinical Presentation:

  • Often asymptomatic and discovered incidentally during adulthood, typically after minor wrist injuries that prompt radiographic examination.
  • Symptoms may include:
    • Ulnocarpal impaction.
    • Restricted forearm rotation.
    • Median nerve compression.

Management:

  • Early release of Vicker's ligament is recommended to prevent progression of the deformity.
  • Corrective osteotomy of the radius, with or without distal ulna resection, may be required for symptomatic cases.

questions.text: A previously healthy 2-year-old girl is seen in the office for evaluation of bloody discharge from her left ear. It was difficult to visualize the left tympanic membrane because of the impacted wax. An ear curette was used to remove the cerumen and subsequently a normal left tympanic membrane was seen. After the visit, her mother noted blood coming from the left ear. The girl's vital signs are normal. Her physical examination findings are normal except for crusted blood in her left ear canal obscuring the tympanic membrane. Of the following the next best step is?
questions.solution:
• The child in the vignette should be given supportive care.
  • Irrigation could further irritate the ear canal and exacerbate the bleeding. (Option B)
  • Antibiotic ear drops are not needed at this time because an infection has not been identified. (Option C)
  • Referral to an otolaryngologist is also unnecessary because she has a simple superficial irritation that will resolve. (option D)
  • Bloody otorrhea that results from superficial irritation of the ear canal requires only reassurance and supportive care.
  • Counseling patients on appropriate ear hygiene can prevent ear canal irritation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the definitive diagnostic test for multiple sclerosis?
questions.solution:
OPTION A - CT scan is not sensitive for detecting multiple sclerosis lesions.

OPTION B - MRI with gadolinium is the gold standard for diagnosing multiple sclerosis as it identifies active demyelinating plaques.

OPTION C - Evoked potentials are supportive but not definitive.

OPTION D - CSF analysis (oligoclonal bands) is useful but not diagnostic alone.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

  • Multiple sclerosis is characterized by dissemination of lesions in space and time.
  • MRI findings include hyperintense T2 lesions and contrast-enhancing plaques.

questions.text: Vestibular evoked myogenic potential (VEMP) in sternocliedomastoid muscle detects lesion in which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Vestibular evoked myogenic potential (VEMP) is a neurophysiological test that measures muscle activity in response to sound or vibration to assess the function of the inner ear’s otolithic organs through Inferior vestibular nerve.

A repetitive sound stimulus is applied to one ear, and the muscle activity in response is averaged.

VEMPs are measured from the neck using surface electrodes over sternocleidomastoid muscle (cervical VEMP, or cVEMP) or under the eyes (ocular VEMP, or oVEMP).

VEMPs can help diagnose conditions like vestibular neuritis, Meniere’s disease, and multiple sclerosis. They can also help identify which side of the body may be causing imbalance or dizziness.

During the test, you’ll recline at an angle and have sticker electrodes attached to your head and neck. You’ll hear a knocking sound as you lift your head slightly.

choices.text: Hysteroscopy to evaluate the uterine cavity

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman has been trying to conceive for 1 year without success. A hysterosalpingogram (HSG) shows a normal uterine cavity, but laparoscopy reveals no significant findings. What is the most appropriate next step in her infertility management?
questions.solution:
When the HSG is normal but other investigations, like laparoscopy, show no issues, performing a hysteroscopy is useful to further assess the uterine cavity. It helps identify issues such as fibroids, polyps, or congenital uterine anomalies that may not be visible on HSG.

Option-wise Explanation:

A) Hysteroscopy to evaluate the uterine cavity (Correct):

  • Why? It is the gold standard for assessing intrauterine abnormalities and provides both diagnostic and therapeutic benefits.
  • This is the next logical step when less invasive investigations, such as HSG and laparoscopy, have not revealed significant issues.

B) In-vitro fertilization (IVF):

  • IVF is indicated in cases of advanced maternal age, severe male factor infertility, or tubal block, none of which apply here.
  • This patient should undergo further diagnostic evaluation, like hysteroscopy, before considering IVF.

C) Ovarian drilling:

  • Ovarian drilling is a treatment for anovulatory infertility in women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) who are resistant to medical ovulation induction.
  • This patient does not have features of PCOS or anovulation.

D) Laparoscopic adhesiolysis:

  • Adhesiolysis is indicated for significant pelvic adhesions found during laparoscopy.
  • In this case, laparoscopy showed no significant findings, making adhesiolysis unnecessary.

Reference: ASRM Practice Guidelines on Uterine Evaluation in Infertility, 2023.

questions.text: Which of the following trematodes causes intestinal infection and is transmitted through the ingestion of metacercaria larvae from aquatic plants?
questions.solution:
• Fasciolopsis buski infects the intestine and is transmitted by ingestion of metacercaria larvae from aquatic plants.
  • The eggs are operculated.

Key Points:

  • Fasciolopsis buski → Intestine → Aquatic plants → Ingestion of metacercaria larvae
  • Operculated eggs

Reference: Fascioliasis (Clinical Infectious Diseases, 2020)

questions.text: A 53 year old man continued to have a low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol level of 270 mg/dL after a 6-month trial of diet therapy. His triglyceride levels were in the normal range. The patient had been suffering from type II diabetes mellitus for 2 years and peptic ulcer for 4 months. Current therapy included glyburide and metformin for diabetes and omeprazole for peptic ulcer. Which of the following drugs would be most appropriate to treat this patient's hyperlipidemia?
questions.solution:
• Currently, statins represent the most effective and best tolerated agents for treating dyslipidemia.
  • They are effective in all types of dyslipidemia, and when given as a single agent, they may decrease low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol up to 55% and total cholesterol up to 35%.
  • Therefore, they are the drugs of rst choice for treatment of elevated LDL cholesterol. Higher doses can also reduce triglyceride levels up to 35%.

Statins

  • HMG CoA reductase catalyses the rate limiting step in cholesterol biosynthesis (conversion of HMG CoA to mevalonate).
  • Statins act by inhibiting this enzyme competitively and result in decreased cholesterol synthesis in the liver.
  • As liver requires cholesterol for synthesis of bile acids and steroid hormones, it responds by increasing the uptake of LDL from the plasma.
  • This is done by increasing LDL receptors on its surface. Statins are most powerful LDL lowering agents.
  • These drugs also lower TG, IDL and VLDL and increases HDL slightly.

Option A: Niacin should be avoided because of diabetes and peptic ulcer.

Option B: Cholestyramine is relatively contraindicated because it could impair the absorption of the other currently used drugs.

Option D: Fibrates such as gem brozil are the drugs of choice for treating type III hyperlipidemia (familial dysbetalipoproteinemia), as well as high triglyceride levels. They do not signicantly decrease LDL.

Key takeaway

  • Statins represent the most effective and best tolerated agents for treating dyslipidemia. They are effective in all types of dyslipidemia, and when given as a single agent, they may decrease low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol up to 55% and total cholesterol up to 35%.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a family history of colorectal cancer undergoes genetic testing, which reveals a mutation in the MLH1 gene. Which of the following extracolonic cancers is she at increased risk of developing?
questions.solution:
A) Breast cancer: While there is some evidence to suggest that individuals with HNPCC may be at increased risk of developing breast cancer, this association is not as strong as it is for other extracolonic cancers.

B) Ovarian cancer: Individuals with HNPCC are at increased risk of developing ovarian cancer, particularly those with mutations in the MLH1 or MSH2 genes.

C) Endometrial cancer: Individuals with HNPCC are at increased risk of developing endometrial cancer, particularly those with mutations in the MLH1 or MSH2 genes.

D) All of the above: Individuals with HNPCC are at increased risk of developing a variety of extracolonic cancers, including breast, ovarian, and endometrial cancer.

Key Takeaways

  1. Individuals with HNPCC are at increased risk of developing a variety of extracolonic cancers.
  2. Individuals with HNPCC are at increased risk of developing ovarian and endometrial cancer.
  3. Genetic testing can help identify individuals with HNPCC, allowing for early detection and prevention of colorectal and extracolonic cancers.

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient went to visit primary physician due to back pain. He was referred to neurophysician for treatment. Doctor found compression of a sensory tract that leads to loss vibration and pressure in the lower limb. Which among the following tract is affected in this patient?(
questions.solution:
• Vibration and pressure sense are carried by fasciculus gracillis and fasciculus cuneatus.
  • Loss of vibration and pressure = dorsal column involvement (not spinothalamic)
  • In the lower limb = fasciculus gracilis (not cuneatus)
  • Back pain + sensory loss = likely spinal cord compression
  • Option c: The fasciculus gracilis is part of the dorsal column-medial lemniscal pathway and specifically transmits fine touch, vibration, and proprioception from the lower limbs and lower trunk. Compression of this tract can lead to sensory deficits in the lower limbs, consistent with the clinical presentation.
  • Option a: The fasciculus cuneatus is part of the dorsal column-medial lemniscal pathway, responsible for transmitting fine touch, vibration, and proprioception from the upper limbs and upper trunk. It is not involved in sensory input from the lower limbs
  • Option b: The anterior spinothalamic tract carries sensory information related to crude touch, tickle, sexual sense and itch from all parts of the body.
  • Option d: The lateral spinothalamic tract carries pain and temperature sensations from all parts of the body. It odes not carry vibration and pressure sense.

questions.text: A 28 year old male patient had complain of Severe Muscle weakness after mild - moderate exercise which will improve on resting. His blood Lactate level is very low after exercise. No sign of Hepatomegaly. Blood Glycogen level is high. Probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
As per given case scenario, sever muscle weakness and low blood lactate level, High Blood Glycogen is suggestive of Glycogen Storage Disease. Specifically, No hepatomegaly and low lactate after exercise is suggestive of Glycogen Storage Disease Type IV (Type V and not IV)also known as Mcardle Disease.

Enzyme defective in this condition is muscle phosphorylase. The PYGM gene mutation is responsible.

Option A) Glycogen Storage Disease Type 1 (Von Gierke Disease):Caused by a deficiency in glucose-6-phosphatase, primarily affecting the liver.Features include severe hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and lactic acidosis, which are absent in this case.

Option B) Glycogen Storage Disease Type 2 (Pompe Disease):Caused by a deficiency in acid maltase (lysosomal α-1,4-glucosidase).It affects multiple organs, including the heart (cardiomyopathy), and does not present with exercise-induced muscle weakness or low lactate levels.

Option C) Glycogen Storage Disease Type 4 (Andersen Disease):Caused by a defect in the branching enzyme, leading to abnormal glycogen structure. Presents with hepatosplenomegaly, progressive liver disease, and cirrhosis, none of which are seen in this patient.

choices.text: Developmental dysplasia of the hip; hip spica cast
Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE); in situ pinning

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with a limp and pain in his left hip that worsens with activity. The pain radiates to the knee, and the patient has difficulty walking. On examination, there is limited internal rotation and abduction of the left hip, with the leg held in external rotation. His weight is in the 95th percentile for his age, and he has a history of rapid growth over the past year. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the recommended initial treatment?
questions.solution:
The patient’s clinical presentation (limp, hip pain radiating to the knee, limited hip motion, and external rotation) and radiographic findings (slipped femoral epiphysis) are characteristic of Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis (SCFE).

SLIPPED CAPITAL FEMORAL EPIPHYSIS (SCFE) is a condition in which the upper femoral epiphysis becomes displaced at the growth plate, typically in a postero-medial direction, resulting in coxa vara. The slip usually occurs gradually, but in some cases, it happens suddenly.

  • Aetiology: The exact cause is not well understood but is thought to be related to trauma in the presence of an underlying abnormality. It is more common in:
    • Obese and sexually underdeveloped children, or
    • Tall, thin children who are sexually normal.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Age: Typically occurs at puberty (12-14 years).
    • Sex: More common in boys.
    • Side: Bilateral involvement occurs in 30% of cases.
    • Symptoms:
      • Pain in the groin, often radiating to the thigh and knee.
      • Limp and reduced hip mobility (limited abduction and internal rotation, with increased external rotation and adduction).
    • Examination findings:
      • External rotation and 1-2 cm shortening of the leg.
      • Trendelenburg’s sign may be positive.
      • When the hip is flexed, the knee moves towards the ipsilateral axilla.
      • Muscle bulk may be reduced.
  • Treatment:
    The initial treatment for SCFE is in situ pinning to stabilize the epiphysis and prevent further slippage. Early diagnosis and management are crucial to prevent complications such as osteoarthritis or avascular necrosis.

choices.text: Erythematous edematous and eroded gingival and buccal mucosa
Bilateral barely palpable painless subcutaneous nodules adjacent to olecranon process
Dermatomal linear streaks or plaques of upper or lower extremities
Hypertrophic, erythematous pinkish lesions overlying dorsal interphalangeal joints

questions.text: A 12-year-old female with a history of fever, weight loss, and arthralgia is noted on physical examination to have proximal muscle weakness. Laboratory findings include elevated levels of serum creatinine kinase, an elevated antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer, and a negative anti-double stranded DNA. Which of the following is most likely to be identified during physical examination of this patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient has clinical and laboratory manifestations of juvenile dermatomyositis. Hypertrophic, erythematous, pinkish lesions overlying the dorsal interphalangeal joints are known as Gottron papules and are considered a pathognomonic sign of the disorder.
  • Additional clinical manifestations may include:
    • Edematous, erythematous, bluish eyelids (heliotrope rash of the periorbital area)
    • Periorbital, cheek, and knee variegated telangiectasia
    • Periungual telangiectasia and cuticular hypertrophy
    • Dry, scaling scalp
    • Cutaneous calcinosis
  • Patients with juvenile dermatomyositis have proximal muscle weakness and may thus complain of difficulty brushing their teeth, combing their hair, climbing stairs, or standing from a sitting position.
  • Inflammatory changes may also affect the muscles of the gastrointestinal tract (causing constipation), the upper airway (causing dysphonia and dysphagia), and the heart (causing arrhythmias or cardiomyopathy).
  • Elevation of one or more muscle enzymes occurs in nearly every patient.
  • Patients usually have a normal erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and negative rumatoid factor (RF); up to 60% of patients with juvenile dermatomyositis have elevated ANA titers, whereas more specific tests for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), such as anti-double-stranded DNA, are negative.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with symptoms of severe anxiety, palpitations, sweating, and shakiness, which he attributes to a stressful situation at work.His blood reports shows elevated Glucose, Lactate level. Identify the correct statement.
questions.solution:
Glucagon and Epinephrine, hormones that are responsive to a decrease in blood glucose, inhibit glycolysis and stimulate gluconeogenesis in the liver by increasing concentration of c AMP.

This in turn activates c AMP dependent protein kinase, leading to the phosphorylation and inactivation of pyruvate kinase.

cAMP activates protein kinase A (PKA), which phosphorylates and activates enzymes involved in gluconeogenesis (e.g., fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase), while inhibiting glycolysis-promoting enzymes (e.g., phosphofructokinase-2).

Option B) Activation of protein kinase A (PKA) promotes gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis, not glycolysis. Glycolysis is suppressed during epinephrine release to conserve glucose for critical functions.

Option C)Acetyl-CoA activates pyruvate carboxylase, not phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (PEPCK), which is the enzyme in gluconeogenesis converting oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate.

Acetyl-CoA ensures that pyruvate is directed toward gluconeogenesis instead of the TCA cycle.

Option D) Protein kinases and protein phosphatases have opposite mechanisms of action:Kinases add phosphate groups (phosphorylation). Phosphatases remove phosphate groups (dephosphorylation).

questions.text: What is the typical treatment regimen for Trichuris trichiura infection?

questions.text: A 52 year old woman was discharged from the hospital after recovery from an acute Myocardial infarction. Her post discharge medications included captopril. Which of the following act ions most likely contributes to mortality reduction obtained by the use of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors in MI?
questions.solution:
• ACE inhibitors block the vasoconstricting activity of angiotensin II, thus reducing both preload and afterload, which in turn reduces the workload of the heart.
  • In addition, they reduce the growth effects of angiotensin II on cardiac myocytes and at tenuate the cardiac fibrosis induced by angiotensin II.
  • These actions lead to reduction of myocardial remodeling.
  • The initial remodeling phase after a myocardial infarction (repair of the necrotic area and myocardial scarring) may be considered beneficial, but over time remodeling causes an increase of ventricular mass and volume that adversely affects cardiac function.
  • By reducing cardiac remodeling, ACE inhibitors improve ejection fraction and decrease mortality.
  • ACE Inhibitors/Angiotensin Receptor Blockers
  • These drugs are indicated in all grade of Congestive heart failure unless contra-indicated. These can decrease mortality in CHF.
  • These decrease the mortality via prevention and reversal of cardiac remodeling due to aldosterone (final mediator of remodeling).
  • ACE inhibitors cause both arteriolar and venodilatation in Congestive heart failure patients; reduce afterload as well as preload on heart and improve all haemodynamic parameters.
  • ACE inhibitors reduce episodes of decompensation, myocardial infarction and sudden death.
  • Long term benefits of ACE inhibitors accrue from withdrawal of Angiotensin II mediated ventricular hypertrophy, remodeling, accelerated myocyte apoptosis and fibrosis.
  • Indirect benefits occur due to reduction in sympathetic activation and aldosterone levels. Also causes natriuresis
  • These drugs decrease mortality in Congestive heart failure
    • Beta Blockers
    • ACE inhibitors
    • Angiotensin Receptor Blockers
    • Aldosterone Antagonists

Option A: ACE inhibitors do not appreciably affect cardiac contractility.

Option B: By blocking aldosterone formation, ACE inhibitors decrease, not increase, preload.

Option C: By decreasing the workload of the heart , ACE inhibitors actually can indirectly cause coronary vasoconstriction.

  • Key takeaway:
  • ACE inhibitors block the vasoconstricting activity of angiotensin II, thus reducing both preload and afterload, which in turn reduces the workload of the heart. In addition, they reduce the growth effects of angiotensin II on cardiac myocytes and at tenuate the cardiac fibrosis induced by angiotensin II. These actions lead to reduction of myocardial remodelling

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman undergoes liver resection for a suspected liver tumor. Histological examination reveals a tumor composed of hepatocytes with marked steatosis and a characteristic "map-like" pattern of fibrosis. Which of the following liver tumors is most likely to exhibit this histological pattern?
questions.solution:
A) Hepatocellular adenoma: Hepatocellular adenoma is a benign liver tumor that typically exhibits a homogeneous pattern of hepatocytes without significant fibrosis.

B) Focal nodular hyperplasia: Focal nodular hyperplasia is a benign liver tumor that typically exhibits a characteristic "map-like" pattern of fibrosis and marked steatosis.

C) Hepatocellular carcinoma: Hepatocellular carcinoma is a malignant liver tumor that typically exhibits a trabecular or pseudoglandular pattern of growth without significant fibrosis.

D) Inflammatory hepatocellular adenoma: Inflammatory hepatocellular adenoma is a subtype of hepatocellular adenoma that typically exhibits a mixed inflammatory infiltrate and a homogeneous pattern of hepatocytes without significant fibrosis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Focal nodular hyperplasia is a benign liver tumor that typically occurs in young women.
  • Majority are solitary and have a central scar on imaging and gross examination
  • Classic histologic features include fibrous septa, nodules of hepatocytes, abnormal thick walled vessels, bile ductular reaction and chronic inflammation
  • Glutamine synthetase demonstrates characteristic map-like staining by immunohistochemistry.
  • Characteristic map-like staining pattern of focal nodular hyperplasia with glutamine synthetase immunohistochemistry.

questions.text: Reena a 34-year-old female is presented to the emergency ward with severe headache and altered consciousness. A CT scan reveals large mass in temporal lobe producing uncal herniation. Which of the following features may be seen in this case?
questions.solution:
• The uncus of the temporal lobe over the edge of the cerebellar tentorium occurs due to space occupying lesions from large tumors, hemorrhage, stroke, abscess.
  • Option a: Uncal herniation involves the medial temporal lobe (uncus) pushing through the tentorial notch, compressing the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III).

This results in:

Ipsilateral pupillary dilation (early sign due to parasympathetic fiber compression).

Ptosis (drooping eyelid) and impaired eye movements (down-and-out gaze).

  • Option b: Biot's breathing is characterized by groups of quick, shallow breaths followed by apnea.

It is caused by damage to the medulla, not commonly associated with uncal herniation unless the herniation progresses to compress the brainstem severely.

In this case involvement of midbrain leads to Cheyne-Stokes respiratory pattern develops, characterized by a pattern of waxing-and-waning depth of respiration followed by apnoea.

  • Option c: Uncal herniation compresses the oculomotor nerve's parasympathetic fibers, leading to pupillary dilation, not constriction.
  • Option d: While compression of the third cranial nerve is relevant, Biot's breathing and pupillary constriction do not align with uncal herniation. This is incorrect option.

questions.text:
A 69-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a syncopal episode while standing in crowded areas. He reports several similar episodes over the past year, triggered by prolonged standing or emotional distress.
Patient is diagnosed with severe neurogenic syncope. Which of the following is primary indication for electrogenic pacemaker use in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Option a: In cardioinhibitory neurogenic syncope, with sinus pauses exceeding 4-6 seconds, Pacemaker implantation prevents bradycardia/asystole episodes, improving symptoms and quality of life. It is the correct option.
  • Option b: While pacemakers do not directly prevent hypotension in vasovagal syncope, their role in severe cardioinhibitory responses, like prolonged asystole, is well-documented. Reflex-mediated hypotension is not the primary issue here.
  • Option c: Baroreceptor dysfunction is not the primary pathology here. The problem is the excessive cardioinhibitory reflex leading to prolonged asystole.
  • Option d: As option a is the correct choice, this option does not fit as right choice.

questions.text: A newborn was delivered at 30-week age from the pregnant lady. Newborn has difficulty in breathing leading to respiratory distress syndrome. Which of the following factors favour IRDS?
questions.solution:
• Option a: ENaC plays a crucial role in absorbing fluid from the alveolar space during late fetal life and after birth to transition from a fluid-filled to air-filled lung.

Immaturity of ENaC in preterm infants delays the clearance of lung fluid, contributing to pulmonary edema and exacerbating respiratory distress syndrome (IRDS).

  • Option b: Surfactant, produced by type II alveolar cells, reduces alveolar surface tension, preventing alveolar collapse during exhalation.

Surfactant production is complete at around 34 weeks. Preterm infants, particularly those born before 34 weeks, have inadequate surfactant levels, leading to alveolar collapse (atelectasis), reduced lung compliance leading to IRDS.

  • Option c: During fetal life, pulmonary epithelial cells actively secrete chloride ions (Cl-) into the alveolar space, which drives fluid secretion into the lungs.
  • Option d: All these factors-ENaC immaturity, insufficient surfactant production, and continued Cl-secretion-contribute to the pathogenesis of IRDS in preterm infants.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of difficulty relaxing his grip after shaking hands or gripping objects. He denies significant muscle weakness but reports occasional muscle pain after prolonged activity. Patient is diagnosed with myotonia. Which from the options is a type of myotonia?
questions.solution:
• In the various forms of clinical myotonia, muscle relaxation is prolonged after voluntary contraction.
  • Option a: This condition can present with episodes of muscle stiffness (myotonia) along with intermittent weakness. It is caused by mutations in the SCN4A gene, which encodes a voltage-gated sodium channel in skeletal muscle.Myotonia is a hallmark feature due to altered muscle membrane excitability, especially during episodes.
  • Option b: Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder involving antibodies against acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction. It causes fluctuating weakness and fatigue but does not cause myotonia.
  • Option c: This is a paraneoplastic or autoimmune disorder affecting presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels, resulting in reduced acetylcholine release. Like myasthenia gravis, it causes muscle weakness but not myotonia.
  • Option d: This is incorrect because only hyperkalemic periodic paralysis can include myotonia, whereas the other conditions do not exhibit myotonia as a feature.

questions.text: Dense deposit disease is a glomerular disease characterized by the deposition of dense, ribbon-like material within the glomerular basement membrane (GBM). Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the pathogenesis of dense deposit disease?
questions.solution:
A) It is caused by the deposition of immune complexes within the GBM: While immune complexes can deposit within the GBM in various glomerular diseases, this is not the primary mechanism of dense deposit disease.

B) It is caused by the activation of the alternative complement pathway: Dense deposit disease is characterized by the activation of the alternative complement pathway, leading to the deposition of dense, ribbon-like material within the GBM.

C) It is caused by the deposition of fibrin within the GBM: While fibrin can deposit within the GBM in various glomerular diseases, this is not the primary mechanism of dense deposit disease.

D) It is caused by the mutation of the COL4A3 gene: Mutations in the COL4A3 gene are associated with Alport syndrome, a different glomerular disease.

Key Takeaways:

  • Dense deposit disease (C3 related glomerulopathy) manifested by broad, linear, extremely electron dense deposits with C3 within glomerular basement membrane, mesangium, Bowman capsule and tubular basement membrane.
  • Essential features:
  • Rare C3 related glomerulonephritis affecting mostly children and older people.
  • Clinical syndrome of glomerulonephritis with low level of serum C3, related to abnormalities of alternative complement pathway.
  • Varied glomerular pathology by light microscopy with predominant C3 and little or no immunoglobulin deposition by immunofluorescence.
  • Hyperdense intramembranous deposits in the glomerular basement membrane by electron microscopy (pathognomonic).
  • Recurs in almost all renal allografts.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman undergoes a CT scan for abdominal pain, which reveals a 3 cm well-circumscribed renal mass. A renal biopsy is performed, and histological examination reveals a tumor composed of small, uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and distinct cell borders. The cells are arranged in a tubulopapillary pattern. What is the most likely diagnosis of the renal mass?
questions.solution:
A) Renal cell carcinoma (clear cell type): Renal cell carcinoma is a malignant tumor that can have a clear cell morphology, but it typically has more nuclear pleomorphism and mitotic activity.

B) Angiomyolipoma: Angiomyolipoma is a benign tumor composed of blood vessels, smooth muscle cells, and fat cells, which is not consistent with the histological description.

C) Papillary adenoma: Papillary adenoma is a small, benign tumor that can have a papillary architecture, but it typically has a more complex morphology and can have nuclear atypia.

D) Oncocytoma: Oncocytoma is a benign tumor composed of large, uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and distinct cell borders, which is consistent with the histopathological

Add the image below

Key Takeaways:

  • Benign renal epithelial neoplasms characterized by large round eosinophilic cells packed with mitochondria.
  • Renal oncocytoma are benign renal oncocytic neoplasms.
  • Cells are packed with mitochondria under electron microscopy.
  • Often possess pathogenic mitochondrial mutations; it is suggested that the defective mitochondria activates a metabolic checkpoint leading to autophagy impairment and mitochondrial accumulation and that this acts as tumor suppressive mechanism limiting tumor progression
  • Essential to differentiate from mimicker oncocytic renal cell carcinoma entities.

questions.text: study of testicular carcinomas in adults is performed. These neoplasms have a high frequency of karyotypic abnormalities, particularly i(12p). Pathologic findings include focal intratubular germ cell neoplasia adjacent to the malignancies. Which of the following is the most likely risk factor for these carcinomas?
questions.solution:
• The presence of i(12p) karyotypic abnormalities and intratubular germ cell neoplasia (ITGCN) adjacent to the malignancies suggests that the testicular carcinomas in this study are of germ cell origin.

A) Gonadal dysgenesis, also known as Swyersyndrome, is a condition characterized by the presence of a Y chromosome and gonadal dysgenesis, which increases the risk of developing germ cell tumors, including testicular carcinoma.

- The other options are not directly related to the development of testicular carcinoma:

B) Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection is associated with an increased risk of penile and anal cancers, but not testicular cancer.

C) Hydrocele is a condition characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the scrotum, but it is not a risk factor for testicular cancer.

D) Syphilis is a bacterial infection that can increase the risk of certain types of cancer, but it is not a known risk factor for testicular cancer.

Key Takeaways:

  • Gonadal dysgenesis is an abnormal development of the gonads (ovaries or testes).It's usually part of a genetic syndrome.
  • Men with gonadal dysgenesis have a higher risk of developing testicular cancer.
  • Gonadal dysgenesis is a known risk factor for intratubular germ cell neoplasia unclassified (CIS), which is a common precursor to testicular germ cell tumors.
  • The ten-year survival rate for testicular cancer is around 95%.This is due to the tumors' responsiveness to cisplatin-based chemotherapy.

questions.text: What is the main difference in cytoplasmic features between LSIL and HSIL?
questions.solution:
A) LSIL: abundant cytoplasm, HSIL: scant cytoplasm: This is the correct answer. The main difference in cytoplasmic features between LSIL and HSIL is the amount of cytoplasm, with HSIL showing scant cytoplasm.

B) LSIL: scant cytoplasm, HSIL: abundant cytoplasm: This is incorrect.

C) LSIL: normal cytoplasm, HSIL: abnormal cytoplasm: This is partially correct, but it does not specifically address the difference in cytoplasmic abundance.

D) LSIL: abnormal cytoplasm, HSIL: normal cytoplasm: This is incorrect.

Key Takeaways:

The main difference in morphology between low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL) and high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL) is the amount of cytoplasm in the cells:

  • LSIL: Has abundant cytoplasm, similar to intermediate squamous cells
  • HSIL: Has less or scant cytoplasm, similar to basal and parabasal cells

Other morphological differences between LSIL and HSIL include:

  • Location

LSIL affects the lower part of the cervical lining, while HSIL affects most of it

  • Nuclear abnormalities

LSIL may have nuclear enlargement, irregular nuclear membrane, and high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio

  • LSIL is a diagnostic category for HPV transient infection-related changes, while HSIL is used to categorize precancerous lesions. However, some cases may have equivocal features of both LSIL and HSIL, which are called LSIL-H.

choices.text: Release of histamine from mast cells

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of joint pain, a rash on her cheeks, and fatigue. She mentions that these symptoms have worsened over the past few months. Upon examination, you note a butterfly-shaped rash on her face and swelling in multiple joints. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of antinuclear antibodies (ANA) and anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies.
Based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings, which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
A) Direct cytotoxicity by T cells

Direct cytotoxicity by T cells is associated with hypersensitivity type 4 (delayed-type hypersensitivity) rather than type 3. In this case, the symptoms and laboratory findings do not indicate a T cell-mediated mechanism.

B) Immune complex deposition in tissues

The patient's symptoms, including joint pain and a facial rash, along with the presence of ANA and anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies, suggest a condition like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which is associated with the formation of immune complexes that deposit in various tissues, leading to inflammation and damage.

C) Release of histamine from mast cell

The release of histamine from mast cells is characteristic of hypersensitivity type 1 (immediate hypersensitivity) reactions. The clinical findings do not support this mechanism.

D) Autoantibody production causing cellular lysis

While autoantibodies can cause cellular damage, the mechanism described in this case aligns more closely with immune complex deposition rather than direct lysis of cells.

Key Takeaway:

  • In this case, the patient's symptoms and laboratory findings are indicative of a condition related to hypersensitivity type 3, likely systemic lupus erythematosus, characterized by the deposition of immune complexes in tissues.
  • This leads to inflammation and tissue damage, highlighting the importance of recognizing the clinical manifestations and underlying mechanisms of type 3 hypersensitivity for accurate diagnosis and management.

choices.text: Immunologic tolerance is only established in the thymus during T cell development.
Immunologic tolerance can be broken, leading to autoimmune diseases.
Immunologic tolerance occurs only in response to foreign antigens.
Immunologic tolerance is a permanent state that cannot be altered.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about immunologic tolerance is true?
questions.solution:
A) Immunologic tolerance is only established in the thymus during T cell development.

While central tolerance occurs in the thymus (for T cells) and bone marrow (for B cells), peripheral tolerance also develops outside of these organs. Peripheral mechanisms include anergy, suppression by regulatory T cells, and deletion of autoreactive immune cells.

B) Immunologic tolerance can be broken, leading to autoimmune diseases.

Immunologic tolerance is a dynamic process, and when the mechanisms that maintain tolerance fail or are disrupted, it can lead to the activation of autoreactive T or B cells, resulting in autoimmune diseases.

C) Immunologic tolerance occurs only in response to foreign antigens.

Immunologic tolerance primarily refers to the immune system's ability to recognize and not attack self-antigens. It is crucial for preventing autoimmunity, yet it also applies to foreign antigens under certain conditions (like in the case of transplant tolerance).

D) Immunologic tolerance is a permanent state that cannot be altered.

Immunologic tolerance is not a permanent state. It can be influenced by various factors, including infections, changes in the immune system, or the introduction of specific therapies.

Key Takeaway:

  • Immunologic tolerance is a crucial mechanism that prevents the immune system from attacking the body's own tissues.
  • It can be established during T and B cell development and maintained through peripheral mechanisms.
  • However, it is not absolute and can be disrupted, leading to autoimmune diseases, highlighting the delicate balance the immune system must maintain.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman has had a light brown nodule on her left shin for the past year. On examination it is a 0.7-cm firm, nontender nodule. It is excised and on microscopic examination consists of a localized, dermal, spindle cell proliferation with overlying epidermal hyperplasia and downward elongation of hyperpigmented rete ridges. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) The clinical and histological features described are consistent with a dermatofibroma.

Clinical features:

- A firm, nontender nodule on the shin

- Light brown color

- Size: 0.7 cm

Histological features:

- Localized, dermal, spindle cell proliferation

- Overlying epidermal hyperplasia

- Downward elongation of hyperpigmented rete ridges

B) Leiomyoma: A smooth muscle tumor that typically presents as a painful nodule.

C) Merkel cell carcinoma: A rare, aggressive neuroendocrine tumor that typically presents as a rapidly growing, firm nodule.

D) Neurofibroma: A benign nerve sheath tumor that typically presents as a soft, painless nodule.

Key Takeaway:

  • Dermatofibromas are benign, fibrohistiocytictumors that typically present as firm, painless nodules on the extremities.
  • They are often pigmented and can be mistaken for melanocytic nevi.
  • It could be a localized response to trauma.
  • The malignant counterpart that grows larger and is more aggressive is the dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans.

questions.text: Which laboratory method is preferred for confirming Zika virus infection within the first week of symptom onset?
questions.solution:
• Option B is correct because RT-PCR is the gold standard for detecting Zika virus RNA in blood and urine within 7 days of symptom onset.
  • Option A (EIA) is useful but typically applied later in the course of illness after 7 days.
  • Option C (Plaque-reduction neutralization test) is specific but not commonly used due to its complexity.
  • Option D (IFA) is also a viable option but is generally used in later stages of the infection.

choices.text: Leishmania amastigotes are found in the peripheral blood of humans and are the diagnostic form for cutaneous leishmaniasis.
Trypanosoma trypomastigotes are diagnostic in the insect vector, while epimastigotes are the infective form to humans.
Leishmania promastigotes are the infective stage to humans and are found in the sandfly vector, while amastigotes are the diagnostic form found in human tissues.
In visceral leishmaniasis, the infective form is the amastigote, and the diagnostic stage is the promastigote.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the transmission and diagnostic forms of Leishmaniasis and Trypanosomiasis?
questions.solution:
• Option A: This statement is incorrect. Leishmania amastigotes are indeed diagnostic forms but are found in human tissues, not in peripheral blood. Cutaneous leishmaniasis is characterized by skin sores, not typically by amastigotes in blood.
  • Option B: This is incorrect. In Trypanosomiasis, the trypomastigote is the diagnostic form found in the peripheral blood of humans, not in the insect vector. The epimastigote is found in the insect vector and is not the infective form to humans.
  • Option C: This is the correct statement. In Leishmaniasis, promastigotes are the infective stage that is transmitted by the sandfly vector to humans. Amastigotes are the diagnostic form found in human tissues, including skin or internal organs, depending on the leishmaniasis form.
  • Option D: This is incorrect. In visceral leishmaniasis, the infective form is the promastigote (transmitted by the sandfly), while the amastigote is the diagnostic stage found in human tissues.

choices.text: Ingestion of contaminated food or water

questions.text: How is Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) primarily transmitted?
questions.solution:
Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) is primarily transmitted through intimate oral contact, such as kissing or sharing utensils. It is commonly known as the "kissing disease" due to its mode of transmission.

  1. Overview:
    • Virus Type: Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) is a member of the Herpesviridae family.
    • Also Known As: Human Herpesvirus 4 (HHV-4).
  2. Transmission:
    • Primary Route: Spread primarily through saliva (e.g., kissing), hence it is sometimes referred to as the "kissing disease."
    • Other Routes: Can also be transmitted through blood, organ transplantation, and from mother to child during childbirth.
  3. Clinical Manifestations:
    • Infectious Mononucleosis: Characterized by fever, sore throat, swollen lymph nodes, and fatigue. It is the most common manifestation.
    • Chronic Fatigue Syndrome: EBV has been associated with chronic fatigue syndrome, although this link is still being studied.
    • Associated Cancers: EBV is linked to several cancers, including Burkitt lymphoma, Hodgkin lymphoma, and nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  4. Diagnosis:
    • Clinical Evaluation: Based on symptoms and physical examination.
    • Serology: Detection of specific antibodies (e.g., heterophile antibodies) in the blood.
    • PCR Testing: Detects EBV DNA in blood or tissues for more precise diagnosis.
  5. Treatment:
    • Infectious Mononucleosis: Typically managed with supportive care, including rest, hydration, and pain relief. Antiviral medications are not usually required.
    • Complications: Treatment for complications, such as associated cancers, depends on the specific condition.
  6. Prevention:
    • Avoiding Close Contact: Reducing contact with saliva from infected individuals.
    • No Vaccine: There is currently no vaccine available for EBV.

Reference:

Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). (2023). Epstein-Barr Virus and Infectious Mononucleosis. Retrieved from CDC Epstein-Barr Virus

questions.text: Which laboratory diagnostic marker is most specific for confirming congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) in a neonate?
questions.solution:
• A) IgG antibodies: While IgG antibodies are present in neonates, they cannot differentiate between maternal transfer and congenital infection. They are less specific than IgM antibodies for diagnosing CRS.
  • B) IgM antibodies: The presence of IgM antibodies in a neonate is diagnostic of congenital rubella infection because they do not cross the placenta and are produced by the neonate in response to the rubella virus.
  • C) Reverse transcriptase PCR: This test can detect the viral RNA, but it is not as commonly used for the initial diagnosis as IgM antibodies. It is useful in detecting the virus during the early stages.
  • D) Virus isolation from urine: Virus isolation is more likely to be positive within the first six months after birth, but IgM antibodies are more specific and reliable for diagnosing CRS.

Key Takeaway:

IgM antibodies in a neonate are a diagnostic hallmark of congenital rubella syndrome, as they are not transferred across the placenta and indicate the presence of the rubella virus in the infant.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child from a rural area in India develops high fever, vomiting, altered consciousness, and seizures. A diagnosis of Japanese Encephalitis is suspected. Which of the following mosquito species is primarily responsible for the transmission of Japanese Encephalitis virus (JEV)?
questions.solution:
• A) Aedes aegypti: While Aedes aegypti is a vector for viruses like dengue, Zika, and yellow fever, it is not the primary vector for Japanese encephalitis. The Culex species is responsible for JEV transmission.
  • B) Anopheles stephensi:Anopheles mosquitoes are primarily responsible for malaria transmission, not Japanese encephalitis. Culex mosquitoes are the primary vectors for JE.
  • C) Culex tritaeniorhynchus: This is the primary vector for Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) transmission. These mosquitoes are most active during dusk and dawn and breed in rice paddies and other water sources.
  • D) Aedes albopictus: While Aedes albopictus is an important vector for several viral diseases (e.g., dengue and Zika), it is not the primary vector for Japanese encephalitis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Culex tritaeniorhynchus mosquitoes are the primary vectors for Japanese Encephalitis.
  • These mosquitoes breed in rice fields and other stagnant water bodies, particularly in rural areas of Asia.
  • Preventive measures for JE include mosquito control (e.g., insecticide-treated nets) and vaccination in endemic areas.

References:

  • Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Japanese Encephalitis - CDC Guidelines. CDC Japanese Encephalitis
  • World Health Organization (WHO). Japanese Encephalitis Fact Sheet. WHO Japanese Encephalitis

questions.text: Which of the following fungal agents is most commonly associated with chronic meningitis?
questions.solution:
• A) Aspergillus species: While Aspergillus species can cause meningitis, it is more commonly associated with invasive infections, especially in immunocompromised individuals. It is not one of the most common fungal agents of chronic meningitis.
  • B) Histoplasma capsulatum: Histoplasma capsulatum is a fungal agent that is frequently associated with chronic meningitis, especially in immunocompromised patients. It can cause a granulomatous infection in the central nervous system.
  • C) Candida albicans: Candida albicans is more commonly associated with bloodstream infections and invasive candidiasis, rather than chronic meningitis.
  • D) Pseudallescheria boydii: While Pseudallescheria boydii can cause infections in immunocompromised individuals, it is not a common cause of chronic meningitis compared to Histoplasma capsulatum.

Key Takeaways:

  • Histoplasma capsulatum is a common fungal cause of chronic meningitis, especially in patients with compromised immune systems.
  • Other fungal agents like Candida albicans and Aspergillus species are more commonly associated with other types of invasive infections rather than chronic meningitis.

choices.text: Fixed viruses cause longer incubation periods and are more virulent than street viruses.
Fixed viruses do not produce inclusion bodies, do not multiply in extraneural tissues, and have a shortened incubation period.
Street viruses are used for rabies vaccination due to their ability to replicate in extraneural tissues.
Fixed viruses cause more severe neurological symptoms than street viruses.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the difference between street and fixed rabies virus strains?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Incorrect. Fixed viruses have a shorter incubation period and are less virulent than street viruses.
  • Option B: Correct. Fixed viruses, used for rabies vaccination, are adapted through serial propagation in animals. They lose some virulence and do not produce inclusion bodies.
  • Option C: Incorrect. Street viruses are fresh isolates from animals and are not suitable for vaccination due to their unpredictability and ability to replicate in extraneural tissues.
  • Option D: Incorrect. Fixed viruses generally cause milder neurological symptoms compared to street viruses, which have a more variable and severe clinical course.

Key Takeaway:

Fixed viruses are used for rabies vaccines due to their predictable behavior and shortened incubation period, whereas street viruses are more variable and virulent.

References:

  • Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Rabies. Available at: CDC Rabies Information
  • World Health Organization (WHO), Rabies Fact Sheet. Available at: WHO Rabies Fact Sheet

questions.text: Which of the following infections caused by Chlamydia trachomatis is most likely to develop after a treatment with penicillin or cephalosporin for gonococcal urethritis?
questions.solution:
• Option C is correct. Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of postgonococcal urethritis (PGU), which develops after gonococcal urethritis (GU) when patients are treated with penicillin or cephalosporin without antichlamydial drugs.

Gonococcal urethritis is caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae and is treated with penicillin or cephalosporins.

However, Chlamydia trachomatis often co-infects along with gonorrhea.

Penicillins and cephalosporins are effective against N. gonorrhoeae but not effective against Chlamydia, which is an intracellular organism requiring a different class of antibiotics (like doxycycline or azithromycin).

So after treating gonorrhea with penicillin/cephalosporin, Chlamydia infection can persist, leading to nongonococcal urethritis (NGU).

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the purpose of MPT64 antigen detection in the identification of M. tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
• (A) It identifies the presence of mycobacterial DNA in the specimen: This is not the primary function of MPT64. It is an antigen detection test, not a DNA detection method.
  • (B) It detects the species of nontuberculous mycobacteria: This is incorrect. MPT64 is specific to the M. tuberculosis complex, not NTM.
  • (C) It differentiates M. tuberculosis complex from non-tuberculous mycobacteria: This is correct. MPT64 antigen is specific to M. tuberculosis, M. bovis, and M. africanum and is used to differentiate them from NTM.
  • (D) It helps detect drug resistance in M. tuberculosis isolates: This is incorrect. MPT64 antigen detection is not used for drug resistance testing.
