questions.text: Which of the following is the primary method for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis (BV), which is characterized by a shift in the vaginal microbiota, including an increase in Gardnerella vaginalis?
questions.solution:
• (A) Microscopic agglutination test: This test is used primarily for diagnosing Leptospira infection, not for bacterial vaginosis.
  • (B) Nugent's score: This is a diagnostic scoring system based on a Gram stain of vaginal discharge. It helps identify bacterial vaginosis by counting the number of Gardnerella vaginalis, Mobiluncus, and lactobacilli present. A score of 7 or more is considered diagnostic.
  • (C) Wet saline mount for Trichomonas vaginalis: Wet mount is used for diagnosing Trichomonas vaginalis, but it is not a method for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis.
  • (D) PCR for Trichomonas vaginalis: PCR is useful for diagnosing Trichomonas vaginalis infection but is not used for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Nugent's score is the gold standard for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis, using Gram-stained vaginal smears.
  • Bacterial vaginosis involves a shift from lactobacilli dominance to overgrowth of anaerobes such as Gardnerella vaginalis.
  • PCR is not typically used for BV diagnosis but is highly effective for diagnosing Trichomonas vaginalis.

questions.text: A 65 year old patient was scheduled for surgery to remove a glioma located on his left parietal lobe. Which of the following drugs would be most appropriately given before and after surgery to prevent increased intracranial pressure?
questions.solution:
• Osmotic diuretics are often given to patients with a brain tumor before and after neurosurgery to reduce cerebrospinal fluid volume and therefore intracranial pressure.
  • These drugs cannot cross the blood-brain barrier, and they enhance the diffusion of water back into the plasma by elevating plasma osmolality.
  • Mannitol is a low molecular weight compound used i.v. for the treatment of glaucoma and cerebral edema (drug of choice)


Osmotic Diuretics

They are inert drugs that can cause osmotic diuresis.

    Mnemonic [MIGU]

Mannitol,

Isosorbide

Glycerol,

Urea and


Option B & C: Other diuretics are useless in decreasing intracranialpressure.

Option D: Increased intracranial pressure often causes hypertension and bradycardia. Drugs that decrease the heart rate are therefore contraindicated.

Key takeaway
Osmotic diuretics are often given to patients with a brain tumor before and after neurosurgery to reduce cerebrospinal fluid volume and therefore intracranial pressure.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented to the clinic with a 2-month history of right-side head pain recurring on a weekly basis. His headaches were usually preceded by unformed ashes of light, bilaterally, and were associated with nausea, vomiting, and photophobia. The headaches were not relieved by aspirin or ibuprofen and usually lasted all day unless he was able to sleep. A drug acting on which of the following receptors would be most appropriate to stop the migraine attack in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Triptans (e.g., sumatriptan and zolmitriptan) are specific 5-HT1B/1D agonists that are equally as or more effective than ergot alkaloids in the acute treatment of migraine attack.
  • There are two major proposed mechanisms for effectiveness of triptans in acute migraine headache:
    • Vasoconstriction of cerebral vessels via the activation of vascular 5-HT1B receptors
    • Inhibition of release of neuropeptides with inflammatory properties via the activation of presynaptic 5-HT1D receptors
  • Sumatriptan
    • It is the first selective 5-HT1D/1B receptor agonist
    • Advantages of Triptans over Ergot compounds:
      • Sumatriptan is effective and better tolerated than ergotamine.
      • It tends to suppress nausea and vomiting of migraine
      • The triptans have been found to suppress neurogenic inflammation of cranial vessels.
    • The antimigraine activity of sumatriptan has been ascribed to 5-HT1D/1B receptor mediated constriction of dilated cranial blood vessels, especially the arterio-venous shunts in the carotid artery, which express 5-HT1D/1B receptors.

The use of sumatriptan (or other triptans) should be restricted to treatment of acute attacks of moderate to severe migraine not responding to analgesics or their combinations.

Option A: Beta-blockers are effective for the prophylaxis of migraine in some patients, but they are of no value in the treatment of an ongoing migraine attack.

Option B & C: Drugs acting on these receptors can not cure a migraine attack.

Key takeaway The antimigraine activity of sumatriptan has been ascribed to 5-HT1D/1B receptor mediated constriction of dilated cranial blood vessels, especially the arterio-venous shunts in the carotid artery, which express 5-HT1D/1B receptors.

questions.text: A 20 year old male patient diagnosed with acute rheumatic fever, started high-dose salicylate treatment . A few days later, laboratory values indicated increased blood pH, decreased PaCO2, and decreased plasma bicarbonate content . Which of the following acid-base disturbances was most likvely caused by salicylate treatment?
questions.solution:
• In the early phase of salicylate toxicity, salicylates directly stimulate the respiratory center in the brain.
  • This causes hyperventilation, leading to:
    • ↓PaCO₂(because you're breathing out more CO₂)
    • ↑blood pH (more alkaline)
    • ↓plasma bicarbonate (due to renal compensation trying to bring pH back toward normal).
  • This combination fits a diagnosis of respiratory alkalosis.

Later stages of salicylate toxicity can cause metabolic acidosis too, but early on, it's respiratory alkalosis.

  • The lab values indicate that the acid-base disturbance was respiratory alkalosis, which is an effect of high therapeutic doses of salicylates.
  • These drugs stimulate respiration both directly (by a direct effect on the respiratory center in the medulla) and indirectly (by increased production of carbon dioxide due to increased oxygen consumption).
  • Compensation is achieved by increased renal excretion of bicarbonate.
  • This acid-base disturbance is typical of a high salicylate content in blood.

Acute salicylate poisoning

  • Fatal dose in adults is estimated to be 15-30 g, but is considerably lower in children.
  • Manifestations are:
    • Vomiting,
    • Dehydration
    • Electrolyte imbalance
    • Acidotic breathing
    • Hyper/hypoglycaemia
    • Petechial haemorrhages
    • Restlessness, Delirium, Hallucinations
    • Hyperpyrexia, convulsions, coma
    • Death due to respiratory failure + cardiovascular collapse.

Treatment is symptomatic and supportive.

Most important is external cooling and i.v. fluid with Na+, K+, HCO₃⁻ and glucose according to need.

Relationship between the dosage of aspirin and the pharmacologic and toxic effects of the drug.


Aspirin side effects:

  • Mnemonic : [ASPIRIN]
    • Allergic like reactions (urticaria)
    • Susceptibility to bleeding
    • Peptic ulcer
    • Idiosyncratic reactions
    • Reye's syndrome
    • RInging in ears (Tinnitus)
    • Nephropathy

Key Takeaway

Acute salicylate poisoning occurs in adults when fatal dose of aspirin is taken which is estimated to be 15-30 g, characterised by marked hyperthermia, and the respiratory depression & respiratory alkalosis

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman with Parkinson disease had been maintained on levodopa/carbidopa with adjunctive use of a drug that acts by reducing central dopamine metabolism. Which of the following drugs was most likely the adjunctive drug?
questions.solution:
• Two isoenzymes of monoamine oxidase (MAO) metabolize monoamines.
  • MAO-A metabolizes primarily norepinephrine and serotonin, MAO-B metabolizes primarily dopamine and is predominant in the striatum.
  • Selegiline is a selective inhibitor of MAO-B, leading to irreversible inhibition of the enzyme, thus retarding the breakdown of dopamine in the striatum.
  • Because MAO-B is primarily found in the brain, selegiline does not inhibit the peripheral metabolism of dopamine and can be safely taken with levodopa.

Selegiline (Deprenyl)

  • It is a selective and irreversible MAO-B inhibitor.
  • Two isoenzyme forms of MAO, termed MAO-A and MAO-B are recognized; both are present in peripheral adrenergic structures and intestinal mucosa, while the latter predominates in the brain and blood platelets.
  • MAO-B preferentially oxidizes DA
  • Selegiline in low doses (10 mg/day) does not interfere with peripheral metabolism of dietary amines, while intracerebral degradation of DA is retarded.
  • This is responsible for the therapeutic effect in parkinsonism.

Key takeaway

  • Selegiline is a selective inhibitor of MAO-B, leading to irreversible inhibition of the enzyme, thus retarding the breakdown of dopamine in the striatum.

questions.text: A 29 year old female patient presented to gynaecology department with frothy, greenish vaginal discharge with a musty smell. On examination 'strawberry vagina' was noted based on which diagnosis of trichomonas vaginalis was made. Which of the following is the Drug of choice for trichomonas vaginalis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is trichomonas vaginitis. The drug of choice is metronidazole or Tinidazole

Trichomonas vaginitis

  • Metronidazole is the drug of choice; 2.0 g single dose is preferred. Alternatively 400 mg BD-TDS may be used for 7 days.
  • The male partner should be treated concurrently in cases of recurrent infections.

Metronidazole

  • It has broadspectrum cidal activity against anaerobic protozoa, including Giardia lamblia.
  • Many anaerobic and microaerophilic bacteria, such as Bact. fragilis, Fusobacterium, Clostridium perfringens, Cl. difficile, Helicobacter pylori, Campylobacter, peptococci, spirochetes and anaerobic Streptococci are sensitive.
  • Pseudomembranous enterocolitis caused by Cl. difficile is generally associated with use of antibiotics.
  • Oral metronidazole is more effective, more convenient, less toxic, and therefore preferred over vancomycin which may be used in nonresponsive cases, or when the infection recurs.

Key takeaway

  • The drug choice for Trichomonas vaginitis is metronidazole or Tinidazole

questions.text: A homemaker, while working in the kitchen, became a victim of the household fire and passed away. On examination of the wound, which of the following findings will suggest an antemortem burns wound?
questions.solution:
Antemortem burns have a peripheral zone that shows enzyme reaction.

The autopsy findings of antemortem burns include:

  • A line of redness is present
  • Blister containing serous fluid with proteins and chlorides
  • Red and inflamed base
  • Vital reaction in the form of marked cellular exudation, reactive changes in tissue cells present
  • The peripheral zone of the burn shows an increased enzymatic reaction. This is due to the release, activation, and synthesis of enzymes. The mediators of enzyme response are histamine, serotonin, kinins, prostaglandins, etc.

Options B,C,D are findings of postmortem burns.

questions.text: A woman gave birth to twins. The father who believed that they did not belong to him requested DNA testing. After testing, it was found that one child did not belong to him. This case would be best described as?
questions.solution:
• Superfecundation refers to the fertilization of two or more ova from different acts of sexual intercourse, in the same cycle, resulting in the conception of multiple embryos with different genetic fathers. In the given scenario, the woman gave birth to twins, but DNA testing revealed that one child did not belong to the father.
  • This indicates that two separate acts of sexual intercourse with different partners occurred, leading to the fertilization of two different ova by two different spermatozoa. As a result, the twins have different genetic fathers, confirming the occurrence of superfecundation.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - Superfetation: Superfetation refers to the occurrence of a second pregnancy during an ongoing pregnancy, where a woman conceives another fetus while already pregnant. This is not applicable in the given scenario as there is no indication of a second pregnancy occurring during an ongoing pregnancy.
  • Option C - Suppositious child: A suppositious child refers to a child who is falsely or fraudulently claimed or substituted as one's own. In the given scenario, there is no indication of false claims or substitution of the child, as the DNA testing revealed that one child did not belong to the father. Therefore, suppositious child is not the appropriate term for this case.
  • Option D - Atavism: Atavism refers to the reappearance of a characteristic or trait in an organism that is not present in its immediate ancestors but was present in previous generations. It is not applicable in the given scenario, as the issue at hand is related to the genetic paternity of the twins, rather than the reappearance of ancestral traits.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Superfecundation refers to the fertilization of two or more ova from different acts of sexual intercourse, in the same cycle, resulting in the conception of multiple embryos with different genetic fathers. In the given scenario, the woman gave birth to twins, but DNA testing revealed that one child did not belong to the father.

questions.text: Black foot disease with peripheral neuropathy is seen in which metal poisoning?
questions.solution:
• Black foot disease, also known as Blackfoot or arsenicosis, is a condition associated with chronic arsenic poisoning.
  • It is a severe form of peripheral vascular disease in which blood vessels of the lower limb are severely damaged, eventually resulting in gangrene.
  • Prolonged exposure to high levels of arsenic, typically through contaminated drinking water or food, can lead to peripheral neuropathy and other health issues.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B - Lead:
    Lead poisoning can lead to developmental delays, learning difficulties, behavior problems, and impaired growth. In adults, it can cause neurological symptoms, such as headaches, memory loss, and concentration problems, as well as abdominal pain and reproductive It is not associated with black foot disease.
  • Option C - Mercury:
    The symptoms and effects of mercury poisoning depend on the form of mercury involved:
    • Methylmercury, a form of organic mercury found in contaminated fish and seafood, primarily affects the nervous system and can cause developmental issues in children, as well as neurological and cardiovascular problems in adults.
    • It is not associated with black foot disease.
  • Option D - Cadmium: Cadmium poisoning primarily affects the kidneys and can cause kidney damage, causes Itai Itai

KEY TAKEAWAYS-

Black foot disease, also known as Blackfoot or arsenicosis, is a condition associated with chronic arsenic poisoning.

questions.text: You are working as a medical officer in a PHC. One day your friend brought his dead father to the hospital and told you that he died of myocardial infarction. He pressures you to issue the death certificate and you oblige filling up myocardial infarction as the cause of death. Later there were accusations about this death and it was found that this person died of organophosphorus poisoning. You could be tried in court under which BNS/IPC section
questions.solution:
The doctor could be tried under BNS Sec 234 (IPC 197). It deals with issuing or signing false certificates.

BNS Sec 2(6), (IPC 46) denotes the death of the human being, unless the contrary appears from the context. In simple words, the word "death" denotes the death of a human being unless the context suggests otherwise.

BNS Sec 271 (IPC 269) denotes a negligent act likely to spread infection or disease dangerous to life.

BNS Sec 241 (IPC 204) denotes the destruction of documents to prevent their production as evidence.

questions.text: In a cohort study, the participants are grouped based on:
questions.solution:
Cohort study is a type of analytical study which is usually undertaken to obtain additional evidence to refute or support the existence of an association between suspected cause and disease. Cohort study is known by variety of name: prospective study, longitudinal study, incidence study and forward-looking study.

The distinguishing features of cohort studies are:

  1. The cohorts are identified prior to the appearance of the disease under investigation
  2. The study groups, so defined, are observed over a period of time to determine the frequency of disease among them
  3. The study proceeds forward from cause to effect

questions.text: Framingham Heart Study is an example of:
questions.solution:
FRAMINGHAM HEART STUDY:

  • Is a classic example of cohort study
  • Initiated in 1948 by US Public Health Service at Framingham, a town in Massachusetts, USA
  • Aim: To study the relationship of risk factors (serum cholesterol, blood pressure, weight, smoking) to the subsequent development of cardiovascular diseases
  • Age group: 30 - 62 years
  • Sample size: 5127 (4469 - 69% of the sample actually underwent first examination)
  • Method: Multiple exposure was studied, as well as complex interactions among the exposures using multivariate techniques
  • Follow-up:

- Study population was examined every 2 years for 20 years

- Daily surveillance of hospitalizations at only hospital at Framingham

  • Findings of study:

- Increasing risk of CHD with increasing age & more frequently in males

- Hypertensive have a greater risk of CHD

- Elevated blood cholesterol level is associated with CHD

- Tobacco smoking and habitual use of alcohol are associated with increased risk of CHD

- Increased physical activity is associated with decrease in CHD development

- Increase in body weight is associated predisposes to CHD

- Diabetes mellitus increases risk of CHD

Koplik spots are pathognomonic for measles and appear before the rash, not as it disappears.

MEASLES (RUBEOLA):

questions.text: A 60 year old diabetic patient presented with right sided severe ear ache, rapidly progressing infection in the external auditory canal with involvement of bone and presence of granulation tissue. What will be the drug of choice in this case?
questions.solution:
Malignant otitis externa, also known as necrotizing otitis externa or malignant external otitis (MEO), is an infection that affects the external auditory canal and temporal bone.

The causative organism is usually Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and the disease commonly manifests in elderly patients with diabetes. The infection begins as an external otitis that progresses into an osteomyelitis of the temporal bone. Spread of the disease outside the external auditory canal occurs through the fissures of Santorini and the osseocartilaginous junction.

The pain Is out of proportion to the physical examination findings. Marked tenderness is present in the soft tissue between the mandibular ramus and mastoid tip.

Granulation tissue is present at the floor of the osseocartilaginous junction. This finding is virtually pathognomonic of malignant external otitis (MEO). Otoscopic examination may also reveal exposed bone.

Treatment includes meticulous glucose control, aural toilet, systemic and ototopic antimicrobial therapy. Fluoroquinolones that attain high soft tissue and bone levels with oral doses were then developed. Subsequently, several authors have demonstrated the efficacy of oral ciprofloxacin monotherapy.

questions.text: Inferior turbinate is ?
questions.solution:
The inferior turbinate is a bone in the nose that's the largest of the three turbinates and has many anatomical features, including:

Location

The inferior turbinate is located in the lower part of the lateral nasal wall, next to the nasal floor.

Structure

The inferior turbinate is a scroll-like bone that increases the surface area for air to come into contact with. It is a separate bone and not a part of maxillary ethmoid or sphenoid bone.

Articulations

The inferior turbinate articulates with the maxillary, palatine, and ethmoid bones.

Blood supply

The inferior turbinate's cancellous central bony layer contains the major arterial supply of the turbinate.

Epithelium

The inferior turbinate is covered with a pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium.

Mucosa

The mucosa of the inferior turbinate contains goblet cells, ciliated columnar cells, and basal cells.

Submucosa

The submucosa of the inferior turbinate contains glands that produce nasal secretions and inflammatory mediators.

Nasolacrimal duct

The inferior meatus, which is located beneath the inferior turbinate, contains the opening of the nasolacrimal duct.

Hasner valve

The inferior meatus also contains the Hasner valve, which prevents air reflux from the lacrimal system.

Dimensions

The inferior turbinate is typically 35-58 mm in length and 6-21 mm in height.

Allergies, irritation, or infection can cause the inferior turbinate to become swollen and inflamed, which can lead to nasal obstruction and congestion.

questions.text: Treatment of choice in recurrent epistaxis due to hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia is ?
questions.solution:
Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT) is a rare genetic disorder that can cause frequent nosebleeds:

Symptoms

The most common symptom is frequent nosebleeds, which can start in childhood and sometimes occur daily. Other symptoms include:

Small red spots or lacy red vessels on the lips, face, fingertips, tongue, and inside of the mouth

Iron deficiency anemia

Shortness of breath

Headaches

Seizures

Causes

HHT occurs when blood vessels don't develop normally, resulting in abnormal blood vessels called telangiectases. These fragile vessels can bleed easily, especially when they form in the lining of the nose or gut.

Treatment

There's no cure for HHT, but treatments can help control bleeding and prevent complications. Treatments include:

Electrocautery to stop nasal tissues from bleeding

Iron supplementation to reverse anemia

Embolization

Surgery in form of septodermoplasty

Stereotactic radiosurgery

Prevalence

HHT affects males and females equally, and is estimated to occur in about 1 in 5,000 people. However, it’s often underdiagnosed because some people with HHT have few obvious symptoms.

questions.text: Fracture of zygoma shows all of the following except ?
questions.solution:
A zygoma fracture, also known as a zygomaticomaxillary complex (ZMC) fracture, is often caused by trauma to the face, nose, or eye. Symptoms include:

Pain: Pain in the affected area, especially when palpated

Swelling: Swelling in the cheek and eyelids

Bruising: Bruising around the eyes

Facial distortion: Flattening of the cheek, or a widened facial appearance

Step-offs: Palpable step-offs at the infraorbital rim or upper lateral edge of the orbit

Diplopia: Double vision

Trismus: Difficulty opening the jaw

Ocular issues: Impaired ocular motility, globe malposition, or subconjunctival hemorrhage

Other symptoms: Headache, vertigo, epistaxis, or loss of consciousness

A physical exam may also reveal: Posterior displacement of the fracture fragment, Inferior displacement of the lateral canthal angle, Entrapment of orbital contents, and Enophthalmos.

questions.text: A 4 year old child developed acute laryngobronchitis. His xray image is given below. What is the name of the sign shown in this image ?
questions.solution:
The steeple sign is a radiographic appearance that can be seen on a frontal neck radiograph of a patient with croup or other conditions:

Appearance

The steeple sign is characterized by a narrowing of the subglottic lumen that makes the tracheal air column look like a church steeple or a steeply pitched roof.

Cause

The steeple sign is caused by edema in the trachea, which elevates the tracheal mucosa and makes the air column lose Its normal lateral convexities.

Conditions

The steeple sign is usually seen in children with croup, but it can also be caused by other conditions, such as angioneurotic edema, bacterial tracheitis, epiglottitis, and thermal injury.

Croup is a viral infection of the upper airway that can cause a characteristic cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, and dyspnea. Other symptoms of acute laryngotracheobronchitis, also known as croup, include mild chest wall retraction and audible stridor.

Treatment for croup includes intranasal oxygen, oral dexamethasone, and epinephrine nebulization.

questions.text: Vertical and horizontal fractures of nasal septum are known as ?
questions.solution:
Nasal fractures are usually identified visually and through physical examination.In addition, relevant questions to ask the patient include whether there is a noticeable cosmetic deformity and whether the patient has difficulty breathing through the nose after the injury.

A priority is to distinguish simple fractures limited to the nasal bones (Type 1) from fractures that also involve other facial bones and/or the nasal septum (Types 2 and 3). In simple Type 1 fractures X-Rays supply surprisingly little information beyond clinical examination. However, diagnosis may be confirmed with X-rays or CT scans, and these are required if other facial injuries are suspected.

A fracture that runs horizontally across the septum is sometimes called a 'Jarjavay fracture', and a vertical one, a 'Chevallet fracture'.

Although treatment of an uncomplicated fracture of nasal bones is not urgent- anti inflammatory drugs are given for 5 to 7 days. Closed reduction and fixation is done only if patient sustains cosmetic deformity or nasal obstruction even after 7 days of injury.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with severe eye pain, blurred vision, and blood in the anterior chamber following a high-speed motor vehicle accident. On examination, he has a torn cornea with a shallow anterior chamber, an irregular pupil, and a positive Seidel test. Which of the following is the MOST LIKELY diagnosis and complication?
questions.solution:
Open Globe Penetrating Injuries

  • Overview:
    • Penetrating injuries from sharp objects or foreign bodies are serious and require immediate attention. The eye should be shielded, and the patient examined under general anesthesia. Repair should be considered promptly.
  • Complications:
    • Iridocyclitis (common after perforating wounds)
    • Risk of infection and sympathetic ophthalmitis (serious complication)
  • Corneal and Scleral Wounds:
    • Corneal wounds: Linear or lacerated; small wounds heal well unless infected (treated like a perforating ulcer). Large wounds often cause iris prolapse, requiring surgery with 10-0 nylon sutures.
    • Scleral wounds (posterior to the limbus): Require thorough exploration, suturing, and cryoapplications to prevent retinal detachment.
  • Infections:
    • Dirty corneal wounds (e.g., caused by vegetable matter) may lead to pyogenic infections and ring abscess
    • Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection can cause rapid necrosis, requiring intensive antibiotic treatment and possibly therapeutic keratoplasty.
    • If infection reaches the anterior chamber, it can lead to iridocyclitis, endophthalmitis, or panophthalmitis.

questions.text: Which of the following features is least likely to be associated with early-stage papilloedema?
questions.solution:
Papilloedema:

Definition:

Papilloedema is swelling of the optic disc due to increased intracranial pressure (ICP). This non-inflammatory condition arises as the optic nerve sheath, continuous with brain meninges, transmits raised ICP to the optic disc.

Pathogenesis:

  1. Mechanism:
    • Blockage of axoplasmic transport in optic nerve fibers.
    • Elevated cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pressure causes axoplasmic stasis and optic disc swelling.
    • Secondary vascular changes occur on the disc surface.
  2. Key Factor:
    • Relief is possible with procedures like optic nerve sheath fenestration.

Pathology:

  • Features:
    • Passive edema at the optic nerve head.
    • Engorged, tortuous vessels; swollen axons with disrupted mitochondria.
    • Retinal and macular involvement (e.g., macular star, cotton-wool spots).
    • Chronic cases lead to secondary optic atrophy.

Aetiology:

  1. Primary Cause:
    • Increased ICP due to conditions like brain tumors, hydrocephalus, pseudotumor cerebri, or subarachnoid hemorrhage.
  2. Other Causes:
    • Malignant hypertension.
    • Venous thrombosis, aneurysms, or abscesses.

Clinical Features:

  1. Symptoms:
    • Early stages: transient blurred vision, episodic blackouts, headache, nausea, vomiting.
    • Advanced stages: progressive vision loss, enlarged blind spots, optic atrophy.
  2. Signs:
    • Early: blurred optic disc margins, hyperemia, reduced venous pulsations.
    • Progressive: disc swelling, hemorrhages, exudates, macular star, and tortuous veins.
    • Late: optic atrophy and irreversible vision loss.

Diagnosis:

  • Based on ophthalmoscopic findings, ICP measurement, and neuroimaging to exclude other causes.

questions.text: Which is the longest part of optic nerve?
questions.solution:
Parts of the Optic Nerve

The optic nerve is approximately 47-50 mm in length and consists of 4 parts:

  1. Intraocular Part (1 mm): Starts at the optic disc, passes through the choroid and sclera (forming the lamina cribrosa), and connects to the intraorbital part.
  2. Intraorbital Part (30 mm): Extends from the back of the eyeball to the optic foramina. It is slightly curved to accommodate eye movements and is surrounded by the annulus of Zinn, where it is close to the origin of the rectus muscles.
  3. Intracanalicular Part (6-9 mm): Located near the ophthalmic artery and sphenoid and posterior ethmoidal sinuses. Its proximity to the sinuses can lead to retrobulbar neuritis following sinus infections.
  4. Intracranial Part (10 mm): Lies above the cavernous sinus and converges with the other optic nerve to form the optic chiasma.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a therapeutic application of cryotherapy in ophthalmology?
questions.solution:
Cryotherapy in Ophthalmology

Cryopexy: Application of intense cold (-40°C to -100°C) using a cryoprobe to treat various ocular conditions.

Principle:

Cryotherapy works on the Joule-Thompson principle of cooling, which results in tissue injury by intense cold.

Cryo Unit:

  • Uses gases like freon, nitrous oxide, or carbon dioxide as cooling agents.
  • Cryoprobes come in various sizes, e.g., 1mm for intravitreal use, 1.5mm for cataract extraction, 2.5mm for retina, and 4mm for cyclocryopexy.

Modes of Action:

  • Tissue necrosis (e.g., in tumors, cyclocryopexy).
  • Adhesion production (e.g., between retina and choroid in retinal detachment).
  • Vascular occlusion (e.g., in Coats' disease).
  • Adherence of cryoprobe (e.g., during cataract extraction).

Uses:

  1. Lids:
    • Cryolysis for trichiasis
    • Cryotherapy for warts, Molluscum contagiosum, basal cell carcinoma, and haemangioma.
  2. Conjunctiva:
    • For hypertrophied papillae in vernal catarrh.
  3. Cornea:
    • Treats herpes simplex keratitis.
  4. Lens:
    • Used in cryoextraction for cataract surgery -ICCE (no longer common today).
  5. Ciliary Body:
    • Cyclocryopexy for absolute glaucoma and neovascular glaucoma.
  6. Retina:
    • Sealing retinal holes in retinal detachment.
    • Prophylactic cryopexy to prevent retinal detachment.
    • Anterior retinal cryopexy in ischemic retinal diseases.
    • Treatment of retinoblastoma and angiomas.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol use presents with confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
OPTION A - Vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency leads to Wernicke's encephalopathy, characterized by confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia, particularly in chronic alcohol users.

OPTION B - Vitamin B6 deficiency can cause neuropathy, but it does not cause this triad of symptoms.

OPTION C - Vitamin B12 deficiency is associated with subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, not Wernicke's encephalopathy.

OPTION D - Vitamin D deficiency causes osteomalacia and rickets, not neurological symptoms.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

  1. Wernicke's encephalopathy requires prompt treatment with parenteral thiamine to prevent progression to Korsakoff syndrome.
  2. Chronic alcohol use impairs thiamine absorption and storage.

questions.text: A 72-year-old male presents with sudden onset of hemiparesis, dysarthria, and loss of coordination. His blood pressure is 180/100 mmHg, and he has a history of atrial fibrillation. A CT scan shows a hyperdense lesion in the right basal ganglia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Acute ischemic stroke typically presents with neurological deficits without a hyperdense lesion on CT scan.
  • Option B: The most likely diagnosis is an intracerebral hemorrhage, which can present with sudden-onset neurological deficits and show a hyperdense lesion on CT due to blood accumulation.
  • Option C: Subarachnoid hemorrhage would present with a sudden severe headache and not localized neurological deficits.
  • Option D: Transient ischemic attack (TIA) presents with temporary neurological deficits and would not show a hyperdense lesion on CT.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Intracerebral hemorrhage presents with sudden neurological deficits and a hyperdense lesion on CT.

questions.text: In a patient with Parkinson's disease, the cardinal feature is:
questions.solution:
OPTION A - Chorea is associated with Huntington's disease.

OPTION B - Dystonia can occur but is not a cardinal feature of Parkinson's disease.

OPTION C - Bradykinesia (slowness of movement) is one of the key diagnostic features of Parkinson's disease.

OPTION D - Myoclonus is not characteristic of Parkinson's disease.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The triad of bradykinesia, rigidity, and resting tremor defines Parkinson's disease.

choices.text: Immediate incision and drainage of the abscess under local anesthesia
Refer to a breast surgeon for evaluation of breast cancer

questions.text: A 32-year-old breastfeeding woman presents with a painful, swollen, erythematous mass in her right breast, associated with fever and fatigue. The mass is firm and tender on examination, with no fluctuation. She also has tender axillary lymph nodes. She has no history of trauma or surgery, but this is her first episode of such symptoms. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Acute mastitis can occur in lactating as well as non-lactating women, with the former being more common.

The incidence of acute mastitis in lactating mothers ranges from 3% to 20%, with Staphylococcus aureus being the most common cause. Abscess formation typically occurs at two key stages:

  1. First month postpartum due to inexperience or improper breastfeeding.
  2. During weaning caused by engorgement and nipple trauma from the baby's teeth.

If left untreated, acute mastitis in breastfeeding women often progresses from generalized cellulitis to abscess formation. Cellulitis initially presents with erythema, pain, and swelling. If not addressed, it can progress to an abscess, which is typically fluctuant. However, in the case of a deep-seated abscess, fluctuation may be absent. Associated symptoms include fever, malaise, difficulty feeding, and tender axillary lymph nodes.

Ultrasonography is essential for diagnosis, revealing increased echogenicity (cellulitis) and a hypoechoic collection (pus) with floating debris, indicating liquefaction necrosis.

In such cases, the most appropriate management step is ultrasound-guided drainage to accurately drain the abscess, especially in deep-seated abscesses where fluctuation may not be palpable.

Option A: A breast support garment, cold compression on the breast (Not warm), and analgesia aid in symptomatic relief. During the cellulitic stage, the patient should be treated with anti-staphylococcal antibiotics such as cloxacillin, flucloxacillin, or erythromycin. Breastfeeding should be actively continued from both breasts with frequent emptying of the affected breast.

Option B: Contrary to the practice of incision and drainage, ultrasound-guided drainage in a breast abscess gives an excellent cosmetic result, does not hamper breastfeeding, and can be done as a day-care procedure with a high success rate.

Option C: This option is correct. In abscesses >3 cm in diameter or those containing more than 30 mL of pus (assessed on ultrasonography), a vacuum suction catheter is inserted under ultrasound guidance to drain the pus

Option D: Most of the cases of breast cancer are painless. Hence this option is not correct.

Key Takeaway Point:

Treatment requires antibiotics and frequent emptying of the breast. True abscesses require drainage. Initial attempts at drainage should include needle aspiration; surgical incision and drainage should be reserved for abscesses that do not resolve after aspiration and treatment with antibiotics. In such cases, abscesses are generally multiloculated.

Ultrasound evaluation can assist in characterizing a breast abscess and help to guide needle aspiration.

Antibiotics should be continued for 14 days.

choices.text: Tight casts are a common cause of compartment syndrome
Pulselessness is an extremely late sign
Compartment syndrome can occur in open fractures
The inci-dence of compartment syndrome associated with high- and low-energy injuries is nearly equal

questions.text: All are true regarding compartment Syndrome except?
questions.solution:
Option A: (False)

Compartment syndrome is raised pressure in a fascial compartment to a level that compromises tissue perfusion.

There are several causes of compartment syndrome, fractures being the most common (70%), followed by soft-tissue contusions (23%).

Rarer causes include bleeding disorders, including anti coagulation; burns (particularly circumferential third-degree burns); post-ischaemic swelling (reperfusion injury); tight casts/ dressings; and extravasation of intravenous infusions (contrast under pressure).

Option B: (True)

Compartment syndrome is a clinical diagnosis characterised by pain out of proportion, increasing pain, and pain on passive stretch, with paraesthesia possible. Paralysis, numbness, and pallor are late signs and pulselessness is an extremely late sign

Options C & D: (True)

There are some common pitfalls to remember. The incidence of compartment syndrome associated with high- and low-energy injuries is nearly equal. Compartment syndrome can occur in open fractures. Have a high index of suspicion and be particularly vigilant in patients with an altered level of consciousness

KeyTakeAwayPoint:

choices.text: The vast majority of fistulas are Extra-sphincteric
Management strategies are different for Suprasphincteric fistula and high-level trans-sphincteric tracks
Loose setons are used in the Fistula in ano due to chrons disease

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about Fistula in ano?
questions.solution:
Option A: Anal fistula may be found in association with Crohn's disease, tuberculosis, lymphogranuloma venereum, actinomycosis, rectal duplication, foreign body, and malignancy (which may also very rarely arise within a longstanding fistula).

Option B: The vast majority of fistulas are intersphincteric or trans-sphincteric

Option C: Suprasphincteric fistula (10%) runs up to a level above the puborectalis and then curls downwards through the levators and ischioanal fossa to reach the skin. They are often caused by excessive probing of an abscess cavity or fistula tract during examination under anesthesia. They are difficult to distinguish from high-level trans-sphincteric tracks; however, the management strategies are similar.

Option D: Loose setons are also used for long-term palliation to avoid septic and painful exacerbations by establishing effective drainage, most often in Crohn's disease and in those with problematic fistulae not wishing to countenance the possibility of incontinence

Key Takeaway Point:

questions.text: Which of the following factors is NOT included in the calculation of the Thoracoscore, a scoring system used to predict mortality following thoracic surgery?
questions.solution:
The Thoracic Surgery Scoring System (Thoracoscore) is the most widely used model to assess the risk of operative mortality in thoracic patients.

Risk is calculated based on nine variables

  1. Age,
  2. Sex,
  3. American Society of Anesthesiologists score,
  4. Performance status,
  5. Dyspnoea score,
  6. Priority of surgery,
  7. Extent of surgery,
  8. Malignant diagnosis and
  9. Composite comorbidity score.

It is currently the most robust model available to estimate the risk of death when considering patients for thoracic surgery.

KeyTakeAwayPoint:

questions.text: A 22-year-old man with a left pulmonary contusion, open comminuted left femur fracture, and mild head injury (GCS 12) develops confusion, hypoxemia (88% saturation), and a petechial rash on his chest and axillae 40 hours after a motorcycle crash. He was in skeletal traction, on antibiotics, and supplemental oxygen. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Option B: This is the most likely diagnosis. The patient has risk factors (a long bone fracture and trauma) and presents with classic signs of FES: confusion, hypoxemia (oxygen saturation of 88%), and a petechial rash. Symptoms typically develop within 24-72 hours after the injury, which aligns with the timeline in this case.

Option A: ADR can present with confusion and rashes, but is mostly provoked by infusion of certain drugs or fluids. The question does not have such data.

Option C: Drug-induced thrombocytopenia could lead to petechiae due to low platelet counts. However, it usually presents with more generalized thrombocytopenic symptoms, such as easy bruising or significant bleeding. It would not explain the symptoms of hypoxemia, confusion, or timing as effectively as FES.

Option D: Though a drop in GCS signifies traumatic brain injury. The hypoxemia and rashes are not explained. Hence this option is wrong

Key Take Away Point:

  • Fat emboli syndrome (FES) is a condition characterized by respiratory distress, altered mental status, and skin petechiae.
  • Clinical signs are evident hours to days after an injury involving long bone or pelvic fractures.
  • Marrowfat from the fracture site is believed to enter the pulmonary circulation, where it activates the coagulation cascade, causes platelet dysfunction, releases vasoactive substances and inflammatory cytokines, and causes subsequent neutrophil infiltration.
  • The treatment of FES is mostly supportive, but a meta-analysis by Bederman and colleagues has shown that the use of corticosteroids in patients with multiple long bone fractures reduces the rate of FES by 78% without significantly increasing the risk of complications related to the treatment of the fractures.

choices.text: Broad-spectrum antibiotics and immediate surgical debridement

questions.text: A 55-year-old diabetic man presents with severe perineal pain, swelling, and crepitus. His skin shows necrosis, and he has leukocytosis and elevated lactate. What is the most critical next step in management?
questions.solution:
Fournier Gangrene is a frequently tested topic in Neet PG/ Fmge.

Option D: It is a fulminant form of necrotizing fasciitis of the perineal, genital, or perianal regions, commonly affecting elderly men, but can also occur in women and children.

Who is at risk? FG has been associated with diabetes, chronic alcohol abuse, and immunosuppression, although it can occur in healthy patients without significant comorbidities

Causative organism? FG is typically associated with a mixed flora, both aerobic and anaerobic. Cultures from the wounds commonly show Klebsiella, streptococci, staphylococci, clostridia, Bacteroides, and corynebacteria.

Signs and symptoms: The local signs and symptoms may include intense pain and swelling. Crepitus of the inflamed tissues is a common feature because of the presence of gas-forming organisms. As the subcutaneous inflammation worsens, necrotic patches appear over the overlying skin and progress to more extensive necrosis.

Fate of the infection: FG is a surgical emergency: it is usually rapidly progressive and quickly leads to sepsis, potentially with multiple organ failure and even death. Regardless of the cause of FG, the testes are usually spared as the blood supply originates intraabdominal.

Treatment: Treatment of FG requires an aggressive multimodal approach, including hemodynamic stabilization and broad-spectrum antibiotics; however, early aggressive surgical debridement should be commenced without delay. It must be emphasized that early surgical debridement is the cornerstone of treatment and if delayed, may have a negative impact on prognosis.

Option A: Though insulin dosage and infusions may be required, it's not the most critical step in the management of this patient, since it is a surgical emergency.

Option B: Imaging is often not necessary in the case of a septic patient, as the delay in treatment may lead to mortality.

Option C: Hyperbaric oxygen therapy is a newer modality involved in the treatment of Necrotising fascitis, but source control in the form of surgical debridement has to be done prior to it.

Key take away Point:

choices.text: "Milking" the mass distally past the obstruction
Cholecystectomy, enterotomy, and removal of the mass
Enterotomy and removal of the mass

questions.text: An 85-year-old woman presents with severe abdominal pain, distension, tachycardia, oliguria, and metabolic acidosis. Abdominal radiographs reveal pneumobilia and an obstructing mass consistent with a high suspicion of gallstone ileus. During exploratory laparotomy, what is the optimal surgical approach to address the bowel obstruction while minimizing perioperative morbidity in this hemodynamically unstable, elderly patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: At laparotomy, the stone should be milked proximally away from the site of impaction. It may be possible to crush the stone within the bowel lumen; if not, the intestine is opened at this point and the gallstone is removed. If the gallstone is faceted, a careful check for other enteric stones should be made. The region of the gallbladder should not be explored.

Option A: Pushing the stone distally into the bowel may result in obstruction at another, potentially less accessible site, particularly if the bowel becomes progressively narrower (e.g., at the ileocecal valve).

Option B: Resection is unnecessary because it might lead to the need for anastomosis in an unstable patient who is also old. Hence not advisable.

Option C: Cholecystectomy in an acute setting is not to be done. Hence this option is incorrect.

Key Take Away Point:

A cholecystoenteric fistula should not be resected unless the patient is stable and there are residual gallstones that may cause infection or recurrent ileus.

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors for cholangiocarcinoma except?
questions.solution:
Option A:

The major risk factor in Western practice is PSC. It is estimated that a longstanding history of PSC increases the risk of developing biliary tract cancer 20-fold compared with the normal population; those with concomitant IBD are at significantly higher risk.

Option B:(Sabiston) Historically, the most common risk factors for the development of cholangiocarcinoma (all types) were primary sclerosing cholangitis, choledochal cyst disease, hepatolithiasis, and RPC. Recent epidemiologic evidence has now linked IHC to HBV infection, HCV infection, cirrhosis, nonalcoholic steatohepatitis, and diabetes.

Option C :

Congenital cystic disease, hepatolithiasis, oriental cholangiohepatitis, hepatitis C virus infection, and infestation with liver flukes have also been associated with an increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma.

Reason: While the pathophysiology is unclear, it is thought that these parasites cause chronic inflammation that leads to DNA mutations through the production of carcinogens and free radicals; the latter can stimulate cellular proliferation in the intrahepatic bile ducts and ultimately lead to invasive cancer

All of the above are risk factors for cholangiocarcinoma ( Based on Sabiston and Schwartz's textbook of surgery).

Schwartz: Most cases of extrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma develop de novo with no identifiable risk factors.

However, there is an increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma in patients with choledochal cysts, ulcerative colitis, hepatolithiasis, biliary-enteric anastomoses, hepatitis B and C, cirrhosis, biliary tract infections with Clonorchis (liver flukes), and chronic typhoid carriers. Exposure to dietary nitrosamines, Thorotrast, or dioxin also puts patients at increased risk for cholangiocarcinoma.

KeyTakeAwayPoints:


  • Cholangiocarcinoma appears to occur at an earlier age in patients with PSC (30-50 years of age) than in the general population.
  • In addition, the disease is usually multifocal and detected at an advanced stage, resulting in a poor prognosis compared with the general population.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman with a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is 36 weeks pregnant and is on LMWH for thromboprophylaxis. She is scheduled for a Caesarean section. How long should LMWH be withheld before the procedure to minimize the risk of bleeding complications?
questions.solution:
• LMWH should generally be withheld for 24 hours prior to a Caesarean section to minimize the risk of bleeding. This is because LMWH has a longer half-life compared to unfractionated heparin.
  • Withholding for 12 hours may still carry a risk of bleeding, while 36-48 hours could unnecessarily increase the risk of thromboembolism.

choices.text: Lisinopril is a first-line choice for the management of hypertension in pregnancy due to its safety profile
Lisinopril can be used safely throughout pregnancy without any fetal risks, execpt first trimester
Lisinopril is contraindicated in pregnancy due to its potential teratogenic effects, particularly in the second and third trimesters
Lisinopril is the preferred agent for treating hypertension in pregnant women with proteinuria and edema

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman, G2P1, at 28 weeks of gestation, presents for a routine check-up. She has a history of hypertension, which has been poorly controlled with lifestyle modifications alone. Her blood pressure readings today are 160/110 mmHg, and her urine dipstick is positive for 1+ protein. On further examination, the patient has mild edema and a headache but no visual changes or upper abdominal pain.

Which of the following statements regarding the use of Lisinopril in this patient is true?
questions.solution:
• Lisinopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, which works by inhibiting the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), reducing blood pressure. However, its use in pregnancy is contraindicated, especially in the second and third trimesters, due to the risk of teratogenic effects (e.g., renal failure, oligohydramnios, hypotension, and even fetal death).
  • In cases of hypertension in pregnancy, labetalol and nifedipine are typically preferred, as they have a better safety profile in pregnancy compared to ACE inhibitors.
  • Lisinopril can be safely used in non-pregnant patients with hypertension, but for pregnant women, especially after the first trimester, alternatives should be considered to avoid fetal complications.

Reference: ACOG Practice Bulletin No. 203 on "Chronic Hypertension in Pregnancy"

questions.text: A 14-year-old adolescent girl is brought to the emergency department 45 minutes after passing out during her hockey game. She was running down the field with another player, going for the ball. She did not collide with another player or trip. She does not recall any pain or dizziness. She is otherwise healthy and very athletic. Her vital signs and physical examination findings are unremarkable. Of the following which test is most likely to reveal the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient in this vignette had syncope during exercise or physical activity, which should raise suspicions of a cardiac etiology. This concerning history is often difficult to elicit.
  • Of the response choices listed, electrocardiography is the most likely to reveal the diagnosis.
  • Syncope is an acute and transient loss of consciousness that resolves without intervention. Syncope can have neurally mediated, situational, neurologic, psychogenic, or cardiac causes

questions.text: A 2-month-old male infant presents to the emergency department with acute onset of bilious emesis and a history of poor feeding and abdominal distention. His last bowel movement was over 3 days ago. The best diagnostic test will be?
questions.solution:
• A limited upper gastrointestinal (UGI) contrast series is the best examination to visualize the duodenum and assess for malrotation and midgut volvulus.
  • It should be performed, whenever possible, under fluoroscopy and by an experienced pediatric radiologist.
  • Sensitivity of a limited UGI series in infants with signs of malrotation is approximately 96%.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child has severe coagulopathy. Which of the following clotting factor level can be used to differentiate between chronic liver disease and disseminated intravascular coagulation?
questions.solution: • Factor 8 will be low in case of DIC and normal or high in case of chronic liver disease, because all factors synthesized by liver except Factor 8 can be synthesized outside the liver.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of a gray patch of the lumbo-sacral region in neonate?
questions.solution:
• Dermal melanocytosis (mongolian spot) is a benign melanocytic lesion that occurs in more than 90% of African-American infants, more than 80% of Asian infants, 70% of Hispanic infants, and close to 10% of Caucasian infants.
  • The lesions appear as gray, blue-black, or brown patches, most commonly over the lumbosacral back and buttocks.
  • Most are present at birth and fade in the first 2 to 3 years of life, although occasionally they persist into adulthood.

questions.text: A 16-month-old girl is evaluated in ER for a rash and difficulty breathing. She was in her usual state of good health until, while eating a peanut butter and jelly sandwich, she suddenly developed a cough, swelling of her lips, and a rash. On physical examination, she has a heart rate of 140 beats/min, respiratory rate of 30 breaths/min, blood pressure of 70/40 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 82% in room air. She has swelling of her lips, an urticarial rash, and diffuse wheezing on chest auscultation. Which of the following best describes the allergic reaction type?
questions.solution:
• These findings are consistent with anaphylaxis, a type 1, IgE-mediated allergic reaction.
  • Type 2 reactions are antibody driven (e.g., autoimmune hemolytic diseases).
  • Type 3 reactions are caused by antigen-antibody complexes (e.g., drug induced serum sickness).
  • Type 4 reactions are cell mediated and often described as a delayed reaction (eg, proctocolitis in infants).
  • The most common food allergies include milk, soy, and egg; peanut, seafood, wheat, and tree nuts account for most of the remaining allergens.
  • Serum IgE levels or skin prick testing are the tests of choice for diagnosing IgE-mediated allergies.

questions.text: Identify the probable condition from the given skull X ray?
questions.solution:
• The skull x ray is suggestive of Hair on end appearance.
  • 'Hair-on-end' sign is seen in the diploic spaces on the skull radiographs appearing like long, thin vertical striations that resemble hairs standing on ends.
  • Hair-on-end appearance of the skull is a characteristic feature of chronic hemolysis usually seen in patients with thalassemia and sickle cell anemia.

questions.text: A term boy is born limp and gets intubated in labor room. Baby is ventilated and put on SIMV mode of ventilation. His x ray is as follows. Which of the following is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The X ray is suggestive of bowel loops in the chest with shift of cardiac shadow on right. These are characteristic changes in CDH.
  • The child will present at birth with progressive respiratory distress needing respiratory support. Auscultation will confirm the bowel sounds in chest with shift of cardiac sounds on the right.
  • Due to shift of abdominal content in chest, abdomen might be scaphoid.

questions.text: Identify the condition based on the image showing a person with a significant lack of pigmentation in the skin, hair, and eyes
questions.solution:
Albinism is a genetic condition characterized by a complete or partial absence of melanin, leading to a lack of pigmentation in the skin, hair, and eyes. Individuals with albinism often have very light skin and hair, and they may also experience vision problems due to the lack of pigment in the eyes.

Option A. Vitiligo: This condition involves the loss of skin pigmentation in patches, but it does not affect the entire body uniformly as seen in albinism.

Option C. Piebaldism: This is a genetic condition that presents with white patches of skin and hair, but it usually involves some areas of normal pigmentation and does not affect the eyes.

Option D. Tuberous sclerosis: This is a genetic disorder that causes benign tumors in multiple organs and may lead to skin findings such as hypopigmented macules, but it does not result in the generalized lack of pigmentation seen in albinism.

Key Takeaway

Albinism is a genetic condition marked by a complete or partial absence of melanin, resulting in a significant lack of pigmentation in the skin, hair, and eyes, often accompanied by vision problems.

questions.text: A patient presented with hypo-pigmented macules over back and upper trunk, on KOH mount spaghetti and meat ball appearance was seen. What can be the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The case given here is Pityriasis versicolor. Causative agent is Malasezzia globosa/ M. furfur

Clinical lesions are hypo or hyperpigmented macules over neck, chest upper back.

Scratch sign- positive

On KOH mount- Yeast and hyphae are seen known as 'sphagetti and meatball appearance'

On woods lamp: Pale yellow fluorescence

Treatment: Azoles, selenium sulphide

Option A: Trichophyton sp. Causes dermatophyte injection- Tinea cruris, Tinea corporis, Onychomycosis.

Option D: Hortaea werneckii is causative agent of tinea nigra.

Option B: Candida sp causes intertrigo, oral candidiasis, Onychomycosis

Key takeaway:

Pityriasis versicolor

  • Causative agent is Malasezzia globosa/ M. furfur
  • Clinical lesions are hypo or hyperpigmented macules over neck, chest upper back.
  • Scratch sign- positive
  • On KOH mount- Yeast and hyphae are seen known as 'sphagetti and meatball appearance'
  • On woods lamp: Pale yellow fluorescence
